Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 10:14AM Blessings2011 wrote: I've had a scrip for Vicodin forever. It never, ever, took my pain away, but it did make me not care that I had pain! Two weeks ago, I had my BMX with TEs. Had morphine in the hospital, and Norco sent home with me. Norco barely touches the pain at all, as I think it may be nerve pain which is notoriously difficult to control. I take the Norco at night, and since I've been home, I haven't slept for more than 1 - 2 hours at a time. I didn't consider that part of it may be the Norco....my brother told me that when he took Vicodin, it was like taking pure speed. I may have to rethink my pain control regimen here.... What does help for sleep, and is relatively safe and without major side effects, is Benadryl.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2013 11:06AM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, cmv - it sounds like you sure have gotten the run-around! But at least you persevered and got yourself to a breast specialist. While we may really love our primary care docs and OB/GYNs, they just don't have the expertise that a dedicated breast surgeon/breast center specialist has. My mom had BC, diagnosed at the age of 60. She opted for a radical mastectomy, had no more treatment or any reconstruction, and passed in 2009 at the age of 88, still no evidence of any more cancer. Me? In the back of my mind, I always wondered when my turn would come. I had heavy, droopy, dense fibrocystic breasts, full of lumps, yet every year when the mammogram came back negative ("Congratulations! Your recent mammogram showed no evidence of cancer!" read the postcard I would receive every year.) I begged my PCP for an MRI, or at least an ultrasound, and his answer was always "Those are not screening tools." Fast forward to September 2011. I was sitting at the table eating breakfast when my nightgown felt wet. I looked down and saw two large bloodstains. My left nipple was bleeding. Well, THAT got the docs attention, and two days later I was in the breast surgeon's office. She reassured me that it was probably just a papilloma, but to be on the safe side, she'd order some other tests. My radiologist was awesome. She was like a pitbull, determined to find anything hiding in all that dense tissue. The ductogram was not exactly successful. First, we could not express any discharge. (It was dark reddish brown.) Then we got a little, and the cannula would not go in all the way. She kept trying and apologizing, and I laughed, because surprisingly it didn't hurt. Finally she got a bit of dye in, taped the cannula down, and rushed me over to the mammo machine. Well, THAT worked in expressing the discharge - I bled all over the machine. I went on to have seven diagnostic procedures in all. What they found in the beginning was DCIS - ductal carcinoma in situ - meaning abnormal cells that were completely contained within the duct. The ultrasound-guided core needle biopsies, though, found two micro-invasions of IDC, or invasive ductal cancer. I was very fortunate. It was caught early, and the invasive parts were very tiny. I had a bilateral mastectomy, only because of my age (60 - the same age as Mom when she was dx'd) and because the radiologist suspected there may be more in the right breast. There was no lymph node involvement, and all the margins were clear. I did not need chemo or radiation. I had my final reconstruction (implants) last summer, and I do have to say the New Girls look pretty darn good. Now, having said all that, keep in mind that I am quite a bit older than you are. And to ease your mind, you may want to search for other posts from women with DCIS. Just use the search feature - there are many informative posts. Beesie is a member here with lots of experience and info. Finally, I want to tell you that in Dr. Susan Love's breast book, she says that by the time most breast cancer can be either palpated or detected in biopsies, most likely it has been in the body for 8 - 10 years!!! That kind of took away my urge to go back and smack my PCP for not listening to me.  You are doing exactly what you should be doing....ruling out anything serious. Despite your history, the reality is that the majority of breast lumps/breast issues are benign...NOT cancer! So try to take a deep breath, and in the words of another member here (NatsFan) "Don't go there until you get there." In other words, just let the docs do their job. Give them time to get more pieces of the puzzle in place before you panic. With DCIS, you are not in a huge hurry like you might be with a fast growing tumor, so let the process unfold. Soon you will have answers, and I am hoping they are good ones. Wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: Upcoming Ductogram/Biopsy (long, sorry) cmv cmv

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 08:50PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi KSD! I had an LAVH in 1998 and was in the hospital less than 24 hours. This was for a complete hysterectomy due to fibroids the size of Volkswagens. I didn't really have much pain in the hospital, and I wish I hadn't used the morphine PCA because I didn't need it. My sister spent the first night at home with me because it was hospital policy. But I remember her boyfriend ringing my doorbell at 8 the next morning, and fixing him breakfast....grrrrrrr I shooed them both out of there pretty quickly. As I recall, I just rested and napped for a day or so. I do remember the phone ringing on the third day or so, and running down the hall to answer it. About halfway there, I thought to myself "this probably isn't a good idea....". Your body will let you know when you've overdone it. The beauty of the LAVH is tha there are very few sutures and they are internal. You might have a stitch or two where they insert the scopes, but otherwise it's a MUCH easier surgery to recover from than a traditional hysterectomy. I took the maximum amount of time off work, not because I needed it, but because I could. Honestly, I think you may be surprised at how fast you recover. It's always good to have help lined up just in case, though, especially with kids. That way it's there if you need it. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 11:29AM Blessings2011 wrote: Christy826 - You've already gotten great advice here, so all I can add is that when it comes to breast cancer, there is NO BLAME, NO SHAME. You did not do this to yourself. Even women who are in absolutely perfect health and have no family history of cancer can get it. But the most important thing I can say is that the MAJORITY of breast lumps and issues are benign - NOT breast cancer! NatsFan has a phrase that I immediately stole because I liked it so much: "Don't go there until you get there." In other words, let your doctor order as many tests as he or she wants. They really do like to have as many pieces of the puzzle as they can get before they sit down and explain things to you. Once you have the opportunity to do that, many of your questions will be answered,and hopefully, you will have peace of mind. Wishing only the best for you!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 12:23PM Blessings2011 wrote: Christy - when our fears get to the point where they interrupt our daily lives and almost paralyze us from getting on with life, it's probably time to see a counselor. Many women here ask for, and receive a prescription for Ativan, an anti-anxiety medication. You may want to check with your doctor. But I also believe in talk therapy. We are always here on BCO, 24/7, but we're not at your house, or in your head. Sometimes the greatest gift we can give ourselves is to find a guide who can help us navigate the scary parts of life. In this case, a therapist who works with people with illnesses may be a better fit for you. We are not born knowing how to deal with issues like this. Sometimes we learn the hard way, and sometimes we need a hand to hold along the way. Life doesn't have to be this hard, and anyone can learn new ways of coping with difficult situations.  I just hate to hear such fear in your words. Please talk to your doctor about resources to help you cope through this time in your life.

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 07:43PM Blessings2011 wrote: ek25 - So sorry you got blindsided by the IDC diagnosis. I defer to Beesie for her wonderful explanation of DCIS. All I can tell you is what happened to me. You can see my dx in my signature line. Last fall I had some bleeding from my left nipple. The breast surgeon assured me it was probably a benign papilloma, but sent me for further testing "just to be on the safe side." Seven diagnostic procedures later, it was finally determined that I had primarily DCIS with a microinvasion of IDC. The first few biopsies only showed DCIS. I was offered a lumpectomy with radiation, but since my cancer was multifocal (in two different places) the BS suggested a unilateral MX. Well, I considered this and all my other options very carefully. I had many, many risk factors, and my Radiologist was worried that something could be starting in the right breast, even though nothing showed up on mammography or US. I made the decision to have a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. Prior to my surgery I had a radioactive isotope injection. Then during my surgery, I had a SNB, which was sent down to Pathology, and came back clean. Had it not, the surgeon would have taken additional axillary lymph nodes. All the margins were clear, and there was no evidence of any cancer on the chest wall. The tough part is waiting for the Final Pathology Report. You think you have all your ducks in a row, but everything depends on that final report. Well, not only were all the margins clear, so were the remaining parts of the sentinel nodes that were taken, AND - there was no evidence of any IDC. They said it was so tiny that the biopsy had gotten it all. Plus - there was no evidence of cancer in the right breast. Had I been a younger woman, I probably would have chosen lumpectomy with radiation. But at the age of 61, I had been worried about BC since my mom was dx'd at my age. I knew BMX was right for me. I did not have the Oncotype test, nor did I have BRCA testing. Currently, my risk of recurrence (either local or distant mets) is 1% - 2%. I have lost a considerable amount of weight and started exercising. That has further reduced my risk to .77%. And when I start Anastrozole (generic Arimidex) in the Fall (because I'm ER+), that will reduce THAT tiny risk to 0.33%. Obviously, there are no guarantees when it comes to BC. But I get my new ta tas in 3 weeks (permanent implants) and I plan on being the oldest person in the nursing home with perky boobs. Wishing you the best......

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 04:57PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, kbeyer30 - I'm so sorry to hear of your mom's passing. I know this must be a very emotional time for you. I had a benign fibroadenoma removed from my right breast when I was 18 years old. I was pretty ignorant of breast cancer in those days, and I figured it wasn't hurting, so why do anything? When I got to college, the campus doc immediately sent me to a surgeon, who removed a golf-ball sized tumor. Regular mammograms after that showed nothing. Now it's 43 years later, and I have been diagnosed with DCIS and IDC (a combination of non-invasive cancer and invasive cancer) in my left breast. It is very slow growing and was caught very early. It was not related in any way to my fibroadenoma. Having a "risk evaluation" sounds like a smart thing to do, if only to put your mind at ease. There are amazing diagnostic tests and treatments these days. Make a list of the questions you do have, and if you forget any, I'm sure you can call them back later. Best of luck to you and your sister...

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2013 11:20AM Blessings2011 wrote: MishaT - I am six months out from Exchange, and had been dealing with "Iron Bra" issues the whole time. I started seeing a Myofascial Release Massage Therapist, who also specializes in Lymphedema and breast cancer patients. One of the things she did on me was "scar tissue mobilization" to loosen up all the scar tissue and fibrosis that was left over from my BMX, and extensive pocket work during Exchange. She even found a lot of scar tissue around my drain incisions... I can't describe how much better I feel after seeing her! I have absolutely no idea if it's too soon, or even appropriate for you to get this kind of treatment on your biopsy scar tissue (having had a thrombosis), but it may be worth a call to find out. Be sure to check with your breast surgeon first. You definitely need a licensed practitioner who is experienced with breast surgery and reconstruction.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2012 10:27AM Blessings2011 wrote: I checked into the hospital for my BMX at 9 a.m. for my radioactive isotope injection. Of course, I had been fasting since the night before. My surgery wasn't scheduled until 1:30 p.m., but was delayed til 3:30 p.m. Of course, I got no lunch. My stomach was already growling. I finally got to my room around 8 that night. I missed dinner. All I really wanted was ice chips and to sleep. The next morning, when they brought my breakfast tray, it was beef broth, and jello!!!! They thought because I had requested anti-nausea meds during my anesthesia, that translated into a "bland diet"...NOT! I got the same thing for lunch, and finally begged the lunch lady to go steal me a tray from anyone who had already checked out. I got a turkey sandwich. It was yummy. The one thing I will caution you about is all the "comfort casseroles" dropped off by well-meaning friends. I had visions of coming home and eating light, nutritious meals, but every single meal that friends brought were heavy on the fat, cream, cheese, mayonnaise, cream soup, and just made me feel awful. DH was happy, though.... The other thing is that if you are taking any narcotic pain meds, TAKE THE STOOL SOFTENERS TOO!!!!! Seriously. Constipation is something you DO NOT want to deal with!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 03:26PM Blessings2011 wrote: Questions to those who commented.   How old are you, and what phase of life are you in?  (this is very important, as I am 60 and have different need from a 40-something, etc.) I was 60 when dx'd and 61 now. I am married and I have 6 grandchildren. Are you completely healed from your surgery/recon?...or still in progress? I have healed really well from my BMX in December. All my sutures are healed, and I have just had my last set of fills, which have been extremely easy and mostly painless. My PS is very impressed with the lack of any complications. I now have a three-month waiting period for my exchange surgery. Describe being numb......I'm trying to understand.  1.  Are you describing  numbness as no feeling or sensation, as if that area is not attached to your body...completely void of touch? I have almost complete, normal feeling all over my skin - all the way down my chest, and over my foobs, except for small - VERY small - numb spots. As for feeling deep inside the breasts, I still have the rock-hard tissue expanders in, so I can't tell you what feeling I'll have after my exchange surgery. I have a tiny section - 1 or 2 inches - in my left armpit where my SNB was done, but complete feeling in the right. I do have some numbness in the IMF on the right.   2. Or - The numbness from nerve damage is a different feeling, one to be more concerned about..  Are you describing  a painful, tingling numbness like when your hand goes to sleep and you feel like ants are crawlling all over you? I've had absolutely no painful tingling numbness like that....no phantom pains, no sharp stabbing pains, no "electric shock" kinds of feelings....none at all. I do feel sore when I try to do too much, like working out in the yard. 3.  Are you describing the numbness of a recon breast, or the core of your body, like in the ribcage under the breast?  Up into the arm? My body feels good. I have full range of motion in both arms. I have no limitations on lifting from my PS, only from the PT who talked to me about LE. (Which I don't have.)   What I learned from having a cervical fusion years ago is that nerves can take up to 2 yrs. to heal after surgery.  If you are going through recon, this prolongs the healing until after 2 yrs. of that being done. It would be interesting to know how may STILL have pain/numbness 2 years after being completely done with all surgeries. I'll let you know in two years! Mallory - imbalance would be a BIG issue for me.  Thanks for pointing it out. Right now, my foobs are smaller, and symmetrical. This is a first! I am loving it! Risks - it seems like it is about a 50/50 split on whether to wait to see if more problems develop, or be proactive and reduce risk from the get-go.  That is a very personal issue, and I think the stage of life you are at plays a big impact.  For example, I am now 60.  In 10-15 years, do I want to go through this again at the age 60. The only complications I am thinking about now are whether or not my permanent saline implants will last as long as I do. If they need to be replaced when I'm 81, will I care? Or will I just say "To heck with it!" Recon - all of you who commented had recon surgery.  Just wondering how this all plays into your comments of numbness and pain.  For the first three weeks after I got home from the BMX, all I did was cry about the painful TEs. I think it was because there was a foreign body inside me. The prescribed narcotics and Valium took care of that. But soon, the awful pain turned into painful discomfort, and from there, to annoying discomfort. Now I pretty much forget about them, and am even sleeping on my sides again. Sexuallity - are you saying that the numbness and lack of sensation bothers you during sex?  Is this the real issue? DH was adamant that he would rather have  ME healthy, than breasts that weren't. He is still attracted to me, and ironically, I find I am much less inhibited now than I ever was before. He has been with me for every procedure, surgery, and fill, and is my biggest advocate. We're careful right now, because of the TEs, but we certainly have future plans!!!
Posts.Title: UMX or BMX? kem510 kem510

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 04:51PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, kem510 -  I was a 38DD/38DDD before I was dx in December with DCIS and a microinvasion of IDC in the left breast. I was offered a lumpectomy with radiation, but the BS said I may not be pleased with the outcome - because the cancer was multi-focal, she would have to take such a large wedge of tissue, the breast may look deformed. She strongly suggested MX. During this time, the radiologist was working diligently to dx the right breast. In her gut, she felt that there may be "something" there in the right, even though it was very heavy and dense, and nothing was showing up on mammograms. I thought long and hard about my options. I knew that I would not be pleased with the looks of the lumpectomy as the BS described to me. I also knew that a UMX would mean a lift and reduction on the right.....and the chances of making the girls match up were slim. There would also be the future worry about continuing diagnostics on the right. (My mom had breast cancer.) I'd always wanted a reduction, but this was a H#LL of a way to get one. Now, though, I've told my PS I wanted to be smaller, and he agreed, saying he was surprised that I didn't have more neck and back pain with my large breasts. Who knows...maybe I did! With all my risk factors (and I had a lot) I decided on a BMX with immediate reconstruction, and I have never regretted my decision for a minute. This did not guarantee I was "cured", nor did it guarantee I'd never have a recurrence, local or distant. Just having the BMX does not ensure you will not need chemo or rads - only the final pathology report and subsequent testing can do that. But my final pathology report came back good, my risk of recurrence is small, and my treatment will consist of Arimidex for the next five years. This is a really personal decision, and I wish you well with it!

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2013 09:13PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Shabby!!! So sorry to hear you're still having discomfort. I hear you about the Iron Bra feeling!!! I thought that would disappear with Exchange. You're about six months behind me in scheduling... my BMX was in December 2011, and my Exchange was in August 2012. From the minute I got the New Girls, I was miserable. I never, ever, got that "ahhhh" feeling that everyone else seemed to get the minute the TEs were out. The PS wrote it off to all the pocket work he did. Physical therapy didn't really handle cases like mine. () Not only was the Iron Bra feeling of horrific tightness there 24/7, I also had excruciating pain. I did start going to a myofascial release therapist, who found tons of scar tissue and fibrosis... in SO many places! (Not just in the pocket areas...) It took months of her manipulations and my stretching exercises for the pain to go away. Now, I still have extreme tightness and the Iron Bra feeling 24/7, but honestly, if I don't focus on it, I don't think about it as much. I complained to my MO that I feel my implants every minute of every day. She said to give it time. I said "It's been a YEAR!!!" She said give it MORE time. She explained that the brain has a memory of how the Old Girls felt, and now it has to create new memories of how the New Girls feel. Once my brain has figured out that what I'm feeling is now my new normal, it won't bother me so much. I asked what I could do to hurry my brain up, and she just smiled and gave me the look. I did have a prescription for Valium which I took at night after a nice long bath. Sometimes that helped. So sorry I don't have better advice... just gentle hugs!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 01:11PM Blessings2011 wrote: ATLgadgetgrrl - My mom had BC when she was 60, (and I was 33), so I started getting my mammograms when I was 40, I think. Unfortunately, in those days (1983) they didn't know much about BC, and after her radical mastectomy, she had no other treatment, and passed away at the age of 88  from completely unrelated causes, with no recurrence of cancer. However, each time I had my mammogram - and I had one every year - I kept wondering "Is this the year it will be positive?" I had extremely dense, heavy, fibrocystic breasts, and my PCP refused to refer me to an ultrasound or an MRI, saying that they weren't screening tools. But when I had spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple in August 2011, THAT got his attention! Turns out it was multifocal DCIS (non-invasive cancer) and two areas of IDC (invasive ductal cancer). The tumors were very small and caught early, and I decided on a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction as my treatment of choice. Luckily, I didn't need chemo or radiation. Now, having said all that, let's back up. You have BC in your history, so naturally you are concerned. You've been having symptoms, which naturally elevates your anxiety. HOWEVER - the problem with self-diagnosis (and this includes the notorious Dr. Google) is that unless the information we gather is SPECIFIC to our diagnosis, it does us more harm than good. Start small. Go through the steps that your breast surgeon (and I do hope you are seeing a breast specialist) recommends that you take. Start with the least invasive procedures, and work up from there if you need to.  This will give you the information that you need to 1) learn more about your condition, if there is one, or 2) give you complete peace of mind that what you are going through is not cancer. The reality is that the majority of breast lumps, problems, and issues are benign - NOT breast cancer. I'm praying this is so for you!
Posts.Title: Complete understanding of what is going on: smart, or madness? ATLgadgetgrrl SelenaWolf

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2012 07:03PM Blessings2011 wrote: Tamiami - I think it varies. During BMX, the Pathologist only looks at a thin slice of the Sentinel Node that is removed. If cancer is found in this one slice, then the surgeon is notified, and an axillary lymph node removal is done during the BMX. Then the following day, the rest of the SNB tissue is dissected along with the removed breast tissue.  After my surgery, the BS did come out and let my family know that there was no lymph node involvement, and that all the margins were clear, but we knew we had to wait for the final pathology report for the "official" word. I think I had my final pathology report by the time I had my one-week Post-Op appointments.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 10:28PM - edited Jan 24, 2014 10:32PM by Blessings2011 CeciliaVera - I wish I could remember word for word what I wrote on another forum, but it has to do with realizing that none of us knows how much time we have left on this earth, and I, for one, will no longer suffer fools needlessly. In my experience, most people are not interested in any detailed medical information unless it pertains to them. "How are you doing?" is kind of a default question when you don't know what else to say. And those who interrupt and divert the conversation to themselves never wanted to hear the answer in the first place. If someone asks me how I am doing, then interrupts my answer, I just interrupt THEM and say "Oh, I'm sorry. I thought you asked me how I was doing. Did you not want to let me answer?" And then proceed to stare at them intently. Or if somehow my breast cancer experience turns into some dramatic response from them, my standard answer is "I'm sorry, but what part of this is about YOU?" And again, the unblinking stare. I'm particularly fond of the expression "EXCUSE ME?" along with the icy stare. Or there's the old Ann Landers/Dear Abby line: "If it were any of your business, you'd already know the answer to that." I do give my loved ones a lot of leeway. Some of them are truly concerned, and just clumsy when it comes to using the right words. Every time that happens, it's a teachable moment. I'm really not a horrible person!!!  Thanks for listening!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2012 11:13PM Blessings2011 wrote: When I was 46, I started perimenopause....hot flashes every 20 minutes, and night sweats every 45 minutes. I went on hormone replacement therapy (Estrogen/Progesterone). That stopped my hot flashes. When I was 47, I had a total hysterectomy (including ovaries), and switched to Estrogen-only hormone replacement. I stayed on HRT for nearly ten years. Then I figured I was through the worst of it, so went on Estroven (plant-based) for a year. Finally, I quit everything. It was over. No more hot flashes or night sweats for me. Last year, at age 61, I was dx'd w/ BC, and I was 100% ER+. I argued with my MO, telling her I didn't need an AI because I was 1)post menopausal, and 2) I had no ovaries. She kindly pointed out that estrogen is produced in body fat - especially belly fat, of which I had plenty. I went on a diet and exercise program and lost 56 pounds and more than 65 inches. She said I reduced my risk of recurrence by 23%. And yes, I did start the Anastrozole. Interestingly enough, I haven't had any hot flashes. Absence of "cold flashes", yes, but no hot flashes. Is it because I was so ER+ the AI just hasn't had time to suck all the estrogen out of my body? Or is it because I'm so far past menopause and hysterectomy that there really wasn't much estrogen in there to begin with?

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 08:34PM Blessings2011 wrote: justamominOH - welcome to the forum....so sorry you are having symptoms, but glad you found us. I've had mammograms for the past 22 years. I had heavy, dense, fibrocystic breasts, yet every year I asked for an ultrasound or MRI, my PCP refused it, saying that those were "not screening tools"... So each year I'd get a chipper little postcard telling me "Congratulations...there is no sign of breast cancer in your recent mammogram." But a few months after my last one, I had some spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple. THAT sure got the PCP's attention! I was in the Breast Surgeon's office the next day. She suspected a papilloma, but referred me for more testing just to be thorough. After seven different diagnostic tests, they found invasive ductal cancer as well as ductal carcinoma in situ (non invasive cancer).  Thank God for a Radiologist who had the tenacity of a pit bull. Even though she told me that one tumor was acting just like a fibroadenoma, she wouldn't stop til she had a good tissue sample. Fortunately, what cancer they found was early and small, and I did not need chemo or radiation. What angered me though, was the fact that the Radiologist said she could make out the areas of cancer as far back as 2009. (But she said that was only because she knew what she was looking for.) The point of that story is not to scare you, but to urge you to find a professional who has your best interests in mind. It's true: the MAJORITY of breast lumps that women find are benign. But you want a doctor who will assure you of this after taking all steps possible to rule out anything else. Wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: Sent for mammogram & diagnostic mammo.......Is this weird? justamominOH justamominOH

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 08:30PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, figaro - glad for your good news, and hope you continue to be symptom-free! One morning last fall, I was sitting at the breakfast table and my nightgown felt wet. I looked down and there were two blood stains, about an inch and a half in diameter each. I realized it was coming from my left nipple. This had never happened before. A day later I saw my PCP, who booked an appointment with the Breast Surgeon for two days later. When I saw her, she reassured me that it was probably an intraductal papilloma, a very common condition among women, but it would have to be surgically removed as it would only get worse. Just to be on the safe side, she sent me for some diagnostic tests. I had more mammograms (one where I bled spectacularly all over the plates), a ductogram (where the Radiologist could not insert the cannula into the duct), a few ultrasounds, and two US-guided core needle biopsies. It wasn't a papilloma. It was multi-focal DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ), with multifocal microinvasions of IDC (invasive, or infiltrating ductal carcinoma). Everyone was surprised except me. (I had many risk factors, including a mom with BC.) Because it was so small, and so early, I was offered a lumpectomy with radiation. But due to the multifocal (in two different places) aspect, my surgeon recommended a unilateral mastectomy. I made the decision for a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. I don't regret any of my choices, and now, four months later, am doing really well. I did not need chemo or radiation. I think if I were just starting out, and I had doctors who suggested diagnostic procedures, I would take advantage of them and have them done. There's no reason to be suspicious that every little thing is cancer (in fact, it usually ISN'T) , and it's great when a test can definitely rule it out.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2011 04:05AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Lesley! Your dx sounds a lot like mine. I have multi-focal cancer: one tumor of DCIS and IDC, and a second tumor of just DCIS. I had two mammograms, two ultrasounds, an U/S-guided core needle biopsy, a ductogram, and a second U/S-guided core needle biopsy. I wonder why they didn't do an U/S of the lymph nodes on me? Hmmmm.....I haven't had genetic testing, either. Not sure if it's even important at this point.... I'm having TEs inserted in preparation for saline implants down the road. This is the breast reduction I always wanted, but never got At first, the TRAM flap and DIEP flap sounded too good to be true (Perky foobs! Tummy tuck!!!) but I decided that I would be happy with just the implants. If I have to have them replaced in 10 - 15 years, so be it. I'm just not ready for a flat chest yet. I want the implants to remind me that I need to take care of my body, and get healthy in other ways, but I think the scars will also remind me of what a warrior I am. My mom had breast cancer when she was 67, and had the MX but no reconstruction. I won't have an oncologist AFTER the final pathology report is in. If there is no cancer in the lymph nodes, then most likely I won't need chemo. If there is no cancer on the chest wall, then most likely I won't need radiation. Glad to "meet" you, my December sister!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 06:38PM Blessings2011 wrote: Rodeotimeagain - Sorry...this is kind of long. I'm too wordy!!! I had the same fears. I've had pretty severe fibromyalgia for the past ten+ years. I've been through an intensive pain management program, and while my symptoms are fairly well-controlled, all it takes is some episode of acute pain to throw me into a fibro flare again. So prior to my BMX/recon I did what I could to prepare a little "nest" at home....DH and I rearranged things so they were convenient for me to reach, and had plenty of little healthy, snacky things to eat, along with some toddler sippy cups so I'd stay hydrated no matter what. Then I ordered a fully-electric hospital bed.BEST IDEA EVER in my case. I have degenerative disk disease and some spinal stenosis, along with arthritis. I love my Tempurpedic mattress, but without the use of my arms there was no way I could get in and out of bed. I put a memory-foam mattress on the hospital mattress, along with my electric blanket. I got an over-the-bed table, and DH rigged up an remote control to my reading lamp. Prior to my surgeries, I was surprised at how little pain I experienced with all my diagnostic procedures and biopsies. In the hospital, I was adamant that I did not want morphine in my PCA, as I'd had a bad reaction to it with my hysterectomy. But that's what I got, and sadly, never got the full benefit of it as I only pushed the button once an hour instead of every ten minutes. When I was discharged the next day, I was still having trouble controlling the pain. The PS sent me home with Norco, which is the same as Vicodin but has less Tylenol in it. Really didn't help much. Ironically, it wasn't the mastectomy that was the most painful - it was the tissue expanders that they put in. It felt like my chest was on fire from the inside out. There were times I just lay in bed and cried because I couldn't get a handle on the pain. My PS told me to just keep taking the maximum dose of Norco, around the clock if I had to. DH even made sure to bring me my 4 a.m. dose so I'd have it in my system. I could only sleep for an hour or two at a time. I started to play around with the drugs that I thought might help. I knew that the TEs were pressing on ribs and nerves and muscles, and I tried Robaxin and Flexeril, along with some Aleve or some Motrin. Once I realized I had very little pain in the actual MX incisions, I started having DH do some trigger-point therapy on my back before I went to bed. Then I would take a hot shower with my shower massage directed at the sore muscles in my back. I took a Norco at 7 pm, another Norco at 8 pm, and an Valium at 9 pm. The first time I did that, I slept for four solid hours. It felt great. I also started doing my deep breathing, relaxation, and meditation exercises during the day. I was also pleasantly surprised at how good the hospital bed made my back feel. I raise the knees up as far as they will go, then recline the head back to about 45 degrees. It takes all the pressure off my spine, which is great. I agree with what your docs office said about the intensity of the pain. For me, I know my brain has trouble distinguishing between a friendly punch on the arm, and getting run over by a train. The pain signals go wild, and drugs don't help much. Everyone on the forum kept saying "Just give it time!" and each time I heard that, I wanted to scream "But you don't understand....it's not discomfort, it's PAIN!!!" Well, they were right. Today I went to a Post-Mastectomy exercise class. I am four weeks out from my BMX, I got my first set of fills yesterday, and get this - they actually made my TEs feel BETTER!!! I have great range of motion, and instead of feeling like I'll never make it 8 more months til exchange, I feel like I now have control over this. I didn't have a DIEP flap, but I don't think that just because you have FM it will take you longer to recover. Just follow your doctors orders (Seriously! ALL of them!) and don't try to be a hero about taking the pain meds. Your brain *may* process more pain signals because of the FM, but then again, you may be used to so much pain already, you may not notice pain that other women do. Here is the truth: This, too, shall pass!!!! Good luck and big prayers for your upcoming surgery!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2014 09:29PM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, yeah.... I told everyone. I am a retired counselor and educator, and always felt it was my mission in life to educate others, even if it meant using my own experiences. I called family members personally, had it announced in church, posted it on my Facebook page, and referred everyone to my Caring Bridge website http://www.caringbridge.org/  This is a website that allows you - or DH or a friend - to post updates on your condition. This way we didn't have to explain things a gazillion times to each person who inquired. I kept everyone updated, and DH did it when I was recovering from surgery. The nice thing about Caring Bridge is that family and friends can leave you encouraging messages. Shoot, I've even been known to flash The New Girls to people who were curious as to what a reconstructed breast looks like. (Mine look pretty good...) HOWEVER - we are all different. When my friend got dx'd, she told her husband, her sister, and me. That was it. She wanted it kept totally private.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 10:40AM Blessings2011 wrote: After I came home from surgery (BMX w/TEs) I was in such severe pain I cried every day. I think the MX was o.k., it was the AMAZON sized TEs the PS had inserted....plus the fact that I was trying to be brave and not take the pain meds. I never got more than an hour of sleep at any one time, and was exhausted. FINALLY, I listened to the wise women here, who said TAKE THE MEDS!!! And so I did. Around the clock. DH even woke me up every morning at 4:00 a.m. for my Norco dose. But at at my ONE  WEEK post-op appointment, the Breast Surgeon, who up until that moment I adored, yelled at me "What do you mean you're still taking the Norco? You should have been off all of that days ago!!!!! And in that moment she became a mean old witch. Fortunately, my appt with the Plastic Surgeon was right after that, and he reassured me that it takes as long as it takes, and what the BS said was really stupid (only he was more polite). He said I'd been through a lot, that this recon stuff was painful, and that he would be there to approve refills should I need them. And in that moment, he became Prince Charming.
Posts.Title: What does/did your MO/RO/BS/PS say that made you want to scream? Momof2inME Wordwrangler

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 06:19AM Blessings2011 wrote: I just wanted to stand up in defense of those who DID have pain after their procedures, and took pain meds. Without going into detail, I went home from the hospital in pain after my BMX w/ TEs  because I refused the morpine PCA at my bedside. Once home, I tried not to take the pain meds, as I had read so many posts from women here who said "Oh, it was nothing...." or "I just took a few Tylenol and was fine..." That made me feel like a real wimp, and so I stuck it out in pain for way longer than I needed to. The truth is, we all react to pain differently. Our bodies are different, our treatments are different, our surgeries and our SURGEONS are different. There is absolutely no way we can - or should - compare ourselves to anyone else on the forum. Now, having said that, I DID listen to the wise women here who told me to take the pain meds if I needed them...which I did. It helped immeasurably, and allowed me to get back on track with my life. A body that is in pain is stressed, and a body that is stressed won't heal quickly. There is no shame in taking pain meds; in fact, it may ultimately help the healing process if you find you need them.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2014 10:34PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Mommyandmore - so sorry you are going through this right now. MelissaDallas is right in that many women have fibroadenomas. When I was 18 years old, I had one the size of a walnut removed from my right breast. (That was a really long time ago, and I guess that was the only way they could see what it was. Sheesh - the olden days - no ultrasounds!) I never had any problems after that, and my breast cancer diagnosis at age 60 was totally unrelated to that. You said: I obviously need a follow up appointment with a real doctor, but the only one I can get is with the PA again. Could I please have advice about what to do? Why is it that you can't you see a doctor? Is it a matter of cost? There are many breast centers now that have services available for women at low or no cost. If it were me, I'd probably ask to see a Breast Specialist. Only a doctor would be able to request a specific kind of biopsy. However, it doesn't sound like the Radiologist who read your ultrasound scans was too worried.... I really wish we could give you advice here, but none of us are doctors. All we can do is tell you to take a deep breath, and if you feel you need to investigate this further, then go for it. Just remember that the MAJORITY of breast issues are benign - not cancer. Please come back and let us now how you are doing. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 07:19PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hello, Ladies! Unless I hear differently tomorrow, I will have my Exchange surgery on August 22nd. WooHOO! Got my dx last September, but my surgery got rescheduled twice. Talk about anxiety! Finally had my BMX w/TEs on December 5th. Trust me on this: the anticipation is WAY worse than the reality! I was totally OCD about making lists of everything I would need in the hospital and at home. I packed an overnight bag that I NEVER EVEN OPENED in the hospital. I'd bought a boatload of special mastectomy camis, drain holders, etc., that I never even used. I woke up wearing a giant Ace bandage, and ended up just pinning my drains to it with cute diaper pins. Since I couldn't shower with drains in, didn't need a lanyard or shoelace for the shower. I got a bunch of front-zip and front-button tops, thinking it would be forever before I could use my arms again. It was only a few weeks. I wore a zip-front sports bra from JCPenney after the Ace bandage came off, and when I was done with my fills, I lived in my Genie bra. We have a Tempurpedic bed that is difficult to get out of sometimes on a GOOD day (like swimming in Jello), so I rented a hospital bed for the month after my surgery. Smartest thing I ever did! I am NOT a back sleeper, and that worried me the most. But I put a memory foam pad on the hospital mattress, and also had an over-the-bed table. DH rigged up my reading lamp (over on a bookshelf) to a remote control, and attached that to the bed controls. It was so easy to lay back at the correct angle, and raise the mattress up under my knees so my back felt supported. If I wanted to sit up and get out of bed, all I had to do was raise the back all the way up, and I didn't have to use my arms. I got some satin jammies at Sears for cheap, and they really helped getting in and out of bed. None of our recliners were comfy enough to sleep in, and I couldn't reach or manage the controls. We put snacks and dishes out on the counter within reach. I used my travel sippy mugs for at night, so I wouldn't spill. It's really important to keep good records, so we made a space in the bathroom for the "Drain Station" where we kept the alcohol wipes, the measuring cups, and the logs. We also had a log for pain meds. Ah....the pain meds.....I came home from the hospital in pain, because I didn't use the morphine PCA by my bed. I wanted to be one of those women who came home and took a Tylenol, then ran a marathon the week after my surgery. Alas, that wasn't me. I did have more pain than I should have, and it was all my fault. I had great pain meds, and when I finally started taking them the way they were prescribed, the really bad pain changed to annoying discomfort. DH even got up at 4 a.m. to give me my Norco dose. By the time I got to fills, I had no pain at all. And if you're taking pain meds, TAKE THE STOOL SOFTENER!!!! Seriously. You think you won't need it, but you will. And you do not want to get to the point where you need Milk of Magnesia. I got filled to 620ccs in five visits. I never had any pain associated with the TEs or the fills until I lost 50 pounds, Then it got hard to sleep on my side again. I'll be getting high profile smooth saline implants. Can't wait to cross over to the squishie side! Here is my favorite quote from BCO: "I just want this breast cancer to be a bump in the road in my rear-view mirror!" Feel free to PM me with any questions..... And big honkin' hugs to all of you who are just starting out on this journey!!!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 08:14PM Blessings2011 wrote: Damiana - I got my Genie bras pre-BMX when I was HUGE. They looked horrible on me. Fortunately, I didn't toss them. So they were big enough post-BMX. I hear you about tight bands, though - awful! Dc1262310 - Genie Bras come two to a box for $19.99. You can get them at Target, Walmart, Kohls,  Bed Bath & Beyond, and lots of other places. They are pull-over-the-head, or step-in. I slept in my recliner just fine, and this morning was up early to go out and get the paper. I let DH sleep in ! Thanks to all for your prayers and good wishes! I have officially crossed over to the Squishy Side!!! WOOT!!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2012 04:46PM Blessings2011 wrote: WELL..... we had the Grand Unveiling this morning. Fortunately, I knew what to expect, so wasn't too disappointed. After being wrapped like a mummy in a very tight Ace bandage for 72 hours, the implants were shaped more like TEs, and had gotten a bit, er, dented at the bottom. But I took a shower......ahhhhhhhhhh.....washed my hair......ahhhhhhhh.....and then after I dried off, I put a Xeriform strip across each incision. I can't really tell if the PS extended them at all, but there was some recent bleeding on one of them and a lot of dried blood on the other. He said he had used skin glue on both, and to go ahead and get both wet, but y'all know how OCD I am about germs!!! So on went the Xeriform, and then we taped mini-pads inside my sports bra (sticky side against the fabric) so nothing would rub the incisions. Within about an hour, the bottom half of the implants started to fill out. I still have a tiny crease on the bottom of the right one, but I also have quite a bit of swelling from the additional release of the pectoral muscles in the IMF. I can also tell I'm pretty swollen in my upper chest (I think he did a lot of work up there,too), but once I get to the ol' Drop and Fluff, they should be lookin' pretty good. I definitely don't have stripper boobs! We didn't want to take a chance on uncontollable pain this time, so have been hitting the Norco, Cipro, and Benadyl on a regular basis. Cut back on the Norco today - I'm just sore, no constant pain whatsoever. I have been eating my protein (100 grams a day, girls!) and napping like a big old housecat. I figure I have a prescription for two weeks of couch potato, and I'm taking advantage of it!!! Sorry to be lazy, but I might copy and paste this post in a few other threads. Hope everyone is doing well and having a good weekend!

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2012 11:08PM Blessings2011 wrote: Beckers - I was blissfully ignorant when I first got diagnosed. I let that "But it's a GOOD cancer" statement lull me into complacency. The reality is that once you have invasive breast cancer, you have some risk - however tiny it may be - of it coming back again, either as a primary (new cancer) or as mets (metastasized into other organs). I was fortunate. My cancer was small, and it was caught early, and I had the maximum surgery for the minimum cancer. But the reality is, there are Stage IV women who started out with my exact same dx. THAT was a sobering realization. And the more complex your cancer is, and the more treatment you need, I think it's natural that your mind takes you to a place where the worst case scenario is staring you in the face. But here's the thing: I believe that most women do NOT go on to develop mets. However, it's just another one of those crap shoot things - you can do everything right, and for some reason, that tiny speck of cancer left in your body decides to mutate and grow. I decided that for me, I would take my 0.38% chance of recurrence and go with that. No, make that ZERO percent. My faith sustains me and gives me hope. I believe in my heart that I am healed of cancer. I believe I will die of something else. In the meantime, I have a responsibility to educate myself so that my future health is my #1 priority. With regard to my Stage IV sisters, I have just gotten back from a very angry place in my head. I have been reading posts for months about "Pinktober" and "Pinkwashing" and truthfully, have been horrified, shocked, furious, and just plain enraged about the fact that every October we have this tsunami of pink, and everyone and his dog wears a pink something, and that is supposed to create awareness of BC and make us all feel good that we're doing something positive. Well, HELL, trust me: I'm aware. Now where's our cure? What are your pink socks doing for MY breast cancer? (Among other snarky thoughts I've had.....) I had a great chat with my MO about cures, and her point was that finding a cure takes research, and doing research takes TONS of money. I've just emailed her to ask which organizations she feels are the most responsible and the most dedicated to actually finding a cure. I'll post her suggestions here when I get them. But for now, the anger has subsided somewhat. I will definitely resist the "Pinkwashing" and all my Facebook and Caring Bridge friends will get my "Pinkwashing 101" lecture. I will continue to walk in the Komen Race For The Cure, because I now understand better the motivation of some of the women I saw last year who freaked me out. Pink wigs, pink tutus, the whole circus atmosphere totally turned me off. I was two weeks post diagnosis and completely lost. My MO was the one who helped me put it into perspective....she said that many of those "frivolous" women had lost someone near and dear to them, and were expressing their grief, or their elation that someone had survived - in different ways. Many of them were survivors themselves. Our local support group will be having a team, and staffing a booth there. I've spent a year now on BCO, and I'm at the place where I'm ready to find a place to give back to my community. I read somewhere that if you're not giving, you're taking. So I plan to find my niche and start giving back. Am I worried about my future? Am I scared about the possible progression of my breast cancer? Not a bit. Like I said...I will be vigilant, but not obsessed. I am grateful for my BC dx - had it not been for that, I would not have made so many important changes in my lifestyle. Like Maya Angelou says: We do the best we can with what we know. And when we know better, we do better. And THAT, my sweet friend, is the end of my Saturday night soapbox speech. I hope it made sense. (And yes, you were absolutely right to eat those three cookies. It was meant to be.) xoxoxo

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 11:02AM Blessings2011 wrote: Omeggo - Ohhhh.....I'm overdue for my colonoscopy. I just figured with everything else going on this past year, I needed to give myself a break. But Kaiser is sneaky....if you don't follow up on your recommended appointment, they'll mail you a kit for a fecal occult blood test that you mail back in. I haven't even done THAT yet! Thanks for the reminder.....and hope you are feeling nice and clean and emptied out , and have nothing but good results from your test. Beckers - I started Anastrozole (generic Arimidex) on September 5th. (Kicking and screaming, I might add...I really didn't want to take it. But I had to do lot of soul-searching, and finally realized - as my mom used to tell me - "Honey, you won't know until you try.") So I put on my Big Girl Panties and swallowed the first pill, and the next day I did the same. I was like Alice in Wonderland...waiting for something dramatic to happen. It didn't. Now it's habit. I just don't ever want to get to a place where I'd be saying "Oh, I wish I had taken it when it was offered to me..."  As for the liver, what an awesome organ. It can take tons of abuse and still, it is the only organ in the body that is able to regenerate itself. Many things affect the liver - and yet it can still be repaired. When I was on the fasting phase of my diet, my liver enzymes shot up very high. I was terrified, not because of possible mets, but because I'd had HepB many years ago. I am VERY protective of my liver, thankyouverymuch. Fortunately, the docs ran tons of tests, showing that there were no lesions and no active disease. They figured that the high numbers were the result of the low calorie diet. I'm back on food now, and the liver enzymes have gone back down. But I do keep a very careful watch on them. And the Anastrozole = so far, so good. The only thing I'm noticing is that I'm no longer suffering from COLD flashes!!! I can sit in an air-conditioned room without my sweatshirt!  I do keep a log of possible symptoms for my MO, though. ~~~~~~~~~~ Yesterday we ripped out the pathetic, twig-like trees in our parking strip. We've been here for seven years. The first trees were planted by the developer....Crape Myrtles, I think. They never grew. Then we put in Chinese Pistache. Same thing. Skinny, sad looking trees. Then I decided I wanted Gingkos....I knew they were slow growing, but I didn't care. What I didn't anticipate was that they would get SMALLER...... So last week we went to a local nursery and picked out two large October Glory maple trees in 24" boxes. The crew planted them yesterday, and showed us how to water them. In a few weeks, they'll turn the most gorgeous shades of reddish orange and gold, and it will be soooo nice to look out in front and see the colors. Can't say it's fall here yet (it was 104 last week, this week it's in the 80's) but one of these days!!!!!! Hope everyone has a wonderful, relaxing weekend.....just take a look at Mother Nature's beauty and don't forget to just b-r-e-a-t-h-e!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 06:58PM Blessings2011 wrote: Dear August Sisters - I posted this in another thread, but thought it might be helpful here. Most of you going through chemo already know that certain chemo drugs are tototoxic (can cause hearing loss). One of my friends (who had several different cancers and multiple rounds of chemotherapy) discovered too late that she lost a significant amount of hearing after her chemo, and needed hearing aids. Unfortunately, she had never gotten a hearing test before she started chemo, so there was no evidence that this loss was caused by her treatment. If she DID have a baseline audiogram prior to starting chemo, and followup audiograms showed hearing loss, then her insurance would have paid for her hearing aids. Sadly, she had to pay for them out-of-pocket - not cheap - I think they were about $3,400. Those of you who have started, or will be starting chemo might ask your MO about getting a baseline hearing test/audiogram. Just a thought....

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2012 10:03AM Blessings2011 wrote: Tazzy - totally normal. I've had surgeries in the past, where one minute I'd be in the living room talking with DH, then get up to go to the bathroom, and he wouldn't see me for four more hours, as I was lying in bed taking a nap. One question: are you getting enough protein? Unless you have a medical condition that restricts the amount of protein you take in, most of us need at least 100 grams of protein a day to heal. My DH has kidney disease and is restricted to small amounts of protein. After my BMX, I was eating the same food he was. DUH! That was only about 25 grams. Once I upped my protein intake to over 100 grams (supplementing with whey protein drinks and organic turkey jerky) I felt much better. In the beginning, I needed help to walk the 50 steps to our mailbox. I leaned heavily on DH's arm, and would get back to the house exhausted. I thought the fatigue would never go away. A few months later, I was biking, power walking, and doing water aerobics. Hang in there! Prayers and good thoughts for all our August girls who have come home from procedures and are recovering. And great big prayers and hugs for our Shabby, who is having her sugery today!!! xoxoxo

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 09:54AM Blessings2011 wrote: Aw, Mumtothree - big honkin' hugs to you!!!! When I got my BC diagnosis last September, my first impulse was to call my mom, who'd had breast cancer and a radical mastectomy, with no reconstruction, at the same age I was. But then I remembered she had passed away three years ago (from other causes - she was 87, never had a return of the cancer) and that I couldn't phone her. I think that upset me almost as much as hearing the diagnosis. Eventually, I realized that she is with me every day, and all through this, I have heard her words of wisdom in my heart. You are going through a lot right now, and yes, it does feel like insanity at times. Please believe me that the anticipation is WAY worse than the reality. I think one of the worst things our friends can do in the way of "supporting" us is to make us second-guess our decisions. Somehow, they think they know what's best for us. Not true. Here's the thing about reconstruction - you don't have to do it now. Many women, for many reasons, have delayed reconstruction. Many are like you - they just don't want it. But years down the line, they change their minds for whatever reason. Others have to delay it in order to have treatments first. But recon is an option that is still open to you in the future. I had a bilateral mastectomy in December, with immediate reconstruction. Tissue expanders were placed, I was filled to 620ccs in five visits, and decided to wait til I had lost weight before I got permanent implants. My exchange surgery will be in three weeks. I knew there could be serious complications with recon, and if that happened to me, so be it. I was used to seeing my mom flat, and to me that seemed normal. But I'm 61, and I knew that I needed a reminder that I would have a new body to take better care of. The implants were part of that decision - I lost weight, started exercising, and got smaller, perkier boobs. (The Original Girls were 38DDD - droopy, heavy, fibrocystic, and painful. Now I'm thrilled to be able to see my feet again, and I've even gone braless - for the first time since 5th grade!!!) And please don't ever discount another intimate relationship in your future! I was single my whole life, and figured I would be so until the day I died. But when I was 48, I reconnected with a guy I'd known since I was four years old, and we married when I was 54. So never say never!!! About the pics - there is a picture forum that is totally separate from this site, and is managed by a BCO member. Because of the sensitive nature of that site, the general rule is that you have posted a while here, to show that you are supportive of other women going through this disease. I'm not sure of the number of posts you need to have, but you can PM either nowheregirl or Lilah for permission to get access to the picture forum. Hang in there, Mumtothree - your surgery is almost here. Find something you love to do, and go do it. Stay busy, stay distracted. I was OCD about planning to have everything packed, everything ready, everything planned out. Then the big day arrived and it was over so fast, I never even opened my hospital bag. I thought I'd be so disabled for so long after the surgery, and that wasn't the case at all. I was way more independent than I thought I'd be. I still can't believe my surgery was 8 months ago!!! It's really flown by. Wishing you the best......

Much of the skin is already numb from the BMX, but he will be doing  some extra pocket work once he gets in there (separating more pectoral muscle), so it will take a bit longer than usual. Still, I'm staying positive! Markat - wishing you the best on Monday! Even with scar tissue, hopefully you can come out with no drains! Beckers - I took pics the night before my BMX - not because I was mourning the loss of my breasts, but to remind me how imperfect they were before I started this journey...but just in case I got frustrated by the outcome of the reconstruction. I also took pics every step of the way (post-op, fills, etc.). Looking back, I'm glad I had a photo journal of the whole process. YAY, Tazzy!!!! May you continue to heal well and rapidly!!!! ChristyRN - Welcome to BCO!!!! You don't need to stress about reconstruction right now; many women choose (or must have) delayed recon. You are in the absolute best place for information and support. August Sisters - You know, I forgot to say earlier about how staying home is actually a good thing to do right now. Last year, three days before my scheduled surgery, I got SO sick from a snotty, coughing, sick teenaged clerk in the Apple store, that I had to cancel my BMX and wait another month to be rescheduled. I stayed home recuperating that entire time. We called it my Quarantine. And after I came home from the hospital, we told family and friends that they were welcome to call, but couldn't come over, because I was on - you guessed it - QUARANTINE!!! (Our family is notorious for showing up everywhere, sick as dogs, insisting "I'm not contagious!" ) Now that I'm going in for my Exchange surgery in 3 weeks, I'm back to wearing my surgical mask to all doctors' appointments, practically bathing in hand sanitizer, and spraying the soles of our shoes with Lysol when we come back from the clinic or hospital. Even if you haven't had your procedures yet, it's time to start being safe around germs. O.K., so I'm a germophobe!!! Thinking about Marilyn113,  Damiana, and Secret Agent who were scheduled for August 2nd (and we've already heard from our Tazzy!) Next up is Markat, RobinJoy, and Pointvalue who are scheduled on Monday, August 6th... you are all in my prayers!

DH lugged it up to my room after my BMX,  and it sat on a chair, unopened, until he lugged it downstairs and back into the car to take me home. Seriously - he'd taken home the clothes I wore to the hospital, and while I was there I wore only the hospital gown. The next day, when I was discharged, he brought me a button-front gown I knew I'd be wearing at home, and my fuzzy robe (it was December) and slippers. That way when I got home, I didn't have to change again before I went to lie down and rest. Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 10:44AM Blessings2011 wrote: GmaFoley - good news on the benign stuff! SO many women are allergic to the adhesives in bandages! Fortunately, my PS doesn't use any. I got Xeriform (that wet, yellow, gauzy stuff) then a dry bandage over that, then lots of padding, and then a huge honkin' Ace bandage wrapped around me. I didn't touch the dressings at all until my Post-op, when he did the Great Unveiling, then wrapped me up for another week. Once those came off, I was free of bandages altogether. Justegan - HOORAY for negative nodes! Morphine didn't work for me, either. So my PS sent me home with Norco (like Vicodin, only less Tylenol in it) and Valium. That combination worked very well. Abby20 - glad you are recovering well! Omeggo - Bless you for still working while you are going through all this. Part of the reason I can spend so much time on the computer is that I'm retired. Tazzy - thank you for your kind words! I love to learn about people... and have been on different "medical condition" forums for a long time. Some of my best friends are people I've never met in person. Damiana - sorry you are dealing with questions regarding treatment, but sounds like you have a good support team, and are ready for whatever comes your way. Glad you are healing well! Shabby - Tuesday is just around the corner! I have TEs; in fact, have had them for more than 8 months. What would you like to know? You asked about waking up from surgery...I honestly don't remember being in Recovery. I did get to my room about 8 p.m. (had a late surgery), and vaguely remember DH giving me some ice chips to suck on. But at 1 a.m.  I was wide awake and chatting up everyone who came into my room to check on me Britishlass - the "back sleeping" part of the BMX was REALLY annoying! I'm a side sleeper! When I saw my incisions for the first time, I told my PS that my sewing teacher certainly wouldn't give him good marks for stitching...but that it was o.k. because I knew they would settle down eventually. Happy to hear about your good SNB; prayers that the rest will be clear. Hi, melmcbee! You wrote:  I just wanted to tell everyone how much better I feel and the worrying and stress before the surgery was much worse than the surgery. That is SO true! May everyone waiting for their dates take this to heart! Glad you are home and recuperating... prayers for your next steps ahead. HMP12IND - OW! Haven't had torticollis, but I know what it is. If the chiro isn't helping you, then it's time for a specialist. I know it can be chronic or acute, and that often it can go away by itself. On the other hand, it can mask other, underlying causes and is worth investigating. I know they use muscle relaxers and anti-inflammatories, and sometimes Botox injections. So sorry this is happening - I hope you find a treatment that works for you, and relief very soon!!! Nancedawg - I always have lower back pain if I try to lie flat on my back. Have you tried putting some pillows under your knees? That takes the pressure off your lower back. Hope you get your drains out soon! Mumtothree -  sooo glad you are home and doing well!!!! Pointvalue - waiting for that final pathology report is like waiting for the other shoe to drop. You are absolutely right about drinking water! I had a boatload of antibiotics in IV during surgery, and in pill form for ten days when I got home. I didn't get a vaginal yeast infection, but I DID get one in a fold of skin under my very swollen stomach! Who knew!!! Hope you continue to heal well! OttawaMom12 - I had some extra swelling after the drains were removed...guess it had to go somewhere, and for me it was my abdomen! I looked 8 months pregnant for a while! Glad you are home doing well. Hoping that Mlo69 and Christina do well in their procedures today; big prayers for our Monday girl: Onelife2012. ~~~~~~~~~~~ Random thoughts on: Catheter - when I heard my PS was going to give me a bladder catheter, I loved him even more. No struggling to get up in the middle of the night to use the restroom!  Of course, it came out the next day, but still.... Constipation - when we go through general anesthesia, our bowels slow way down. And if we take any narcotic pain relievers, everything seems to come to a complete halt. Forget prunes and fiber - if your doc has given you Colace or a stool softener, TAKE IT!!!! Trust me on this....you do not want to resort to Milk of Magnesia! Couch potato - someone mentioned those having better toned muscles experiencing more pain with TEs than those who are flabby and out of shape. That's pretty much what the PS told me. I went from 0 - 620ccs in only five visits. My muscles were mush. NSAIDS - (anti-inflammatory meds like Motrin or Aleve). Just be sure your doc has said it's o.k. to take these. They do cause excessive bleeding in some cases, which is why you're told not to take them before surgery. Some docs don't want you taking them right after surgery, either. Mine didn't. Just check before you decide to take them on your own. Get your doc's permission. Pain meds - were given to you for a reason. If you don't need them, whoopee! But if you do need them, it's better to just take them around the clock as per the instructions in the beginning. You can always taper off. But it is very hard to "catch up" to pain. Ladies - have a great weekend!!!!

For your theme song, I'm hearing the words "Healin', Healin', Healin" sung to the tune of the "Rawhide" western TV show. Shabby - one thing I DID make sure I had was a pillow for the ride home. You put it between the seat belt and your chest. Try it out before you go to the hospital to see which one fits best, and how to place it so you're not trying to do it after you get discharged. I just used a nice soft bed pillow. As for the stool softener...I got Colace. Didn't take it before surgery, because I didn't want it to work, uh, while I was under, if you get my drift. But I sure needed it when I got home!!!! Tazzy - be glad the drains are in. When they come out, that fluid has to go somewhere. As for those muu muus, if I lived in Hawaii, I wouldn't care WHAT I wore!!!! Damiana - I tried to not be dependent on pain meds but that backfired on me. At my one-week Post-op visit, the BS (who I used to love) was very upset with me when she learned I was still taking the Norco and the Valium. "You should have been off all that days ago!" she yelled. Fortunately, my appointment with the PS was right after that. "Well, that's stupid." he said. "You need to take the meds as long as you are in pain. If you still have pain, keep taking the meds. Just let me know if you need a refill. Your body can't heal if it's stressed and in pain." REALLY love this guy! Oh, and congratulations on the, um, great exercise with your DH!!! Now THAT'S a great way to keep fit!!! June56 - don't be surprised if you do have pain with your fills, it doesn't come until later in the day. That's when the heat and back rub come in handy. OttowaMom12 - LOVE the deep breathing exercises. I don't think any of us really take deeeep breaths during the day...especially when we're stressed. We need that oxygenated blood to make our muscles hurt less, and our heart rates to slow down to stop the stress hormones. Melmcbee - hope you get more comfortable with your port.... Markat - I totally rocked the stretchy velour track suits after my BMX. Got them at Walmart for cheap. Even better - they had inside pockets in the hoodie for my drains! Christina0001 - the morphine didn't work for me, either. But the Norco (Vicodin with less Tylenol in it) was great. Lisa2012 - I've had the same thoughts about what happens AFTER the exchange....just five years of Arimidex!!!! It feels weird somehow.... Britishlass - I never met my Oncologist until three weeks after my BMX. Infobabe - Just like you said, I got my zip-front sports bras at JCPenney in a size larger than I normally wear!!! Love them! I even slept in them after my BMX. Oh, TrailGirl - they warned me about that before my surgery! I told them that thanks to years of deep, diaphragmatic breathing, my breathing rate was very, very, slow and often shallow....sometimes six breaths per minute. The nurse warned me that if I didn't breathe deeply enough I would set off the alarms!!! Glad you are o.k.! Did you have to suck on one of those incentive spirometers? They sent one home with me. Cottontail - The reason I was told not to shave, specifically on my SNB side, is that the removal of lymph nodes makes us more susceptible to lymphedema. According to my BS, we need to avoid getting BP taken, or blood draws from the biopsy side, as well as being super careful to not get any kind of cuts or abrasions that could let bacteria into the affected arm. A regular razor leaves tiny cuts in the skin - perfect for germs to sneak in to. She told me to use an electric shaver. It's kind of a moot point, though ....after menopause, I was left with tiny little gray fuzz instead of armpit hair. But it's more than just shaving.....check out the Lymphedema threads! Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 09:55AM Blessings2011 wrote: Shabby - I think I mentioned that I stayed on the pain meds(Norco, plus Valium) around the clock for nearly three weeks. Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2012 07:33PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hellooo Sisters!!! Beckers  - I sent you a PM. Omeggo - you'll have fun with the Vitamix!!!! melmcbee - gentle hugs to you...may tomorrow be a better day!!! ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Today was my one year cancerversary! On September 15, 2011, I got the call saying I had breast cancer. I decided to celebrate today by going to a luncheon sponsored by an amazing group of women breast cancer survivors and their supporters. What an awesome, upbeat, funny, and proactive group of women! When you are dx'd with BC, you can call their office, or go on their website, and request a tote bag of information. Then a breast cancer survivor delivers it to your house personally. The totes themselves are so pretty....beautiful fabric, with an embroidered angel and pink ribbon on the front. Inside, the totes are packed with wonderful goodies, including Dr. Susan Love's breast cancer book. My survivor sister and I hit it off so well that she and talked for three solid hours. I was hooked. Now I think it's time to give back, so I will be thinking of ways I might want to volunteer my time. They have a monthly luncheon, as well as other activities during the year. All funds go to supporting local women who have been diagnosed, or need services. I even won two door prizes today! (One from a raffle ticket another woman gave me as an anniversary present ) Afterwards, DH and I just went for a ride in the foothills and spent some quiet time together.  We had told family and friends that this process would take at least a year....and I think we're right on schedule. When we sat down to dinner, there was a beautiful card on my plate. (One o' them WORDY ones that kind of makes you cry, it's so sweet.) He just wanted to honor this day, and he did. May all my August sisters have a restful, renewing weekend!!!! xoxo

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 10:23PM Blessings2011 wrote: Dear August Sisters: I posted this over on the "Songs That Get You Through Hard Times" thread, and thought I'd share it here. If you are not at this place in your journey, have faith. You will be. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Last night I watched the movie "The Help" for the second time, and this song - "The Living Proof" was sung by Mary J. Blige during the credits at the end. It made me cry, and I think it was because I was thinking of the past year of my life. Here is the video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WfmdjKTH1a4&feature=related Here are lyrics: It's gonna be a long, long journey It's gonna be an uphill climb It's gonna be a tough fight It's gonna be some lonely nights But I'm ready to carry on. Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2012 07:03PM Blessings2011 wrote: Wow. Last year, before my BMX, I took all my bras and put them away in a box. (I was a 38-40DD/DDD) I knew I'd never be able to wear them again, so they were in the "donate one of these days" boxes. But after my exchange last month, I got curious. I pulled out a few bras, and realized very quickly that regardless of how much the underwire fit around the implants, the cups would never be filled, and would always have wrinkly, empty spaces. I knew, though, from reading bra threads, that minimizers are good for women who've had breast recon but not nipple or areola recon. Just before my PS appt this morning, I dug through the box one more time, and sure enough, found one I hadn't tried on. It's a front-closing underwire with a racer-type back, size 36DD. IT FIT PERFECTLY!!!!   I haven't been in for a professional fitting because the PS wanted me to wait. But when I showed him this bra, he was VERY impressed, and wrote down "minimizer" to share with his patients who complained that they no longer could fill a bra cup. The underwires tend to be wider, and the cups are shallower. I've been wearing it all day, and it's SOOO comfy! Can't post the name yet because I'd have to take it off. Anyway, had a good one-month post-exchange visit. He says I'm healing well; his only concerns are Lefty, who still has a considerable amount of fluid in the upper region (he says it's NOT the implant), and also a tiny area of incision that hasn't quite closed. So no pools for me yet. Righty is looking pretty darn good, except for what I found out was a small stitch protruding from the incision. I told him I was tempted to pull on it, but then I had visions of ripping out the hem of my skirt. He said to leave it alone and it will resolve on its own. Yanking on it creates a pinhole, which - as we all know - can get WAY bigger and cause all sorts of issues. So tonight I'm a happy camper. There are some loose skin issues and areas he may want to address later, but for now, I go back to see him in two months. Hope all my August sisters are having a relaxing Monday evening!

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 08:24PM Blessings2011 wrote: To all the girls who are really dealing with BMX and TE  pain right now - hang in there! I think I cried every day for three weeks when I got home from my BMX last year. I just wanted it to be OVER. I didn't want a long recovery, I didn't want to feel disabled, I was tired of feeling weak, I just wanted to "turn the corner" on pain and be done with it. It made me feel like a big weenie when I'd read about someone who went home from BMX, took a Tylenol, then ran a marathon the next day. Well, that was not me. My PS put it into perspective for me:  "Pain stresses the body, and a body that is stressed does not heal. Take the meds." I got Norco (Hydrocodone) (same as Vicodin, but with less Tylenol) 1 - 2 tablets every six hours. DH set his alarm to give me my 4 a.m. dose. I also got Valium, 10 mg, 1 tablet every 8 hours. One day we were driving somewhere (probably a doctors' appointment) and all of a sudden, I realized I was feeling almost normal. It will sneak up on you slowly, but that day will come. Don't rush it. Be good to your body and give it the time it needs to make a comeback. I promise you it will. Big honkin' hugs to all of you. Thinking about keepmovingforward, who had her procedure today. Hope she is resting comfortably tonight! Big prayers for Trinity, Mooleen, and Lisag46, as they have their surgeries tomorrow!
