Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 10:50AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hellooooo August Gals and Guy!!! To all those experiencing fatigue.....totally normal!!! Like GmaFoley said, make sure you're getting enough protein - the general rule, unless you are restricted for some reason, is 100 grams a day. For me, it made a HUGE difference! I supplemented my regular meals with Trader Joe's protein powder shakes, and organic turkey jerky. AND - stay hydrated!!!! Water is the best. Keep drinking it; flush the anesthesia, drugs, and other miscellaneous toxins from your body. And naps - even better! Years ago, whenever I would tell my mom that I'd fallen asleep and napped for several hours, she'd always say "Well, Honey, your body must have needed it!" I still hear her voice today, and listen to it. This morning was my first Post-Op visit with the PS since Exchange on Wednesday. I could tell how he frowned that he wasn't exactly thrilled with some of the things that were going on, but on the other hand, he did say I was healing well. Thankfully, I've known all about "Drop and Fluff" since last December, and knew that the day would come when I'd finally get my squishies, and even if they weren't perfect, I needed to be grateful. He did a TON of pocket work when he was in there. He removed a boatload of scar tissue from around the TEs, released the pectoral muscles at the bottoms and the tops of each breast, where they had tightened up, and did lateral capsulorraphies (narrowing of tissue pockets) to enclose the new implants. I still have loose skin at the bottom, which I think pissed him off, since he had said he would take care of that during exchange. Now he's not sure if that will resolve or not. And I have a huge amount of swelling on the left, all the way up to my collarbone, where he did a lot of the reconstruction. He says it's filled with fluid, so it's larger than the right side. But all in all, I'm happy. They're the right size, they ARE softer than TEs, but I still can feel them in a very distinct way when I flex my pecs. I'm sure that will lessen with time. Can't even think about sleeping on my side, due to all the soreness, but that, too, shall pass. I'm giving it 3 - 6 months before I even consider any revisions. Who knows, I may be so comfortable with them at that point, I'll keep them no matter what they look like. To those who just had their big surgeries.....hang in there! I promise you the fatigue will get better!!! Seriously - all I did was sleep for at least a month after my BMX...then three months later I started slow, just walking around the block. Then I started riding my bike, doing water aerobics, and power walking. I was definitely not one of those ladies who has a BMX, comes home, takes a tylenol, then runs a marathon the next day. I was a total couch potato. But I did get my energy back eventually!

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 07:10PM Blessings2011 wrote: Yay, Markat, on crossing over to the Squishie Side!!! Hope RobinJoy, Pointvalue, and Pinkie are resting comfortably. Prayers for Lisa and Lisag46 who are next on the list. ~~~~ Got a disconcerting call from the Surgery Scheduler this afternoon, telling me that my surgery was scheduled for the end of September. Well, I pitched a HUGE hissy fit (politely, of course ) letting her know that two people in her office had already confirmed my Exchange date of August 22nd. She patiently listened to my story, said how sorry she was, and how she would try to make it right by bumping another elective surgery. Well, I'm sorry too....but it's not like I'm getting big ta tas for the heck of it. This ain't AUGMENTATION, it's RECONSTRUCTION! ~~~~~ On another note, some drain tips for the newbies: We need to be REALLY careful with our drains. They are open pathways for infection to enter the body. It's good to have a drain station set up in your bathroom ahead of time. You'll have your measuring cups, your log to write in amounts, and a good idea is to have some alcohol wipes on hand. DH actually helped me with the drains. I would unpin them from my bandages, and he would uncap them and empty them into the cup, then write in the amount. I would then fold the bulb in half horizontally, and then roll it up to get all the air out. That's how the nurse taught me to do it. Then DH would carefully wipe the cap and the opening with the alcohol wipe as I kept squeezing the bulb tight, and when he put the cap back on, I'd let go. Be sure to empty your bulbs when they get half full, otherwise they don't have the suction necessary to drain off the fluid. My PS taught me this. The tubes can be filled with all sorts of gunky stuff, but as long as the fluid is still draining into the bulb, you don't need to worry. If you feel there is a big chunk in the way, you CAN try to "milk" the tubing and move the chunk. First, hold the tubing very close to where it exits your body, and pinch it tight. Don't let it move. Take an alcohol wipe or even a wet washcloth, pinch that around the tube, and pull downward. Remember, your hand is holding the tube where it exits your body (and it is also stitched into place.) Don't worry about breaking the tube; that sucker can stretch. Again, you'll probably never have to do this. Stringy gunk can accumulate in the tube without affecting the drainage at all. If it's been a while, and you're still having lots of drainage, or what's draining out is dark in color, ask yourself if you've been taking it easy as instructed. The more you move, the more fluid can be produced, and the darker the color can be. This is also a good time to be a bit OCD about germs. I never let anyone touch my incisions except the PS, and I never let anything touch my body (towel, cami, sports bra, gown etc.) that wasn't freshly laundered. DH even wore surgical gloves when he emptied my drains. ~~~~~~~~~~~~ For all those worried about ugly button- and zip-front clothing, just remember, in no time at all you'll be able to wear your regular clothing, so don't spend a fortune on the other stuff. This is just temporary. I ordered some new summer satin jammies online...they sure help sliding in and out of bed without using your arms.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 04:05PM Blessings2011 wrote: I was on pain meds (the big guns - Norco and Valium) for three solid weeks. I started tapering off right before my first fills at one month post BMX. My BS thought I should be off ALL the meds after one week. The PS thought that was crazy. He said if it hurts, take the meds. Once I started getting fills, the TEs actually started feeling better. They moved off of nerves that had been compressed, I think. Valium seems to be a common Rx for muscle spasm....I also had DH massage my back muscles, and took a nice hot shower before bedtime after I started getting fills. I think you will probably always have some weird feeling (steel plate, iron bra, boulders) with the TEs, but your body and your brain do adapt to that feeling at some point. There came a day when I actually did NOT think about the horrible feeling in my TEs, only when I consciously did so. Then it was easier to stay distracted, and not feel like I could not possibly stand the fills, much less the 3 month waiting period before exchange. But that day will come! Hugs to you.....

I changed into a button-front gown (which I planned to wear at home), my fuzzy robe, and my Easy Spirit Travel Time shoes and got in the wheelchair. DH dutifully lugged my unopened tote bag back down to the car. All I needed after surgery was my glasses, so I could tell who I was talking to! Didn't need anything else....but the pillow Shabby mentioned to put in between me and the seat belt on the ride home. ~~~~~~~~~~ One thing I may not have mentioned here is that before I got up to my room, DH went in and wiped everything down (that I might touch) with Clorox wipes. Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 01:34PM Blessings2011 wrote: Beckers - no, I didn't have to lose weight before I took Arimidex - it just turned out that way. I lost weight for two reasons: 1) my TEs were inserted when I was much heavier, and they were huge. I asked my PS what would happen if he put in permanent implants to match the TEs, and later on I lost weight, and he said the implant size would not change. So I told him I wanted to stop my fills at 620ccs, and that I'd be back when I got to my normal weight, because I didn't want stripper boobs. When I saw him again, 50 pounds lighter, his first comment on examining my TEs was "Whoa! They look so much bigger now that you're so much smaller!" Ya think?   So when I got my permanent squishies two weeks ago, I knew that they were the appropriate size for my frame. 2) The second reason is that my MO wanted me on Armidex (generic form: Anastrozole) last March. (I'm 100% ER+.) I argued with her that not only was I post-menopausal, but I'd already had a hysterectomy, so there was NO estrogen in my body!!! She kindly pointed out that estrogen is produced in body fat, of which I had plently. So I joined the Optifast program at Kaiser and have lost 50 pounds so far. I still want to lose another ten pounds (I'm 5'5", and want to get down to 140.) I wanted the MO to know I was serious about getting in shape, because if the side effects are too rough on me, I may decide to stop in favor of QOL. She said that by dieting and exercise alone, I have reduced my risk of recurrence by 23% - not bad, when you figure that my initial risk of recurrence after BMX was only 1% - 2%. I also want to lose just a bit more weight in case the Anastrozole does cause me to put on weight. But in any case, I will have to continue to keep my activity level up anyway if I want to maintain this weight loss. Then again, I could be one of those women who have NO side effects on Anastrozole!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 09:47PM Blessings2011 wrote: Helloooo Sisters!!! Big hurrahs for those who have received good news this week... Big prayers going up for all those dealing with challenges in their progress..... Tazzy - did you get Elavil (Amytriptyline)? I took that for years for my fibromyalgia. It's a tricyclic antidepressant at higher doses, but used for other issues at lower doses, such as pain management and in my case, quality of sleep. I'm off all meds now (due to Optifast) but I used to take 10 - 40 mg at bedtime. I'm still in the recliner for half the night, and in bed the other half. DH is still in the guest room, as I have to make a giant pillow fort to support various limbs and body parts. I promise you, side-sleeping will be in your future again one of these days. ~~~~~~~~~~ I am two weeks out from exchange, and doing well, except for the fact that I thought yesterday would be the day the PS lifted my restrictions. Wrong! He INCREASED them. So no lifting, reaching, driving, exercising, etc. for another two weeks. He's just being very careful with the excess swelling on the left and wants to make sure all the internal sutures are healing properly. I've gained a tiny bit of weight, but not stressing about it. I've upped my protein to over 100 grams a day, and I'm not exercising a bit. So I'm not surprised. You can't be on this diet and NOT exercise! But I have more important things to do - like heal - right now. I also saw my MO yesterday. She was VERY happy with the weight loss, and VERY firm about starting the Anastrozole now. So no more reprieve. I took my first one last night. Just now, I was sitting here sweating and cursing the evil hot flashes....then I realized that I'm wearing my heavy, fuzzy, winter robe. DUH. So far so good! Ladies - please do not fall into the trap of comparing yourself to any other woman on BCO. Our bodies are all unique and wonderful and we heal at totally different rates. We react to different things. We respond to different meds. As I've said before, I wanted to be one of those women who had a BMX, took a Tylenol, than ran a marathon the next day. Well, guess what....I wasn't. I had to finally wrap my mind around the fact that I needed the pain meds, and that being in constant pain was just another stressor on my body. And a body that is stressed does not heal. It didn't mean that I was a big weenie, although in retrospect, I do think DH deserves a medal for putting up with nearly a month of my weeping..... So - we are who we are. Awesome, brave, and persevering....and let's get through September being good to ourselves and each other. (And come here for a good rant whenever we need it.) DANG, I love this group!!!! xoxoxoxo

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2012 06:48PM Blessings2011 wrote: Ladies - I have two juicers, both relatively expensive, that are gathering dust out in my garage somewhere. Using them was a pain, it took forever to clean, and I always felt guilty about throwing away all the pulp that collected. Then we got our Vitamix blender. That thing could pulverize concrete blocks!!! We put in whole fruits and veggies and blend them all up. They say the motor is as fast as a jet engine. It's about that noisy, so I don't doubt it. But everything you put in it is completely blended up - no nutrients are lost. And - this is another neat feature...you can put in raw veggies, and the longer you blend them, the more they heat up - just from the heat generated by the friction of the spinning blades...so nothing is cooked out like on the stove. DH has his fruit smoothies every day. He'll throw in whatever's in the fridge, or whatever we get at the Farmer's Market. I used to make my protein drinks in it....lots of water and ice and whey protein powder from Trader Joes, plus Greek yogurt and fresh berries. Now I make my Optifast shakes in it: for breakfast, 2 cups of water, 1/2 cup of ice, 1/4 cup of fat free cottage cheese for protein, 1/2 cup of frozen blueberries, and a packet of vanilla shake mix. OMG - YUMMY!!!! At night I like a bowl of ice cream....so I'll put a cup of fat-free Lactaid in a baggie and freeze it. Then I put that in the Vitamix, throw in some frozen banana chunks, and for fat, I have raw almond butter and if I'm in the mood, some sugar-free Torani syrup. It comes out soooooo yummy, and without the almond butter it's fat free, and no added sugar. This is the link to their home page. Warning - they are NOT cheap. We got ours at Costco after standing around like rubes watching a demo. After the first few samples, we were hooked. https://www.vitamix.com/ After I'm done with my Optifast plan, I will definitely be doing more of the anti-cancer recipes. I love my Vitamix because nothing is lost - peel, core, seeds, whatever you put in it is totally blended to a smooth mix.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 01:20PM Blessings2011 wrote: MUMTOTHREE - WARNING - BIG LONG HONKIN' POST!!! You asked about my diet. Unfortunately, it wouldn't be appropriate for you right now, in active treatment, but later on, only if you have 40 or more pounds to lose. I went into the Kaiser Weight Management Program. (Open to the public.) It was Optifast, basically a liquid fast for the first four months, for a total of 960 calories a day. It was intensely medically monitored every week, with regular blood work and physicians' exams. Weekly meetings with our "cohorts" were mandatory, which included picking up weekly products, and weigh-ins, plus an hour of classroom time and sharing/support. For four months, I had four milkshakes a day, one soup, and one nutrition bar (all Optifast products). I ate no other food at all.  We had to drink a gallon of water a day, and exercise was mandatory. We were given pedometers, and I'm surprised they didn't implant them surgically. Around week 3, the energy kicked in. My exercise prior to that had been sitting on the couch and reaching for the remote. I had severe fibromyalgia, and the few attempts I made to exercise had been rewarded with more pain, so I quit. My first attempt at exercise, I limped down to the mailbox and back, hanging on to DH's arm. Soon, I could do it myself. Not long after that, I went walking around the block, then two blocks, and soon I was walking for an hour. I have several neurological disorders that have destroyed my balance, and years ago I fell off my mountain bike and never got back on again. So DH bought me a bright raspberry colored adult trike, and it felt great to be able to zoom down the bike trails without fear of falling. But my best work was done in the Therapy Pool at our local Rehabilitation Hospital. The water is kept at 94 degrees (heaven for sore muscles and joints) and I found I was able to do 90 minutes of workout (cardio, aerobic, resistance, stretching, and strengthening) in the water. I could never do that on dry land. A wonderful benefit to the liquid fast was that my fibromyalgia pain nearly disappeared. It wasn't from weight loss, because it happened in the first month. It was from the fact that Optifast is gluten-free. In July, we completed the fast, and started the "Transition" phase, adding regular food back into our meal plans. We follow the American Diabetes Association's meal guidelines, and portion controls are strict. We weigh and measure all our food, and log in what we eat. We have a list of options to choose from. I'm still not back on any starches (breads, rice, starchy veggies, cereals) and I don't plan to be for a while. And when I do, it will all be gluten-free. We finished "Transition" two weeks ago, and had our graduation celebration. So far, I've lost 56 pounds, and more than 65 total inches. I feel better and younger  than I have in 20 years. I've gone from taking 12 prescription medications a day to two, and all my labwork is normal again. I originally went into the program as ammunition against my oncologist.   When I met with her after my BMX, she wanted to put me on Arimidex. I protested loudly. Not only was I post-menopausal, I'd had a hysterectomy, so there was NO estrogen in my body!!! She kindly pointed out that estrogen is manufactured in body fat, of which I had plenty. I called the weight loss program the next day. She was thrilled to see me again when I finished the program, and told me that my risk of recurrence had been reduced by 23% just by diet and exercise. (And yes, I did start the Arimidex....) The program is expensive ($4,300), long (82 weeks), and takes an incredible amount of discipline. We had several members drop out. I kept going because I looked at it as my breast cancer treatment. I hadn't needed chemo or rads, but I COULD control my weight, so to me, it was medicine. Cheating wasn't an option. Now we are in the "Lifestyle" phase, which means we meet once a week to weigh in and monitor our progress, and continue to learn in class and support each other.  Even though it's technically an 82 week program, it's really for life, and the support will always be there if we want it. I still want to lose another 10 pounds, though...they say Arimidex tends to put on weight, so I'd like a little margin. I also have to get cleared to go back to my water aerobics program. There's a tiny area in Lefty's incision that hasn't healed, so until that does, no 94 degree water for me! So there you are. What I did was drastic, but being 100% ER+, I thought it was worth it. There are many other ways to reach the same goal. The principle is the same = eat less, move more. I'd amend that to eat HEALTHY and move more. I used to tell my university students "Sometimes you just gotta take care of business, and right now, school isn't your business." (They had other personal or health issues to take care of.) For you, going on a big diet right now doesn't seem like the smart thing to do. More importantly, I would think you'd want to make sure you are putting good, nourishing things in your body, and staying as active as you are able to. You are still in the healing process, so just be good to your sweet self.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2012 09:49AM Blessings2011 wrote: waterpolomom - well, the implants will sure be DIFFERENT from the expanders....so much has to do with the size of the expanders when they were put in. Because of the way they are constructed, they have a hard plastic back that rests on your chest, and pushes all the saline out in front to stretch the skin and pectoral muscles. (Either that, or out to the sides, giving us those attractive "side boobs".) Have you been over to the "Breast Implant Sizing 101" thread? Whippetmom is our resident implant sizing guru. There are so many factors that go into choosing the right size of implant for you. Regardless of whether or not you choose saline or silicone, they will never have that forward projection that the TEs do, that makes you look you're a walking chest of drawers with the top drawer pulled out all the way. They will be softer, and nestle down into the pockets, and conform themselves to your chest wall in a much different way. That being said, there are ways to choose implants that give you a similar appearance and projection as your TEs. Like I said, Whippetmom is a genius. I went to my PS with her suggestions, and he used exactly the brand and type and size, and they are perfect for my frame. ~~~~~~~~~~~ nbnotes - The Roller Coaster of Emotion is a cruel carnival ride that no one wants to get on, and sometimes there seems to be no way to stop it. Love you and praying for you!!! ~~~~~~~~~~~~ Tazzy - happy retailing. We're on our way to the beach. I need beach therapy. Bad.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 01:22PM Blessings2011 wrote: Cottontail - I've stripped my drains by myself - you just do a little at a time. I'm right handed. I'll tell you how I did it. Scrub up well, then with your left hand, grab the tube where it exits your body. Pinch it and Hold it tight. Then with your right hand, use an alcohol wipe, and pinch the tube tightly. Holding on tight at the exit site, use your right hand to pull down on the tube as far as feels comfortable. The wet wipe will make it slide easier. Don't worry about breaking the tube...those suckers are stretchy! When you've gone far enough, then move your left hand down from the exit site, pinch again, and with your right hand, repeat the stripping motion. (It's kind of like milking a cow.) Keep repeating until all the fluid in the tube has moved into the bulb. I will warn you, though, that there can be all sorts of stringy gunk in the tube that never moves down into the bulb. As long as fluid can get past it, it doesn't matter, and the gunk can stay there til the drains are removed. Here is a really key part: always empty your bulbs when they get half full, or there won't be enough suction left to pull fluid from your body. AND - after you empty the bulb, fold it in half horizontally. Then roll it up to squeeze all the air out. Use an alcohol wipe to clean both the opening to the bulb, and the little plastic cap that goes into it. Then insert the cap. This way you are creating the maximum suction for your drains. As for leakage around the exit site, you could possibly have an infection there, having nothing to do with drains themselves. After my drains were removed, the right side stayed open for a long time, and looked awful. But the PS said to leave it alone, and that it would close up when it was ready. I was armed with tubes of Bacitracin and bandages, but he said no. Always check with your PS if ANY infection is suspected! Good luck to you.....

But my MO told me she wanted me on 5 years of Arimidex, because I was 100% ER+. Having read all the horror stories on BCO about the SEs from AIs, I pitched a hissy fit. I told her that absolutely no way was there any estrogen in my body - that I'd gone through menopause at age 47, and had a complete (ovaries included) hysterectomy at age 48. She very kindly pointed out that estrogen is still produced in the body, especially in belly fat, of which I had plenty. That's what prompted me to go on that Optifast plan. I wanted ammunition so I could argue further for no AIs. But somewhere along the line I had a major shift in my perception. Once I had lost the weight, my risk of recurrence dropped another 23% - down to 0.77%. Taking the Arimidex would further reduce that tiny risk by 50%. I thought about how I had dodged the chemo and radiation bullet, and how many women wish that taking one pill a day would have such a benefit. I heard my mom's voice (herself a BC survivor for 27 years) inside my head, saying "Honey, you won't know until you try..." Long story short - I am taking the AI. Started Anastrozole on September 5th. So far, so good. ~~~~~~ Yes - it's been quiet around here, and I, too, hope that everyone is doing well and just being busy with life. I see my PS this afternoon....Lefty is still having issues. Righty is behaving well...becoming nicely rounded, soft, and perfectly in place; Lefty is still swollen and higher up on my chest, plus there are some areas of thickened skin that are starting to bother me. There may be a revision in my future, but I'm just too tired to deal with it right now. DH and I will be heading down to southern California for a week at the beach....a long-needed break for both of us. But I'll still be online!!!! Hope everyone is having a good week!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2012 03:16PM Blessings2011 wrote: Well, I'm back from seeing the PS.... Ever since my exchange on August 22nd, Lefty has been more swollen than Righty. The PS said it was just excess fluid from all the pocket work he had to do, and that it might take 2 - 3 months for it to resolve. Well, tomorrow it will be 11 weeks out for me, and Lefty still sits a bit higher than Righty, which really isn't noticeable unless I'm totally topless, and pointing it out. (Which I'm usually not... ) A few weeks ago, I started noticing a thickening in the lower, inner corner of Lefty, near the IMF. I thought it might be scar tissue forming, and possibly preventing the implant from fully dropping into the pocket. I had all sorts of images in my mind about a possible revision down the road, and while I WOULD like more symmetry, I just don't have the energy for more surgery. So I saw the PS after lunch today. He said the thickening was just fatty tissue, and that he still felt the swelling in the upper pole was excess fluid that would eventually resolve. He didn't believe it was part of the implant sitting too high. He did say I could try to massage that area more to see if it would go down. I talked to him about symmetry, and that was hard, pointing out EXACTLY what I felt could be improved. After all, that's his creation I'm criticizing! He took it very well, and said that if I wanted a revision to make Lefty match Righty exactly, he could try to remove Lefty's implant, put in a smaller one, and overfill it gradually to see if we could make it match Righty. At that point, I said that 1) this would involve more surgery and more recuperation time (which I would DREAD); 2) when we start fooling around with MILLIMETERS of change, there's no guarantee it will work; and 3) I could end up with a worse result. He agreed. He knows I am a member here, and also on the picture forum, and am well aware of the difficulties some ladies have had just getting to where I am now. I said that while I was sad to hear there was no easy fix, I was glad to hear that there still could be normal changes down the road for me. I also told him that I felt blessed to have had the good healing I've had since the BMX in December, and that if these are the New Girls I'm supposed to have, I consider myself fortunate. DH says he only notices the differences in The Girls because he has taken numerous pictures of them (for my photojournal) ever since my surgery in December. Otherwise, he couldn't tell at all. So now it's time to move on...I've been released to exercise in the therapy pool, and can't wait to get back. I'm finding more of my old bras I can wear, only now they look GREAT instead of my huge old boobs being squished into them. And who knows....there may be a trip to see Vinnie next summer!!!! Life is good.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 05:01PM Blessings2011 wrote: Please forgive me if I've posted this already...my brain is mush... A few days ago I was looking at my now four-months-out Exchange scars, and thinking that they were healing pretty well....when all of a sudden I see a red bump on Righty..... exactly on the incision line.  Of course, I poke at it, and yellowish clear stuff oozes out. Then I poke it some more (doing a "more extensive medical examination"), and a hard, yellow lump comes out, leaving a tiny gaping hole.  Of course, I was FREAKING OUT!!!!  Naturally, I poked it some more, got some more fluid out, then it bled a bit, and stopped. Brilliant researcher that I am, I consulted Dr. Google, and determined that I had a "spitting suture"... how lovely!!! Apparently, after surgery, not all dissolving sutures dissolve. Some of them can be rejected as foreign objects in the body, and they become inflamed or infected, and gradually work their way out of the skin, using the path of least resistance. In my case, it was my supposedly closed up incision. I treated it with hydrogen peroxide and Bacitracin, and emailed my PS. He confirmed that it was most likely a "spitting suture" and to keep doing what I was doing and to come in if the redness did not go away. I changed to alcohol wipes in order to dry things up, and now it looks pretty good. There was a place on Lefty that looked like it was going to do the same thing, but I took care of that with the hydrogen peroxide/Bacitracin/alcohol regimen. Well, I had planned to go back to the pool after New Years to work off some of this excess poundage that seemed to cling to my gut, but with the incisions springing leaks, no pool for me!!! Oh well, two steps forward, one step backwards...at least my knee and toes are feeling better!  ~~~~ So sorry to hear about the psoriasis, Granellie. Hopefully they can give you something topical or oral to relieve this, and that you won't have to go off the Anastrozole.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 01:32PM Blessings2011 wrote: Happyraccoon -(your name just makes me smile!) Recovering from breast cancer diagnosis, treatment, and surgery is a process. Some days it may seem like you will never smile again. But you will. Allow yourself to grieve what you must, and celebrate what you can.  It will get easier with time. As for me, I am getting used to the New Girls. I decided to stop calling them FOOBS. They are, after all, a part of me now. Except that I wish they FELT more like a part of me. At times, they still feel very tight inside, like an internal bra...or.....GASP!!! TEs !!!! But I understand that will pass .... eventually.... I signed up for the "Restart" program at Kaiser - that's eight weeks of Optifast products to get us in shape for the upcoming holidays. I stopped exercising after my exchange (Ps's orders, thanks to the pocket work) and the pounds came slowy creeping back. I made the decision to walk at our local Komen Race For The Cure in two weeks. Regardless of whatever political opinions I may have of corporate Komen, I adore the woman who is our local organization director, and appreciate the fact that around 90% of all funds raised remain here in our local area to benefit local women. To All My August Sisters  - I've been on other "medical issues" Internet forums for 11 years. Some of those folks are the best friends I've never met in person. We've kept each other sane through the darkest  times, and laughed and celebrated together during the best.   It's amazing what a bond forms when you are allowed to just be yourself in spite of your issues, and when you know in your heart that others understand. As for prayer - I do pray - for everyone here - that we all are able to deal with the challenges that come our way....and that - most importantly - we never let a bunch of statistics define who we are.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2012 08:02PM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, Sisters... This is such a germy time of year! Last year, my BMX was originally scheduled for November, but I got such a horrific upper respiratory flu, it took me a month to get well enough to have my surgery in December. From November 5 to December 5, I didn't leave the house except for pre-op appts. And I always wore my mask. Same thing as for my exchange. Two weeks beforehand, I went into "quarantine" so that nothing would jeopardize my surgery date. For those of you going through chemo, I hope you are taking extra precautions right now... My DH has severe kidney disease and is on Prednisone and Cyclosporine. His immune system is destroyed, and he cannot fight off any infections. We buy our surgical masks by the case, and  practically bathe in hand sanitizer. Our social life has been curtailed, thanks mostly to ignorant people who show up everywhere sick as dogs and spread their germs around. Some family members are the worst! I caught a cold from my FIL, Mr. "I'm not contagious", and I was furious. He was coughing in our faces, not even bothering to cover his mouth. I made DH take the iPad over to his house and made him watch this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-K_boO2oceI I also sent over some information from the web explaining that we are contagious for 48 hours BEFORE we show symptoms, and for up to 1 - 2 weeks AFTER our symptoms go away. DH and I also spray Lysol on the soles of our shoes before we enter the house - especially when we've been to the hospital or clinic or nursing home!!! In fact, my PCP was the one who told me that I should wear a mask any time I came to Kaiser....that there were lots of sick people there, and that many germs were airborne. SO......please be careful out there!!!! xoxo

No surprise about the low energy levels... here's hoping you feel better and stronger every day!!! nbnotes!!! So glad you were able to have an LAVH - that makes SUCH a difference in recovery time, and I know you've had multiple surgeries already.  Glad you are tolerating the Arimidex well so far. Hi, GmaFoley!!! Hope you had fun at the party. ~~~~~ Well, I had a mini-meltdown last month... it's been six months since my exchange from TEs to 700cc saline implants. I never once felt that "AHHHH" feeling you're supposed to get after surgery, and in fact, it got worse. It felt like a vise grip around my chest, and every time I raised my left arm (cancer side) I had a painful "snapping rubber band" sensation down the middle of my implant. I still had extreme swelling on the left side (up to my collarbone) as well as that excruciating "Iron Bra" feeling 24/7. I tried to talk to my PS, and he thought the New Girls looked good...what exactly did I want him to do?  I saw a Certified LE therapist/PT at the hospital who was totally useless - she ordered me $600 worth of compression garments that had no effect at all... Finally I found an awesome myofascial release therapist who got rid of the fluid buildup in only 5 visits. She also started reducing my pain and tightness from scar tissue and fibrosis. But then I got really angry and questioned ALL my decisions for reconstruction. I contacted Dr. Khouri's office in Miami for micro-fat grafting and implant removal. I wondered if I should have had a DIEP. I was mad at everyone on my medical team, when only months before, I adored them. I started thinking that they had only fed me minimal amounts of options in considering my reconstruction. Anyway, long story short: I went to see a terrific therapist who helped me see that I had a lot going on in my life before the BC dx (including my husband's kidney disease) and I never really had a chance to deal with any of the other stressors until now. She said that I just now finally allowing myself to acknowledge everything that had been going on, and that while some of my concerns were legitimate, (pain and stiffness, physical complaints, etc.) that I was being really hard on myself in second-guessing my choices. So today, here I am, six months out from exchange. The New Girls are not so new any more, the Iron Bra is loosening up, and I think I've decided that risking another surgery for revision is not worth it, considering that the outcome may not be better than what I've already got. I'm just SO ready for closure!  I'm tolerating the Anastrozole pretty well; I have a lot more aches and pains, but that just means I need to move more. I've kept off 50 of the 60 pounds I lost, but still fit into my size 8 jeans (WOOT!). All I can do is take it one day at a time. I think that's all any of us can do! I think of all of you often, and hope you all are doing well!!! xoxoxoxo

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 02:17PM Blessings2011 wrote: When I realized I couldn't sleep in ANY of our recliners (a suggestion from many women here) I decided to rent a fully-electric hospital bed. Our Tempurpedic bed was just too hard to crawl in and out of without the initial use of my arms, and pillows just kept migrating all over the place. For me, the hospital bed has been a godsend. I am a side sleeper, and with the back problems I have, I knew sleeping on my back wasn't going to be easy. But I put a memory-foam topper on the  hospital mattress, along with my electric blanket, and an over-the-bed table with all my goodies within reach. At bedtime, I get into bed, raise up the bed under my knees to take the pressure off my back, and recline the back until I'm comfortable. My back has actually never felt so good!

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2012 01:55PM Blessings2011 wrote: neugirl - awesome advice you've gotten here!!! My dx is very similar to yours. I got my dx a year ago last September, and had a BMX with TEs in December 2011. In March 2012, I entered a weight loss and exercise program, and to date have lost 60 pounds and more than 65 inches. I didn't do it to look good; I did it to save my life. I am 100% ER+, and it was one thing that I DID have control over. I didn't need chemo or rads, so I looked at this as my breast cancer treatment. I had my exchange surgery in August 2012, and today, I look better and feel better than I have in 20 years. That BC diagnosis saved my life in SO many ways!!! It was definitely a wake-up call for me. And it made me reevalutate many things in my life. I am grateful for the little things, and don't give any energy to the stupid things. Yes, there are sad stories here. Women with metastatic breast cancer (Stage IV) can be very ill, and it is devastating when we lose a sister.  But in the year and a half I've been here, I've also read incredible stories of courage, perseverance, and bravery. Every single woman here inspires me in one way or another. Could I have a recurrence? Absolutely. But I'm not planning to. When I was working, I made a poster for my office that said "It's never too late to become the person you've always wanted to be." That's what I plan to be doing in the next 30 or so years. It sounds like your life is in turmoil on several fronts right now. I totally agree with Wren - when getting through the day becomes impossible because of our thoughts, it's time to get help. A good counselor can be a wonderful gift you give yourself, and can help you learn new ways of coping. Oh, yeah....my mom had BC. She was dx'd at the age of 60 - same as me - and went on to live a very full life until she passed at the age of 87 from unrelated causes. Wishing you peace and comfort....

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 11:44AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, bev - Sorry you're here, but very glad you found us. My mom had BC, diagnosed about the same age I am now (61). She had a radical mastectomy, no recon, no treatment. Back in those days, it was either "benign" or "malignant". In the back of my mind, I always wondered if each year I had my mammogram, would this be the year something showed up? Ironically, nothing ever showed up on my mammos. Instead, I had some tiny bleeding from my left nipple one morning. Seven diagnostic procedures later, they told me I had multifocal cancer: two areas of DCIS, and two smaller areas of IDC (invasive ductal cancer). I was offered a lumpectomy and radiation, but because of my history (Mom's BC, 30 years of birth control pills, 10 years of hormone replacement therapy, and heavy, dense, fibrocystic breasts) I chose a bilateral mastectomy (BMX) with immediate reconstruction. At the time of my surgery, the Breast Surgeon (BS) removed all the breast tissue. During the operation, the Sentinal Node (lymph node that "lit up" when I was injected with a radioactive isotope)) was removed and sent to the lab. They sent back word that there was no cancer in the sample they looked at, so no more nodes were removed. (My final path report showed clear margins all around, no lymph node involvement, and no evidence of cancer in the right breast. My tumors were very tiny, and in fact, there was not even any evidence of the IDC - they said the biopsies had removed it all. I did not need chemo or radiation, but I will need to take Arimidex for the next five years to remove estrogen from my body.) After the BS finished her portion of the surgery, the Plastic Surgeon (PS) stepped in, and through the incisions the BS had already made, made pockets in between my pectoral muscles and inserted tissue expanders. TEs are like deflated implants. They have a metal port, and once you heal from your surgery, they are inflated every two weeks until there's enough room to insert a permanent implant (saline or silicone). I was sent home with two surgical drains, which didn't hurt a bit. They were sutured into place, and in my case, covered with an Ace bandage so the tubes never moved. DH was my "Drain Man", emptying them and keeping charts. When the PS removed them two weeks later, I didn't feel a thing. I hate pain as much as you do, and I have to tell you that none of my biopsies hurt more than a bee sting or a little pinch. The mastectomy itself wasn't all that painful because breast tissue is mainly fat and glandular tissue. I did have some pain right after the insertion of the tissue expanders, but my PS was awesome and send me home with wonderful drugs. I had no complications, and was completely filled in five office visits. Other ladies will say that these fills were painful, and they needed medication to get through the procedures. Some PSs will make you wait three months for your permanent exchange; mine will take longer because I am in a weight loss program to lose 40 pounds, so I won't have my permanent "squishies" until September. However, the surgery - for both TEs and implants - is relatively quick as long as there are no complications. Other ladies choose to reconstruct from their own tissues (LAT flap, DIEP flap, etc) so there is no "foreign body" like an implant inside them. These surgeries require PSs who have good experience in doing the procedure you want, the surgeries are longer and there are more phases, but there are also wonderful outcomes in doing it this way. Many ladies also choose no reconstruction at all and are very happy. I chose implants, because at the age of 61, I wanted my BMX scars to show that I was a warrior, but also that I have a body that needs taking care of for the next 20 - 30 years. I thought after a 50 pound weight loss, I would deserve to have perky foobs (fake boobs) even if nothing else on me was perky. If for any reason there are complications, or the implants fail, I would not hesitate to go natural. There is just no right or wrong, but there are factors that affect your choices. Will you have radiation or chemo? You may not know this until your final pathology report come in after your surgery. This can affect the timing, and the type of recon you have. Wishing you and your sister the best...

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 11:39AM Blessings2011 wrote: skylar321 -  I had a ductogram a few months ago as one of my diagnostic procedures. The only thing they did differently on me was have me take Prednisone, Benadryl, and Tagamet the morning of, because I am allergic to iodine. Like you, I thought it would be pure torture. But I was pleasantly surprised. I never even felt the needle go in, because it is very small, and goes into a hole that is already in your nipple. Are you having this done because you have a discharge from your nipple? That's why I had mine...I had bleeding in my left nipple. In order to locate exactly where to place the needle, the tech did have to express a tiny bit of blood just to find out where it was coming from. Then the Radiologist put the needle in the same place, and injected the dye. She had a lot of trouble at first, because apparently my duct was almost completely blocked. So she had to keep trying over and over, apologizing the whole time. But you know what? It didn't hurt! And I am a BIG weenie about pain. When she did get a bit of the dye in, I told her when I started to feel a change in sensation, and she stopped. Then we went over to the mammogram machine and took pictures, with the needle still in. The idea freaked me out in the beginning, but it was no different from any other mammo. Talk to your doc. Not sure if they can put you out, but perhaps they can give you something to calm your nerves, as you do need to move from the table to the mammo machine. BTW, right after we were finished with the ductogram, I walked over to the Ultrasound room and had an ultrasound core-needle biopsy. THAT one I got a shot for, that numbed the breast. The ductogram doesn't feel anything like a shot. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 12:06PM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, I understand! I was always a side sleeper until my BMX in December. I knew I'd have trouble with sleeping on my back because of several other medical issues, as well as getting in and out of our Tempurpedic bed without using my arms. So I rented a hospital bed for my recovery. I was able to raise the back up to exactly where I needed it, and the raise the knees up so my back was fully supported. I put a memory-foam topper on the hospital mattress, then a padded mattress cover, so it was VERY comfy. I used extra pillows to rest my arms on at my sides.  The best part was when I wanted to get out of bed - I would just lower the knees, and raise the back up to a 90 degree angle, then swivel my legs over the sides. Easy peasy. I had an over-the-bed table, and Dh had hooked up my reading lamp on the bookshelf to a remote, which he attached to the hospital bed remote. It made me feel very independent, yet I was able to follow my surgeons' directions to not over-exert myself. What also helped was taking my pain meds on a regular basis (Norco and Valium) and when I was able to shower after the drains came out, I would have DH massage my back muscles first. Then a nice warm shower, and sleeping was much easier. I would say that the best thing you could do would probably be to put soft pillows under your knees at night to take the pressure off your back. Did you get any muscle relaxers? Those might help. I finally WAS able to sleep on my side with my TEs. Then they got completely filled, I lost weight, and now it's hard again. But not for long! It will get better, I promise. One day you will find yourself doing things you thought you wouldn't be able to do for a long time. Wishing you good healing.....

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2014 04:48PM Blessings2011 wrote: Welcome to the forum, pjc71!  A few weeks ago, there was a news story about "an elderly couple" that  was robbed in their home. I was furious, thinking of these frail, helpless, elderly people being assaulted this way. Then I learned that the husband was 64, and the wife was 62, both able-bodied. WHAT??????  Give me a break! My concept of elderly changes with each year that goes by. My FIL is 92 and has a better social life than we do. He walks a bit slower, but crams a whole lotta living into each day. Even though we lost my 93 year old MIL a few months ago, FIL still stays very active. My mom was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 60, and so was I. That was 3 years ago, after 20 years of regular, annual mammograms. The mammos never caught it. I was very diligent, and it did me no good. As I waited for my surgery, the breast surgeon told me that by the time they are detected, most cancers have been in the body for 8 - 10 years, according to Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book. Right now you don't have bad news, you just have news. Find something you love to do, and do it. Stay busy. The waiting is the hardest. But we are here for you. And Mom? She had a unilateral mastectomy, with no radiation, no chemo, no hormonal therapy, and passed at the age of 88 from unrelated causes, with no recurrence of cancer. The closest I could find to an online support group on aging here on BCO was A Forum For Those Over 60 https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/104

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 02:00PM Blessings2011 wrote: I was a 38DD/38DDD when I was dx'd, and hated my huge, dense, painful, saggy boobs. I was initially offered a lumpectomy w/ radiation, but after a LOT of research, discussion, and prayer, decided on a BMX. Influencing my decision were many factors - my history, my mom had BC, I'm post-menopausal, a UNI on the left would mean a lift on the right, and it would be hard to match them up, and my Radiologist really felt that there was something on the right even though mammography did not show anything. My BS was up front about the lumpectomy. She said that because of my multi-focal cancer, she would have to take a wide wedge of tissue to get clear margins, and I might not be happy with the results. She was leaning towards UMX. I told her I wanted a BMX, and asked  if she would recommend that. She said that she was not recommending that, but that it was certainly an option that she would fully support. (Sounded like a CYA situation, really....) Had my BMX with TEs in December and am awaiting exchange surgery for permanent implants in late summer/early fall. My whole medical team was very supportive, and I have absolutely no regrets at all.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 06:17PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Gail - We've all been where you are. Waiting is the hardest. But the truth is, sooo many mammo call-backs are just for precautions, because the mammogram is not a very precise diagnostic tool. That's why they back it up with an ultrasound, just to be sure. Yes, there may be additional tests recommended, but you're not there yet. And - so many of these repeat procedures just verify the presence of benign growths. Look at it this way - the better image you get, the more reassured you can be. If it does turn out to be anything more than benign, then you will simply take it one step at a time. This is a fabulous site with awesome women and incredible information. We hear you, and we care!!!! Congratulations on your retirement, and praying that you get to enjoy that celebration cruise!!!  Hugs....

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 12:52PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, katiebug - Here is how I made my decision: On September 15th,I was diagnosed with multi-focal cancer in the left breast - 9 mm of DCIS, 6 mm of DCIS, and 1.5 mm and .5 mm of IDC. The tissue itself is "cribriform", as opposed to "comedo". The invasive cancer is very small, and they caught it early. The right breast was clear on screening mammography, but later showed some possible "suspicious" areas that would require additional testing. In the beginning, I had numerous options. I knew I could have lumpectomy w/ radiation, or a full-on, bilateral mastectomy w/ reconstruction. I did the research, read the forums, talked to women I knew who had gone before me. I did have that thought - oh, gee, a mastectomy would prevent me from having radiation or chemo....wrong! We won't know until after the final pathology report. I learned that several of my friends had undergone a lumpectomy, thinking that this was the least traumatic way to go...until they needed another lumpectomy, then another, then finally a mastectomy. I have other friends who had a single lumpectomy years ago, and have recovered beautifully. But the final factors for me were 1) in the grand scheme of things, how important to me are my breasts? and 2) how much worrying do I think I will do over the rest of my life (I'm 60) about what else might be going on in there? The answers, for me, were easy. I have very large, droopy, dense breasts. Self-exams are impossible, as the tissue is very fibrocystic. Mammography is at best a guessing game, and there still may be areas of cancer on the right that just haven't shown up yet. I always wanted a reduction, but never got around to it. I'm retired, and I have the time for recuperation from surgery and reconstruction. I don't have to take care of a family, and in fact, have a wonderful DH who will be taking care of me. I'll be having the BMX w/ immediate reconstruction on December 5th. A lot of emotion goes into making these decisions. Try to get at least as much factual information to back it up. Write it down, talk it up, and once you have made your decision, never feel like it was the "wrong" one. Best wishes to you!

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 01:38PM Blessings2011 wrote: SandyBeaches - There could be lots of reasons why you have a rash near your incision site, from the type of Iodine/cleanser they used during surgery, to the type of tape used, to antibiotics, to compression garments....the list goes on, and the best way to get answers is to either call or email your PS. Each doc is different in the way he or she advises their patients, so don't try to diagnose yourself. I will say, though, that itching and rashes are not all that uncommon after surgery. You just want to be sure you're not looking at any kind of infection! The area where your former boobs ended and your chest started is called the Inframammary Fold (IMF). I know my TEs were pressing down hard on this area, and I could feel the bottom ridges of the TEs at first. This is where the PS is creating the pocket for your future implants. The other thing that can happen is that nerve endings that were cut during surgery often act up and cause tingling and other unpleasant sensations. I know the area around my IMF was VERY sensitive for weeks! Hope you feel better soon!!!!
Posts.Title: Rash near incision site? SandyBeaches Cats134

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2014 10:35PM Blessings2011 wrote: pjc71 - sorry it's not a benign lump, but invasive ductal cancer (IDC) is one of the more common cancers we face. And having an estrogen/progesterone positive cancer just gives you one more tool (a daily pill) to fight it with. You will be in for a whirlwind of extra testing, either before or during surgery. Here is some really good information about understanding your diagnosis: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis We all go through that anxious stage, wondering if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes and the rest of the body. In my case, my IDC was found through biopsies, and the tumor type was defined in the preliminary pathology reports. Generally, the spread of any cancer is determined if it is found in the lymph nodes. Some women have node biopsies prior to their surgeries, others have them at the same time. Mine was done at the same time as my surgery. You already have good news in that the tumor is not attached to the chest wall. The rest you will take step by step. What they will do is send the lump that is taken out for a final pathology report, and this will give you a better idea of the next step. Seriously, knowing the plan in more detail goes a long way to dealing with the unknowns. I was diagnosed in 2011, I am healthy today. Wishing you the best... please keep us posted.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 06:22PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, floridatworeds, and welcome to the forum! I think we've all had that feeling of being overwhelmed and scared in the beginning. This is the worst part....we try to imagine the future, when we just don't have enough information. Our minds will take us down the scariest roads. Hang in there. Once you have a definite diagnosis, and a definite plan, things will get much easier. No matter what happens on June 11th, you will get through it. Find something you love to do, and do it. Stay busy. And stay away from Dr. GOOGLE. He often has the wrong information for us. I agree with longislandmom - I knew I couldn't keep repeating myself over and over with friends and family who wanted to know what was happening with me after my diagnosis. I did set up a Caring Bridge page, and I'm so glad I did! That's where we referred everyone who wanted to keep up with my progress. Wishing you the best, and make sure you come back and let us know what's happening.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 03:19PM Blessings2011 wrote: The day after I got my BC dx, my PCP sent me downstairs to get the shingles vaccine. (BTW, it was free at Kaiser.) We had no idea what my treatment was going to be, but he said that if I were getting chemo or rads, I would not be able to get the vaccine. I am very glad he did that. My mom had shingles in her scalp and they were worried about it getting into her eyes. She had a terrible reaction to Valtrex, and was hospitalized. However, she recovered from both, and never had shingles again. My aunt got shingles five years ago. She is in agony to this day from post-herpetic neuralgia. Even though the vaccine may not prevent 100% of outbreaks, I do know if I get them, it will be a light case.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2012 02:03PM Blessings2011 wrote: fmaury - I had my BMX w/TEs done in December 2011. I had dissolving sutures, Xeriform gauze over the incisions, a big soft padded dressing wrapped around me, and over that, a huge ACE bandage all the way around my chest. No post-surgical bras for me! At my one-week post-op, the PS held the grand unveiling, and I got to see my two little wrinkled foobettes. He prounounced everything healing well, then wrapped me back up, with a bit less padding, and a little looser. At the two-week appt, the drains came out and the bandages came off. At that point, all I had to do was keep the incisions clean, which I did religiously. I used each towel only once after I got out of the shower. I wore each garment only once, then it went in the laundry. And no one touched my incisions, even me. Hope you get those pesky drains out Monday - you will feel so much better!

How to post pics 1)      Go to the website 2)      Find the pic, and right click on it 3)      Go down to the last line:  “Properties” and click on that 4)      This will show you the Address (URL) of the pic. Highlight, and copy this address 5)      Go to the “Reply” box in the BCO thread 6)      Click on the little icon of a tree in the gray panel at the top of your reply box. (“Insert/Edit Image”) You’ll get a little pop-up box. 7)      Put your cursor in the space for “Image URL” and paste in the address you just copied 8)      NOW – THIS IS THE IMPORTANT PART:  in that same pop-up box, go down to the line for “Dimensions” 9)      Place your cursor in the first empty box and just click. This should automatically bring up the dimensions of the picture you’re trying to post. If you skip this step the picture will not show up. 10)   Click on “Insert” and you’re done! (Always “Preview” to be sure.)

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 08:36PM Blessings2011 wrote: skapaya - STEP AWAY FROM THE COMPUTER!  Seriously, while I was being diagnosed, I put myself on a Google diet - no more than 30 minutes a day for me. Here is just my opinion: a doctor would order a core-needle biopsy over a fine needle biopsy just because he/she can get more information from the core needle. The fine needle is great for withdrawing fluid from cysts, or getting smears of breast tissue for slides. But the core needle is able to get a much wider range of tissue to be examined. I don't think one necessarily spells BREAST CANCER more than the other. I had numerous tests and biopsies, and I've had two Ultrasound-Assisted Core Needle Biopsies. Here is my experience. Mine were done in the ultrasound room. My breast was exposed, and the tech put the gel on it so the radiologist could use the wand to see the tumor/suspicious area. Once the tumor was located, then the Radiologist gave me a numbing shot in the breast, which sounds way worse than it is. The shot stings for a very brief moment, then the tissue goes numb. When she was sure that I couldn't feel anything, she had the tech isolate the exact area of the tumor, and she inserted the instrument that has the core-needle on it. She put the tip of the needle into the mass, and counted to three. She explained that I would hear a snapping sound as the instrument took a tiny bit of tissue, but should feel nothing. She was right. She did this several times to get several samples, and even though I could feel pressure as she moved the instrument around, I didn't feel any pain at all. I could have looked at the ultrasound screen if I wanted to, or watched the needle go into my breast, but I chose not to. I figured if I couldn't see it, it wouldn't hurt. I was right. In fact, we were talking the whole time, and I remember laughing at quite a few things that were said. I was very comfortable. Afterwards, I got a bandaid, and an ice pack to stuff inside my bra for the ride home. I kept icing the area for the rest of the night, and except for a bit of bruising, had no after effects. If you ask for some anti-anxiety meds beforehand, you might get them, but you in that case you may want a ride home. Seriously, if you don't want to watch, just close your eyes and do some deep breathing. It will be over before you know it! Wishing you the best....

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2014 04:29PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, MarieBernice - so sorry you are dealing with this, but I have to agree with the other posters about using ice, especially on areas where nerves have been cut and compromised. There is a HUGE possibility of frostbite in those areas - especially if any fatty layers of tissue under the skin have been removed. I once got a sunburn through my clothes that turned my TEs a bright red. The PS said absolutely NO ice, but a cool, moist compress would be o.k. The same would apply, I think, to heat. Nothing HOT, but something gently warm to the touch on a normal part of the body. Sometimes it's just a matter of tricking the brain... often it has a hard time discerning two different sensations at once, and if it senses warmth, then that's what you might perceive instead of pain. Always check with your PS first. Hope this resolves quickly for you!

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2012 01:39PM Blessings2011 wrote: Kimbr7 - So sorry you are going through this right now, especially during the holidays. If for any reason something else is found, you will have time to deal with it then. There are some wonderful women on this forum, and we are here for you. Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 11:16AM Blessings2011 wrote: Soyaandpepper - SOOO sorry you are going through this! My dentist is very proactive with the antibiotics - when I had my extraction over a year ago (in preparation for a dental implant), I had to start taking the antibiotics well before the procedure. However, this was all before my BC dx. Now I have in TEs, and even though I need some dental work done, I am going to wait til after my exchange. One thing you might ask the dentist is whether or not he uses PRP in his practice. This is platelet-rich plasma, which is made from a small sample of your own blood. It is spun in a special centrifuge, then inserted into the wound, allowing healing to take place at an accelerated rate. I didn't have this for my extraction (in fact, due to a bone malformation, I did get an abcess) but I got it with my implant surgery and within 24 hours, the tissue and bone were healing. Sorry, I know this didn't answer your question.... Wishing you the best!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 01:01PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, proudmomof3 - Last September I had spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple. The Breast Surgeon suspected a papilloma, but sent me for more tests, just to be on the safe side. The first thing she told me was to stop squeezing the nipple, as it may make it difficult for the Radiologist to express any discharge when needed to identify the duct. Within two weeks, I'd had seven more diagnostic procedures: screening mammogram, diagnostic mammogram, two ultrasounds, ductogram, two ultrasound-guided core-needle biopsies, and finally a screening mammo on the right. The ductogram was incomplete, as the duct was almost completely blocked and they couldn't get the contrast material in. The core-needle biopsies showed that I had mostly non-invasive cancer, with a micro-invasion of invasive cancer. I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction last year. I had no chemo, and no radiation. But that's just me. You have to keep in mind that the MAJORITY of breast lumps and conditions are benign. I think it's a good idea to go to a breast surgeon, only to make sure that all possible tests have been done, and that you can get a clear diagnosis of a benign problem. If it IS a papilloma, it will have to be removed, only because they will continue to grow and cause problems. But this is not breast cancer. I think you are doing exactly what you need to be doing, if only to give yourself peace of mind. If anything changes, and you do find out there is something there, then you've already come to the best place ever for information and support. In the meantime, try to take a deeep breath and relax. Let the test results come in, and see what the surgeon says. Wishing you the best!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 04:43PM Blessings2011 wrote: Renergy - When it comes to pain, I'm a big weenie, too.  I had my ductogram right before I had my ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy. I wondered why I got a numbing agent for the biopsy, but not for the ductogram. Well, the reason was that I didn't need it for the ductogram! Once the spot of blood identified the exact duct that needed to be examined, the Radiologist was very good about inserting the cannula (a REALLY tiny tube) into the duct. Because there was quite a bit of blockage, she had to try multiple times to get the tube in all the way, apologizing the whole time. I kept telling her it was o.k., because it didn't hurt. When she finally got the cannula in far enough to start inserting the contrast medium, I had a weird feeling for a few seconds, and then shortly I told her the feeling changed to a distinct fullness. She said that was her cue to stop inserting the dye. At that point, they walked me over to the mammography machine, and with the tube still taped in place, took several mammograms. Even that didn't hurt, considering how bizarre it must have looked. I think you will find that the anticipation is WAY worse than the reality!

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2013 09:37PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, paloverde - the general consensus has been that you need around 100 grams of protein a day for your body to heal. If you're not feeling like eating much, protein shakes are good. I'd stay away from the carbs and sugars unless they are fresh fruit. Staying well-hydrated is also really important for several reasons: it helps get rid of the anesthesia in your body, and if you are taking any narcotic pain meds, you'll probably get a stool softener to take as well. Do yourself a favor and take it whether you think you need it to not - you do not want to tak Milk of Magnesia - trust me on this. Wishing you well on your upcoming BMX and recon!

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 11:45AM Blessings2011 wrote: chawkins - what an insensitive jerk to have treated you that way....was he the radiologist? Grrrrrrr....  My reasons for BMX are similar to SheChirple's. I was dx with multifocal cancer in my left breast on September 15th. I had two areas of DCIS, and one area of IDC. The breast surgeon said she could do a lumpectomy, but that she'd have to take such a large wedge of tissue, I probably wouldn't be pleased. I also had very large, dense, droopy breasts - 38DD (more than likely DDD). I considered a UMX, and knew right away that no amount of reconstruction on the right would make it match up to an implant on the left. My mom was a breast cancer survivor - radical MX, no recon - so I knew I had multiple risk factors, and the thought of mastectomy was not foreign to me. Add that in with some "suspicious" areas on the right, and a wonderful radiologist who did her best to discover every tiny bit of cancer, and the decision was easy. On December 5th, I had a BMX with immediate recon (TEs). The DCIS was three times bigger in the left breast than had been seen on imaging (but that's pretty normal) and there was NO evidence of the IDC. There was also no evidence of cancer in the right breast. SNB was normal, and final path report showed clear margins everywhere and 0/3 nodes normal. I won't need chemo, I won't need radiation, and after I see the Oncologist on Friday, I will probably be on Arimidex for five years. I am so glad I made this decision. No more waiting and wondering from mammo to mammo - will this be the year they find something? It was always in the back of my mind. You don't need to suffer with this, chawkins. Depression really is a slippery slope. As a retired counselor myself, I am a huge advocate of therapy along with medication. Sometimes ya just gotta get it out of your head, and with someone who won't judge you, coerce you, or tell you you're wrong to feel what you feel. It's wonderful to not have to carry that burden around by yourself. First, see if any of your docs have a referral to either a medical social worker who specializes in cancer patients, or any other therapist who works with chronic diseases. There are many qualified professionals who counsel - Social Workers (LCSW, MSW); Counselors (MFT), Psychologists (PhD); and Psychiatrists (MD). In my experience, though, most psychiatrists do not do a whole lot of talk therapy. They are, however, the ones who can prescribe medications. You can also call your local hospitals and see if there are any breast cancer support groups. This is often a good way to get involved in a network of caring professionals who can help you along this journey. You are young, chawkins. You don't have to feel this bad. I am praying that you will find some relief from all this stress, and find the exact answers you seek for your future treatment. Big hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Still unsure a little chawkins tgisiner

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 12:36AM Blessings2011 wrote: Ariom - I absolutely agree with you... some of the things I read on BCO left me stunned and anxious and afraid and positive I was going to have the worst experience of my life, during the most vulnerable period of my life. Thank God that part is over. ~ ~ ~  That said, I eventually learned that BCO was a place where women came to share their experiences.... the good, the bad, and the ugly. What was difficult to read, though, was the post that insisted to everyone - including impressionable newbies - that "this procedure" or "that procedure" is definitely torture, barbaric, etc.... NOT simply "Here is what I felt when I had this done." I also eventually learned that there can be no comparisons when it comes to BC. My experience is not your experience.  We may have exactly the same dx, procedures, treatments, surgeries.... and each of our experiences will differ. None of us is right or wrong. But I think it's important for those starting out to realize that no one can predict what you are going to feel. Seriously - NO ONE. It's like the Aromatase Inhibitor threads... most of the stories you read are horror stories - mine included! Yet there are hundreds of thousands of women taking these drugs with extremely minor or no side effects. I always make it a point to include that when I post about my incredibly bad experiences.  I would never minimize the pain that a woman experiences when getting that radioactive isotope injection in the breast. If you say it was the worst pain you ever experienced, I believe you! (And I'm so sorry.... ) By the same token, I would hope that those who had a different experience  are not made to feel like they are denying another's pain, or even suggesting that another person is exaggerating.  There's room for all opinions, experiences, and realities here.

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 06:43PM Blessings2011 wrote: sunflowergirl - no worries...your question isn't rude at all. I had a BMX for many reasons. 1.  My cancer was small and detected early. It was multifocal, meaning that it was in two places in my left breast. The BS offered me a lumpectomy with radiation, but warned me that because of the two different locations, she'd have to take such a big wedge of tissue I might not be satisfied with the outcome. She said I may want to  consider a UMX. (Unilateral mastectomy) 2.  The "original girls" were big (38DDD) heavy, droopy, painful, and fibrocystic. I always wanted a reduction but couldn't afford one. I thought about the UMX on the left and how that would mean a reduction on the right...and how that would be a major surgery, and how difficult it would be to match them up. 3.  My mom had breast cancer, diagnosed at the same age I was. She had a radical mastectomy on the left, and no further treatment. I'd always suspected I'd get it some day, with all the risk factors I thought I had, and I realized that I didn't want to play the waiting game with my remaining right breast. I decided to have the BMX with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders), and my medical team was very supportive. I had my surgery on December 5th, my SNB was negative, and all my margins were clear. That meant no chemo, no radiation. It did mean that my MO wants to prescribe Arimidex for five years due to my ER+ status. My BC diagnosis was a wake-up call for me. I have absolutely no regrets over the choice to have the BMX, and am looking forward to perky foobs. (Heck, I could have perky foobs when I'm 80!!!)   I delayed reconstruction until I could lose weight. This did two things - made sure I would get the correct sized implants, and reduced my risk of BC recurrence by another 23%. I've lost 45 pounds with 15 to go. I work out at the gym, do water aerobics, ride my bike, and walk. I haven't felt this good in over 20 years. Wishing you the best at your MO appointment!!!
Posts.Title: Any other newbies? cpp christina0001

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 09:19PM Blessings2011 wrote: I definitely wanted to be tucked away! I set up the sitting area of our master bedroom with a fully electric hospital bed. I had a bedside table with a giant bell to summons DH, all the snacks and drinks I needed (the toddler size sippy cups were a boon at first),  a huge bookcase of books and magazines, and my reading lamp on a remote control. The TV could swivel so I could see it fine, but wasn't really interested. We set aside a portion of the master bathroom as a drain station so all the suppies were at the ready. That way no guests would see all the supplies laid out. Finally, DH set up our baby monitor (that we used for the grandkids) on my bookcase so he could tell if I needed him. This was especially helpful during those first days of showers, when I could be in the shower alone, but needed his help with drying off. I wasn't very social and really didn't want any company. My little nest suited me just fine. The reality was that I didn't need it very long, and soon my DH was telling me he was surprised at how independent I was!
