Then I pull them down to cover my toes, and my shoulders get cold! You are very welcome, Brandi. CoolBreeze - Oh, they're definitely washable (100% cotton only) and washing them only makes them softer and cuddlier.  You like to put yours over the top of you, so your shoulders and the tops of your legs are covered. Got it. Some of our quilts are rectangles, some are squares. I think I'd want one that was just big enough to not fall off or slip down, yet still be big enough to tuck in around me if I got colder. Kayfh - Wow...having someone just show up at my door because a store gave them my name and address would creep me out too! So glad you were able to educate the owner. And you ended up with a beautiful quilt! Yay! Thanks for your kind words... Lumpynme - I think 40 x 50 is pretty standard, but usually the design is up to the individual quilter. She can use blocks of whatever size, and add pretty sashing and borders to make the quilt a little bigger, so usually they're all a little different. I can understand about not wanting your PICC line buried under layers of blankets.  I wanted to ask questions because I didn't share the same experience you all do. Thank you so much for answering. ~~~~~ I received two gorgeous lap quilts when I had my surgery. One was made by a church friend, and had blocks that were signed by all my Bible Study sisters and our Senior Lunch Bunch. The other one was made by the ladies in my quilting class, and each one had made a heart block out of different fabrics, and signed it. In the beginning, each quilt graced my bed on different days. Now one is folded and hung over the back of a chair, and the other is folded and hung over the back of the loveseat in the bedroom. They are loving reminders that others cared. As for the quilts we donate, I always make sure I give them to a person (Breast Care Coordinator, Oncology Social Worker, etc.) who knows the patient they will go to. I give them free reign over how they are distributed. (For example, a tiny woman in a wheelchair may want a smaller lap blanket that won't get tangled in her wheels, so she can use it all the time.) One of our latest projects is making quilts for veterans who are being discharged from the local VA hospital to go home on hospice care. They will be getting quilts with a patriotic theme. I'm working with the Palliative Care nurse on that one. Ladies, thank you so much for your input! You are all in my prayers. Any more thoughts or suggestions? I'm passing them all on to our groups!
Posts.Title: Need Your Advice On Comfort Quilts For Chemo Patients! Blessings2011 christina0001

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 12:59AM Blessings2011 wrote: I took the news fairly well when I was dx'd. I hung up the phone, went into the bedroom, and cried. DH came in and I told him. He held me while I cried, and told me that no matter what happened, we'd face it together - that we were a team. The next day I sucked it up and started doing research on what was to come. I was really sad that I couldn't call my mom just to hear her voice. She was dx'd with BC when she was the same age I was - 61. She had a radical mastectomy, with no reconstruction. I quit a job to come home and take care of her. She had no other treatment, and passed when she was 87, with no recurrence of cancer. But I did feel her spirit guiding me all along. Because of my strong faith, we asked for prayer, which meant telling lots of people. My family handled it o.k, but some friends just burst into tears at the news. I did find myself in the role of comforter, which - as sbelizabeth put it - wasn't fair. I finally had to let those folks go and find their own comfort. I told several friends in personal emails. That way I wouldn't have to keep repeating myself on the phone. One of my close friends was very concerned, wanted to come down and see me the following weekend. That was last September. I've never heard from her since then. I don't have the energy to listen to excuses, so I haven't called her. Like MiniMacsMom I set up a CaringBridge account - with a password. Once I put the word out on Facebook, I let friends know the password, and I was amazed at all the beautiful responses I got on my "Guest Book." Maria - can you talk to your parents? Can you ask them if they want to help you? (I can't imagine them saying no....) Then say "I need you to be positive for me. That's all. Just love me and be hopeful and positive." Big hugs to you....
Posts.Title: Telling people you have BC MarS676 gardengumby

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2013 10:15PM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, Ladies! When I was just 18 years old, I had a benign fibroadenoma the size of a walnut surgically removed. As I got older, I realized that I had heavy, dense, fibrocystic breasts. Once I hit menopause, my 38DDD girls hung nearly to my waist, and felt like bags of rocks and marbles. Self-exams were useless, so I relied heavily on mammograms. When my mom was dx'd with breast cancer at the age of 60, I knew my risk might be higher. I begged my PCP to PLEASE let me have an ultrasound or MRI in addition to my yearly mammograms. He refused, saying "Those are not screening tools." So every year, I would get a cheerful little postcard announcing "Congratulations! Your recent mammogram shows no evidence of breast cancer!!!" Except that 8 months after my last mammogram, in September 2011, I began to bleed spontaneously from my left nipple. THAT got the doc's attention! (I was 60 years old.) Two days later, I was sitting in the breast surgeons's office. She initially thought it was a benign papilloma, but ordered additional diagnostic tests just to be sure. After seven more procedures, they found DCIS, with two microinvasions of IDC (invasive ductal cancer). Nothing had shown up on the mammogram. Long story short - in December 2011 I had a BMX with immediate recon. I did not need chemo or radiation, and in August 2012 I got my saline implants. The point of this is not to scare anyone, but to make sure you are assertive with your doctor if you feel that just annual mammograms are not enough to give you peace of mind. And if your primary care doc, or your OB/GYN just don't get it, then go see a breast specialist.
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Support Thread fenella springmac

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 05:30PM Blessings2011 wrote: SelenaWolf - excellent post! Hi, sunflowergirl99, and welcome to the forum! I'm so sorry you are going through all of this right now, and it's so hard to come to terms with anything until you have ALL the information in front of you, and can formulate a treatment plan. From your signature line, it looks like you have a smaller invasive ductal cancer, clear lymph nodes, and are Her2 negative. In the grand scheme of things, those are all relatively good things. ER+ means that there are additional drugs to treat you that other women may not benefit from. Most all women who have lumpectomies for IDC will also have radiation. If the posts you read here make you anxious, please remember that there are many women who do NOT have major complications, but they are not posting on threads dealing with problems. Do you know if you had the Oncotype test done? That usually gives good information as to how much chemo can benefit your type of cancer. I'm so sorry you lost a friend to cancer. Cancer does just suck. I think all of us go through the "death sentence" thoughts at one time or another. But that just isn't the case. We all deal with the reality of the possibility of a recurrence, but we get as much information as we can, go through the treatments we believe are best for us, then make the transition from cancer patient to living out the rest of our lives. If the cancer does come back, we deal with it then, but right now, it will probably be easier for you to take one day at a time. Yeah, people want to be helpful and tell you not to worry. Most of them don't know what else to say. Here is one suggestion I have: stay away from Dr. Google! In many cases, he is a liar and a fearmonger. And in the beginning, when we don't know what to expect, our minds can take us to scary places. I was dx'd with DCIS and IDC last September, and had a bilateral mastectomy (BMX) with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders) in December. I'm awaiting a date for my exchange surgery. FOR ALL NEWBIES: I think joining this forum right after you've been diagnosed is the smartest thing anyone can do. In fact, this is the only website my MO will let me visit!!! But here's how I see it: there are thousands of women here, many of whom have been posting for years, and seem to have developed strong friendships. I think that's awesome, but for the newly-diagnosed, it may feel weird to just butt into a thread as a stranger. Butt away!!! You won't be a stranger for long. No matter what you are going through, someone here has experienced it. It's like being a brand new driver. You're comfortable on your own street, where you know the neighborhood and the lay of the land, and now you have to merge on the freeway? In rush hour? Are you crazy? Joining this forum can be like merging on the freeway. But come on in.....we'll make space for you, and drive with you down this strange and frightening road. We'll help you navigate the sudden turns. If your car breaks down, we'll be here to assist you. If you need a ride, you can jump in our cars. We'll get you where you need to go. Soon, you will loosen your grip on the steering wheel and be able to take a deep breath and look around. Some of the scenery along the way is beautiful.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 09:12PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Klm0221, and welcome to the forum! In September, 2011, I had some spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple. I was referred to a breast surgeon, who immediately suspected a papilloma, and told me it would have to be surgically removed, because it would continue to cause bleeding in the future, and would only get worse, not better. In the meantime, she referred me for extensive diagnostic testing to rule out anything else. My Radiologist was awesome. She had the tenacity of a pit bull. After 7 different diagnostic procedures (two screening mammograms, two diagnostic mammograms, a ductogram, and two core-needle biopsies) it was determined that I did not have a papilloma at all, but rather two areas of DCIS (non-invasive cancer) and two very tiny areas of IDC (invasive ductal cancer). Because of my history, I chose to have a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. When the breast tissue was biopsied the day after my surgery, there was no invasive cancer to be found! When I asked why, they said that sometimes the core needle gets it all. I was fortunate. The cancer was very tiny, caught very early, and I did not need chemo or radiation. It's been a year now, and I am finished with reconstruction. I am very pleased with the way the New Girls turned out. What I hear you saying is that you have had a biopsy, and a papilloma was confirmed. Now your surgeon wants to go back in and excise the duct to make sure the margins were clear. That makes perfect sense to me. When the contents of the core needle biopsy are examined, they know what they got, but not what was left behind. There's no real reason to suspect the worst here. The reality is that MOST breast lumps are benign! I would imagine that having this surgery would give you the peace of mind you need, knowing for certain that it was nothing more worrisome than a papilloma. It has been my experience (both personally and reading posts here on BCO) that most breast surgeons are usually VERY proactive in ruling out cancer... not because they suspect it and are not telling you, but because you deserve the most diligent care you can receive. Wishing you the best!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2013 05:55PM Blessings2011 wrote: I'd been here on BCO for two months before my BMX, and to tell you the truth, the horror stories about the radioactive injection pain scared the pee out of me. It was the one thing I feared the most. The day of my surgery, I was taken down to the room where I would get the shots. The Radiologist kept apologizing profusely, telling me how sorry he was that the shots were so painful, but necessary. The Tech was glued to my side, clenching my hand as if I were about to give birth. I got no numbing cream at all, and while the shots (4? 5?) did sting, they were nothing compared to the huge cortisone shot I had recently gotten in the bottom of my heel that left me weeping and screaming for the doctor to stop. So with that as my "10" on the pain scale, those shots in the breast didn't even come close. This is not to minimize anyone's experience at all... we are all different in how we react to pain. (I think my foot doctor - who I love - said I was the worst patient he ever had...) But I think it's important for newbies to know that while some women do have a horrific experience, others do not, and those women generally don't post about it.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2014 12:25AM Blessings2011 wrote: The day of my BMX, I checked in at 8 a.m. for my 1 p.m. surgery. I walked down to Radiology at 9 a.m. to get my Radioactive Isotope Injections. As I got up to leave, the Tech told me to keep massaging the breast to help the material spread throughout the lymph nodes. From there I walked back up to Pre-Op, for the never-ending parade of medical personnel lined up, either  wanting something from me (information, vitals, etc) or wanting to give me something (gown, IV, etc.) Seriously, there was actually a LINE of people waiting to get to me. I felt so popular! Then I remembered the Tech's advice. I started massaging my left breast like there was no tomorrow.  I don't know how long it took, but I suddenly realized that my Pre-Op cubicle was at the very end of the room, and my curtains were open. The ENTIRE ROOM - staff and patients -  could see me squeezing my left boob!!! I can only hope they thought it was some sort of self-calming technique.....  At least my girlfriend and I got a good laugh out of it... (she and DH took turns entertaining me until it was time for the OR.) ~ ~ ~  (No scans for me, either. Just the shot in the morning, and surgery in the afternoon.)

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 07:01PM Blessings2011 wrote: I had a BMX w/ TEs on December 5th. I cried every single day for three weeks after I got home, because the pain was so bad. I never got my pain under control in the hospital because I didn't want to use the morphine PCA that was at my bedside. That just made it harder to control when I got home. I wanted to be one of those women who just took a few tylenol after surgery and then ran a marathon, but unfortunately, that wasn't me. At the urging of all the wise women on this forum, I finally started taking the pain meds that were sent home with me. (What a novel idea!!!! ) I took them around the clock as prescribed. Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 10:32PM Blessings2011 wrote: I think there is something to the theory of those more toned having more pain with fills.  My PS told me that being overweight and out of shape actually could have made my fills easier. Gee...first time THAT was ever a bonus!!! I had tons of extra skin (and it would get looser after every fill) and my pecs were just, well, mush. I never worked out. I was a total couch potato. So after 180ccs of saline in the OR, I quickly got to 620ccs in five visits. I never had any of the pain or muscle spasms that many ladies experience. You just couldn't see the TEs very well, as they blended into my fat gut. Now, though, I have a different problem. I've lost a considerable amount of weight (and blubber, or, um, padding) and now my TEs seem huge and rock hard. I've also been working out frequently, trying to make up for lost time until I have my exchange next month. I know the PS will be doing a lot of pocket work when he gets in there, and I'm hoping to get back to exercising quickly after exchange. Oh, yeah....my other brilliant thought: never, EVER compare yourself to anyone else here! We all heal and recuperate at different rates. I had this ridiculous "Today I'll turn the corner on pain!" mantra in my head, and when it didn't happen right away, I was SO down! So don't do that, ladies. Love your bodies and give them time to heal properly!!!

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 03:58PM Blessings2011 wrote: You'll undress completely down to your waist, and put on a hospital gown. You won't be allowed to wear any deodorant, lotion, or powder under your arms. If you do, then you'll be asked to go wash it off in the restroom. The mammogram room itself is private, you'll put your stuff on a chair (unless your facility has lockers) and you'll walk up to the machine. The tech will take off one side of your gown at a time. I think the weirdest part for me was having such huge breasts, and watching the tech trying to place them and turn them just right on the plates for the best views. Your arm may be raised and you'll be holding on to a bar or another part of the machine. Once your breast has been placed properly, flat on the bottom plate, then the top plate will be gradually moved down until it touches your breast. At this point, it's best to take a big breath and relax, because the tech will gradually tighten up the space between the plates, mashing your boob flat. It may hurt, but only for a moment. Keep in mind that the flatter they can make the tissue, the better images they can get. You'll stand very still, (can't remember if I had to hold my breath or not) and the tech will take the picture. As soon as it's taken, the pressure on your boob will be released. Then they'll do the other views, in which the plates are turned, and your boob will be placed between the plates on either side, and pressed vertically for a picture. Then they'll cover you up on that side, and remove the gown from your other shoulder, and repeat the procedure. It really is quick, and then they'll ask you to wait a few minutes while they show the images to the radiologist. If there is something that is not clear, you may be asked to repeat some views. Then when you are done, you get dressed and go home. If you're going back to work, or going shopping, I suggest you bring along some deodorant!!! ~~~~~~~~~~~ As far as the ultrasound goes, again, you will undress to the waist and wear a hospital gown. The US room is darkened, and you will lie on a padded table (ask for a pillow for under your knees if that's more comfortable.) with a pillow under your head. Depending on what your doc is looking for, you may be asked to roll slightly on your side, with your arm raised. The tech will be sitting at the machine, which is right next to you. You can watch the screen if you want. She will start by squirting some warm gel onto your breast, and then using a wand, move it over your breast to find the areas they want to look at. She may move the wand back and forth many times, and may press hard to get at exactly the right spot. She will hold the wand there, and key in instructions on the machine to take the picture and describe the location. Again, this doesn't take long, and afterwards, you'll be given a towel to wipe off the gel, and you can go get dressed and leave. The tech is not allowed to make any diagnosis; that all has to be run  through the Radiologist.
Posts.Title: My first mammogram RaptorSqueaks omg333

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 01:59PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, CynthiaMac - so sorry you've been diagnosed, but very glad you found this forum. The bad news is that tumors do not always show up on mammograms, and according to Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, by the time most tumors can be seen on mammography, they have been in the body for 8 - 10 years. Now for the good news: It sounds like whatever is going on really could be in the early stages. Usually, PCP (primary care physicians) are quick to hand over breast cancer cases to breast surgeons, and rightly so. You should have gotten a written record of your biopsy report. Maybe it's too early for a printed copy, but someone should go over what details they have. Always ask for printed reports on any procedures you have. I would imagine that the BS (breast surgeon) will spend some time with you, telling you what information has been gained so far, such as what type of cancer, location, size, grade, stage, and any other information that has come back after testing such as estrogen and progesterone status, and Her2Neu receptor status. He or she will also talk to you about your options, and your best recommendations for the type of surgery that will be best for you. Sometimes they just can't get all the information from a biopsy, and have to wait until after surgery for the final pathology report. It's kind of like waiting for the other shoe to drop. Look at it this way - defining a breast cancer diagnosis is kind of like handing a 1,000 piece jigsaw puzzle to the surgeon, only with 500 pieces missing, and saying "Now, put this picture together." They really do need most of the pieces of the puzzle to adequately create a diagnosis and treatment plan for you. So the wait time can be agonizing. Don't let it get to you. Find something you love to do, keep busy, and take things one day at a time. Soon you will have more information, and soon you will be more confident that you are making good decisions and are in the right hands. Wishing you the best...please keep us posted!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2012 03:26AM Blessings2011 wrote: Crystal5 - A year ago, I was 60, retired, and tired. I'd been a university counselor for more than 25 years, and loved my job, but my health issues (including increasing blood sugar levels) had started getting in the way. (BTW - my favorite job was being the Reentry Counselor - for older students returning to college to complete their degrees. It is an amazing spark of energy to recall the feeling of being, well, SMART and CAPABLE - things that vanish quickly as we grow older and life gets in the way. Congratulations on your accomplishment!) So there I was, feeling as if I was going through the motions....taking numerous prescription medications, feeling guilty that I didn't have the energy to make the kind of life I wanted to have in the second half of my life. I always had all the necessary lab work, took all the meds, had regular mammograms. But I was overweight, and nearly disabled with fibromyalgia. All my mammos were normal, but one morning I had spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple. Seven diagnostic procedures later, they found invasive ductal cancer. I was dx'd with BC just short of my 61st birthday. I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders) in December 2011. It was a small cancer and caught early. I could have had a lesser surgery, but knew in my heart I had made the right decision. The final pathology report showed that there was no lymph node involvement and no cancer other than what they had initially detected, and thus I did not need chemo or radiation. I recovered well from the mastectomy and expansion, but in the process, I learned that my cancer was estrogen-positive. I argued with the oncologist that I would NOT need the estrogen blocking medication because I was post menopausal and had already had a hysterectomy. She kindly pointed out that estrogen is manufactured in body fat, of which I had plenty. At that point, I made the decision to enter a medically-supervised weight loss program. It was basically a four month liquid fast, with a two month back-to-food transition period. Along with the diet, we had to exercise. Being a committed couch potato, I would much rather lie on the couch, eat chips, and watch mindless TV. I hated exercise. But I went into the program with the mindset that THIS was my medical treatment. And because of that, it worked. I started out walking - limping, actually, around the block at first, then progressed to power walking. I have a neurological condition that affects my balance, and had a bad fall off my mountain bike years ago. I never got back on. So DH bought me an adult trike, and off I went! Finally, I joined a water aerobics class at the local rehabilitation hospital, where the water is kept at 94 degrees. It all worked. I lost 56 pounds and more than 64 inches. Better yet, I went off ALL my prescription medication, except for thyroid. And the best part of all, was for the first time in my life, I felt strong and healthy. Even the fibro pain was gone, thanks to the fact that my diet was gluten-free. Last month, I had my exchange surgery. I have two new gorgeous noobs (new boobs) which make me happy. My risk of recurrence is very small. My life has changed in so many GOOD ways....none of which would have happened without the BC diagnosis. So here is my point: while this is the scariest thing you've gone through, and the waiting sucks, the reality is that the majority of women with abnormal mammos usually turn out to have benign results in the end. And if it does turn out to be breast cancer, you are in a wonderful place to find support and resources. No matter what the outcome, you will get through it day by day. (Hope this wasn't too much sunshine and roses...yes, there were weeds along the way, but today I'm focusing on the garden.) Wishing you the best!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 12:31PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, ro-berta, and welcome to the forum! Getting a BC diagnosis is like getting the wind kicked out of you, getting run over by a steamroller, being sucker punched, and any other devastating thing that could happen. Everyone processes information differently. For me, I'm a "knowledge is power" kinda gal. Even though my background was in medical counseling, I learned almost everything I now know about breast cancer from the awesome women on this forum. Rozem and Denielle are right - all your treatments will be based on your individual diagnosis....and you may be asked to make some decisions that you don't feel equipped to answer if you don't have all the complete information. We all know what it's like to be in that hellish waiting period before we have an actual plan. But here's the problem with not wanting to know the details: our minds will most often take us down that scary, worst-case-scenario path. We will often imagine the worst, whether we want to or not. Sometimes knowing more information - including the GOOD news about how your BC will be treated - can help us stay strong and motivated. Your computer skills are just fine, ro-berta! Here, there are never any dumb questions, and no matter what you are feeling, there are plenty of women who have felt the same way. Even though I always suspected a BC diagnosis would be in my future (Mom had it) I remember the day I got the call confirming it. I kept thinking "24 hours ago, I was a healthy person. Now I have cancer." Just remember we are always here for you. Wishing you the best!!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2014 12:42AM Blessings2011 wrote: ThinkingPositive - your surgery was so recent... everything you have mentioned sounds pretty normal to me. Immediately after my BMX, I looked so swollen EVERYWHERE I looked like a Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade balloon. Everything was swollen, tight, and uncomfortable.  HOWEVER - You are doing all the right things by monitoring your temperature and taking your antibiotics. Now is the worst time for infection to set it, and if you have any questions about that, be sure to call your Breast Surgeon. Don't be shy... they get calls like that all the time. Better to be safe than sorry. Many of us found that the more we moved around, the longer it took for the fluid in the drains to go from red to that pinkish/straw color. The docs want you to be up and around to prevent blood clots, but not so active that your tissues are putting out more fluid. I never touched my dressings. Only the docs did at the Post-Op appointment.  Re the Sentinel Node Biopsy and Final Path report... The way my surgery was done, the SNB tissue was sent down to Pathology while I was on the table. The Pathologist took a slice of each node, and reported back to the surgeon that all was clear. Had the Pathologist seen any cancer in the Sentinel Nodes, he would have reported that back to the Breast Surgeon, and she would have removed more nodes during my BMX. However, that was just a small slice that was examined during surgery. The following day, every single bit of lymph node and breast tissue was examined extensively. Those were the tests that took a while to run, type up into a Final Pathology report, and sent back to the Breast Surgeon. I had my results within a few days.... I think.... and certainly before my one-week Post Op appointment. Did you see your Plastic Surgeon today? What did he/she say? Wishing you good healing!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 06:21AM Blessings2011 wrote: I'm one month out from my BMX/recon. I think I cried every day for a week after I got home because I couldn't get my pain under control. (And oh yeah, the armpits were awful!) I had my drains out at two weeks, and finally was able to shower. That was an amazing leap towards feeling better, as the hot water was relaxing my back muscles, and easing the pain of the TEs. I played around with different drug combinations, and found some that worked for me. Last week, I was sitting there thinking "What shall we have for dinner?" and I realized that I hadn't taken any pain meds all day long! After my fills last week, I was told I could drive. I did - a very short distance - and realized I felt GOOD for the first time since my surgery! Today I'm having some discomfort, and there are days when I do too much and need a nice long nap. I had to get over feeling like a failure because I wasn't healing as fast as some of the other ladies here were reporting. It had to hit home that each person is so individual in the way they recover. Sometimes, there are complications that interfere with that process - and those are the times you really need to communicate with your doctor about what might be going on. Other than that, it's the old "Give it time." I wanted to scream when I read other people say that, but it turned out to be true. The only difference was the amount of time it took for each individual. You'll get there!

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2011 03:01PM Blessings2011 wrote: When I was younger and single, I felt "feminine" because I looked like society told me to. I felt cute and sassy and had rather fetching boobs and cleavage that I worked to my advantage.But eventually, that got very tiring, and very unsatisfying. I didn't marry until six years ago, at the age of 55. By then, "looking good" had more to do with feeling good in elastic waistbands and flat shoes than it did with a hoochie mama top. And soon "the girls" were swelling out of their 38DD confinement and pointing due south, ending up just north of my waist. Somewhere around that time, I had a monumental change in how I perceived "feminine" and "womanly".  After hitting menopause, I realized that among my friends, body image was fleeting, and finally we were putting more emphasis on things like character, personality, intelligence, caring, and humor. It also helped that I'd had a mom who'd undergone a radical mastectomy (with no recon) when I was just a young woman. It never changed who my mom was, except that I would always see her as a warrior. After my cancer diagnosis, my DH and I discussed my options. I asked him how much he liked my breasts. He said "They're really nice, but I'd rather have you." And now this same husband has stood beside me every step of the way since my surgery. He loves my body for what it is, scars and all. I do too. I wanted to have the BMX because I thought it was the best course of action for me. I wanted to have the TEs and implants, not because I thought it would make me more feminine, but because I wanted to be reminded that I still have a healthy body that needs more attention than I've been giving it. If for any reason this doesn't work, then I have no problems at all going au naturel. I am who I am.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 09:21PM Blessings2011 wrote: SimplyAudrey - Welcome to the forum! I'm so sorry you are going through this, especially with your other issues. Are your docs giving you only the options of hypervigilance vs Door Number Three? I can't respond to the issue of LCIS, because I had DCIS in the left breast. But I also had a microinvasion of IDC (invasive cancer) there as well. I was offered many options in the beginning, starting with a lumpectomy with radiation. But for MANY reasons (multifocal cancer - in two different places, Mom had BC, I had huge, dense, fibrocystic breasts that made mammos difficult and self-exams impossible, and my radiologist had her suspicions about the right breast) I chose Door Number Three. I took an agressive stance for a small, early cancer. In December I had a bilateral mastectomy, with immediate reconstruction. (The right turned out to be a prophy.) I had no lymph node involvement and all my margins were clear. Right now my risk of recurrence is less than 1% - 2%. Losing weight has further reduced that risk another 23%. And once I start the Arimidex in the fall (no guarantee I will stay on it) that will reduce this tiny risk by another 50%.  I had tissue expanders placed at the time of my mastectomy, and in September, once I've attained my goal weight, will have my permanent (perky!) saline implants placed. I've never once regretted my decision. I went into the surgery with great peace of mind, and that has never changed. I know it was right for me. For you, other options may be more appropriate. Read all you can, investigate all you can. There are SO many options out there, especially when it comes to reconstruction. If you have an anxiety/panic disorder, then you are probably already taking anti-anxiety meds or seeing a therapist. If not, now would be a good time to start. And give Marvin a big smack and send him back to his cage. Wishing you the best!!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2014 11:46PM Blessings2011 wrote: Ladies - just a warning!!!!  Ice packs can cause frostbite on a reconstructed breast in a VERY short amount of time!   If you have had a mastectomy, that means that all the breast and fatty tissue has been removed as close to the skin as possible, and the skin is much more vulnerable. Muscles and nerves have been cut and sutured, and your ability to perceive that burning sensation of too much cold has been compromised. I learned that the hard way when I sunburned my TEs THROUGH a white T-shirt. I was bright red and miserable, and thought ice packs would help. Fortunately, I called my PS who read me the riot act. Cool compresses, yes; ice, NEVER. As for the Pepcid helping with itching - yes - it is a Histamine II Blocker, and Benadryl is a Histamine 1 blocker. Taken together, the Pepcid enhances the efficacy of the Benadryl. Pepcid alone usually won't help, unless you have heartburn!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 02:45PM Blessings2011 wrote: Well, personally, I think cancer is a big crapshoot, as evidenced by all the people who live incredibly healthy lifestyles and still get it. But having said that, I do think there are things I can do to improve my overall lifestyle, and perhaps affect my total body health in ways that I hadn't done previously. Life isn't very stressful.... I've been retired for 8 years now. The biggest thing I did was to lose weight. I fought with my MO about taking Arimidex - even though my tumor was 100% ER+, I assured her there was no estrogen in my body.... I'd gone through menopause AND a hysterectomy... but she kindly pointed out that estrogen is still manufactured in belly fat, and I had plenty. So I went on a medically-supervised weight loss program and lost 60 pounds. That allowed me to go off all my prescription medications, and all my lab work returned to normal limits. (But I still went on the AI, darn it!) I also went gluten-free. I found out that in just three weeks on a gluten-free diet, my fibromyalgia pain of over ten years had nearly disappeared. So I just kept gluten out of my diet, thinking it might help the AI joint pain. It has, to some extent. We eat no red meat here; DH has kidney disease, and we focus on chicken and fish, or vegetarian meals supplemented with other types of protein. Neither one of us ever drank alcohol, so that wasn't an issue... We stopped with all the white sugars and high fructose corn syrup loaded foods... We read all the ingredients of each item we put in the grocery cart, and avoid any preservatives like the plague. Instead of processed foods, we stick to fresh fruits and veggies. And if we want to splurge, we splurge! Ice cream has become a treat, not a daily dietary supplement... and every once in a while I REALLY like fast-food french fries... I get weekly acupuncture sessions to lessen the AI joint stiffness and pain. We're trying to up our exercise, even if it is just walking every day. It sounds like a lot of work, but it has really just become a lifestyle.
Posts.Title: Anyone make lifestyle changes? Footballnut vbishop

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 04:19PM Blessings2011 wrote: Beesie - I think Nat23 is talking about "upgrading the tatas" by having a mastectomy and implants that would simply give her the size and shape she wants over what she has now. Nat23 - Beesie is right. An MX is never something to take lightly. I had multifocal cancer in my left breast last year, and was offered a lumpectomy with radiation. However, since the BS would have had to take such a large wedge of tissue, she suggested UMX. The Radiologist, though, was never comfortable saying she'd found everything in the right breast, and felt I needed more diagnostic tests. Even though my cancer was small, my personal and family history made it very easy for me to choose to do a BMX with immediate reconstruction. The surgery was successful - I didn't need chemo or radiation - but the truth is there are no guarantees. A recurrance can happen no matter what type of surgery you choose. It's been a year now. I've had my permanent saline implants for two months, and I love the shape and size. They're perky, but not perfect. There are still issues that need to be addressed. This could take another year, with additional surgeries down the line. It's not like breast augmentation, and certainly not the "free boob job" that so many think it is. UMX or BMX are excellent options in many cases, but are really personal decisions that should be made only after careful research and consideration. Wishing you the best!!!
Posts.Title: Benefits of mastectomy..... Nat23 Nat23

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2012 06:36AM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, Isa - I'm so sorry you have to go through this at such a young age, but the fact is, I had my fibroadenoma removed from my right breast at the age of 18. I'd had it forever, it was huge, and I figured if no doctor felt it, and it didn't hurt, it couldn't be cancer. Duh, But finally a doc did feel it, and said it had to come out. I'm hesitant to even post my experience here, as this was 53 years ago, and there just wasn't the same kind of attention paid to breast issues then. I had no biopsies, just a surgery date, and not much other information. As I recall, the surgery today would be similar to a lumpectomy. The surgeon made a large incision - much larger than they do today - and removed the lump. I think it was the size of a large walnut....pretty big! My boobs were a 34C, and the reality is that even though I had a scar, and I could sort of feel the "blank" space where the lump used to be, my right boob continued to be bigger than the left for the rest of my life, until my BMX. And the left boob is where they discovered the cancer - 53 years later!!! So no, a fibroadenoma does not automatically predispose you to getting cancer. You ask great questions, and I'm sure the other ladies will be along to chime in, but you should definitely make sure your surgeon is aware of your concerns. Have him/her explain to you in detail what your surgery will be like, and what kind of outcome you can expect. One thing I will tell you - don't freak out the first time you look at your scar. You may swear your surgeon was some unskilled quack and settled for just sewing up your incision like a gathered piece of fabric, buckling and rippling here and there. Have faith - the skin does marvelous things as it heals. Those wrinkly, rough incisions eventually fade to almost nothing and remain completely flat. Sending you big hugs and wishing you the best!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2012 01:27PM Blessings2011 wrote: My mom was dx'd with BC when she was 61. I started having annual mammos when I turned 40. The older I got, the more dense and fibrocystic my breasts got. I begged my PCP for additional tests, such as ultrasound or MRI. He informed me that these were not "screening tools". So for 20 years, I kept getting these cheerful "Congratulations -  no evidence of cancer!" postcards after each mammo. But last fall, after a "clean" mammo, I had some spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple, and after 7 diagnostic procedures, was found to have mostly DCIS, with two microinvasions of invasive cancer. The radiologist said she could see the beginnings as far back as my 2009 mammogram. (But, she added, only because she knew what she was looking for...) No, I don't think you don't have to be worried. I think you should feel lucky. This MRI can serve as a screening tool and a baseline for the future. BTW, I was dx'd as the same age as my mom (61). After her BC, she had no more recurrence and lived to be quite elderly - 87, and passed from totally unrelated causes.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 01:39PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Bob - so sorry your wife has been diagnosed, and that you are in the middle of that awful waiting period. My invasive ductal cancer was diagnosed on September 15, 2011. Because of scheduling conflicts, and a particularly bad case of flu, I did not have my bilateral mastectomy until December 5, 2011. Luckily, the cancer was small, caught early, and not agressive. I had all sorts of terrible images in my head that every day the cancer would flood throughout my body, and by the time it was removed, it would be too late. Thankfully, the surgeons and the Breast Care Coordinator talked me out of that kind of thinking. What you are talking about is essentially a matter of DAYS difference. According to Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, by the time most cancers are large enough to be detected, they have been in the body for eight to ten YEARS. Does your wife like her medical team at Dana Farber? Then that's where I'd stay. Even after waiting three months for my mastectomy, the final pathology report was good. No lymph node involvement, so no chemo; and clear margins all around so no radiation. The extra waiting time made no difference. Wishing your wife - and you - all the best.
Posts.Title: need one answer! Cadillac Cadillac

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2013 08:29PM Blessings2011 wrote: Widdershins3 - I never got my pain under control in the hospital, so when I got home I was miserable. I couldn't see how all these women could have a BMX with immediate recon, and run a marathon the next day. I felt like a complete weenie. Sometimes I would just lie in bed and cry, it hurt so bad. My BS actually yelled at me when I saw her at my one-week follow-up, and told her I was still on pain meds. She lectured me and said I should have gone off of them days earlier. But later that day, I saw my PS who said basically that was a stupid comment on the surgeon's part, and that if I was in pain, I needed to treat it, and it would take as long as it took. He readily refilled my prescriptions for Norco and Valium. But I didn't take them as prescribed, as I wanted to be like "those other women" with no pain. Then a whole bunch of very wise sisters here on BCO asked if I were taking my pain meds at maximum dosage around the clock. I wasn't. They told me that pain stresses the body, and that a body that's stressed does not heal. So I did. I took the maximum dosage, around the clock, whether I needed it at that moment or not. (The nurse in the hospital told me "You can't chase the pain, because you'll never catch up with it.") Gradually, the pain lessened, until one day I realized that I could cut back on the meds. By the time I got my first fills, a little over a month later, I was doing pretty well. (But I still wasn't ready to run a marathon!) I think now is the time to be extremely gentle with yourself. Do whatever you need to rest and recuperate, and make sure you are healing. Be sure to eat lots of protein in your diet - it helps with healing. Most people say get 100 grams a day. And stay busy doing whatever you are capable of doing, just so long as you are distracted and not focusing on your pain. Take really deep, cleansing breaths. I found that nice hot showers, and a back massage from DH helped relax me so I could sleep at night. AND - try not to compare yourself with any other person here. We are all so different. Be sure to let your doctor know about the pain. It might be time for some physical therapy or other intervention. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 01:38PM Blessings2011 wrote: Mallory - I felt exactly the same way!!! Got my DCIS/IDC dx on September 15th. Surgery (BMX/recon) was originally scheduled for Halloween. Not my first choice, but I got used to it. Then they had to reschedule due to the need for both surgeons (BS and PS) to be present in the OR. So it got bumped to November 8th. Then I started to worry - o.k., I had INVASIVE cancer....wasn't it going to spread? And since they did a core needle biopsy, wasn't that really going to spread the cancer all over the place? And what if my lymph nodes had been clear on November 7th, but showed positive on November 8th, and that would mean the difference between no chemo and chemo? AYYYY!!! But as life often does when you're busy making plans, it got more complicated. Right before my November 8th surgery, I got sick. Really sick, with a horrible upper respiratory infection. I thought maybe I could call it a cold and squeak through the surgery anyway, but my docs were smarter than that. They gave me a month to heal before trying again. And my imagination went into overtime! However, my Breast Care Coordinator was wonderful, went over my biopsy results again and again, assuring me that the IDC was tiny and because it was slow-growing, very likely had been there a while. Although she couldn't be 100% sure until the final path reports, she also said it was highly unlikely that it would spread to the lymph nodes in just a month or two. So she calmed me down, and I actually used that extra time to heal from my flu, to decorate the house for Christmas, to order gifts online and get them wrapped, and to get the house all set up (my  little healing nest) for the day I'd come home from the hospital. I'm so glad I took the extra time. I was healthier, calmer, and more prepared. Had my BMX with TEs on Monday, December 5th, and an recuperating well at home. Don't have the final path report yet, but I do have my first Post-Op appointments this Tuesday. It was 11 weeks from diagnosis to surgery. Big hugs to you!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 01:16PM Blessings2011 wrote: I had two ultrasound core-needle biopsies, and although I didn't have any pain during the procedure, my boob was sensitive and a bit bruised for several days. They sent me home with an ice pack stuffed in my bra, and I think I kept using it off and on the first night. I also slept in a loose "sleep" bra..that seemed to help. My radiologist called a few days later to find out how I was healing from the biopsy. I guess it's rougher on some women than on others. If you are having unusual pain, especially with redness, swelling, and fever (or heat in that area) be sure to call your doc ASAP,  just as a precaution.

She advised me that this was not a good idea, and that she would consult with the BS and the PS. Sure enough, they rescheduled me for a month later. Good thing, though. Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2016 01:31PM - edited Apr 15, 2016 01:33PM by Blessings2011 Ladies - this question may have been answered in the previous 113 pages, but I probably missed it. And if this is the wrong forum, I apologize in advance! My question is this: What response would you be most comfortable with hearing from someone you just disclosed your Stage IV status to? I realize everyone is different... and situations are different.... The reason I am asking is that my husband spent every Friday for a month in the Chemo Infusion room at our local hospital receiving Rituxan infusions. We met many cancer patients and their families. One day it was taking forever to be called back... the computer was down in the Pharmacy. I went over and began chatting with a very elderly lady and her daughter. The  mom disclosed to me that she'd had BC years ago and thought it was all over, til last year they found mets everywhere. I just said something like "Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. So now you're on a maintenance program for chemo?" And she replied that yes, and told me her drugs and rounds schedule. (I'd already said earlier that I had BC but no chemo or rads.) I told her she looked very pretty that day, and how was she feeling these days? She said she felt fine, and that her daughter was taking her out to lunch afterwards. I spoke to the daughter for a while about the long wait, and then we were all called back to the room. It hurts my heart to hear of sisters receiving that Stage IV dx, but stuff happens. It could happen to me; I know there are no guarantees. But in the meantime, all I can do is love and support those I know. So back to my original question.... from your point of view, what would be an ideal answer from a friend? From a stranger? (We've all seen examples of what NOT to say!)

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2012 10:43PM Blessings2011 wrote: Two days after I got my BC dx, I was in my PCP's office for some other issue. He looked at my records, realized I hadn't gotten the shingles vaccine, and sent me downstairs to get it immediately. Because we didn't know then what treatment I might have (rads, chemo), he said it was imperative to get it right away. (I was 60.) My mom had shingles in her scalp, and they were afraid it would go into her eye. It didn't. They started her on Valtrex (valacyclovir) and she had a terrible allergic reaction. (I've had Zovirax (acyclovir) for a possible herpes infection of the inner ear, and had no reaction at all to it.) Then they gave my mom Neurontin for the pain - that made her even worse. But in the end, she recovered completely, with no lasting effects, and never got a recurrence. My aunt had a terrible case of shingles many years ago, and still has post-herpetic neuralgia - the incessant pain that doesn't go away. I forgot to ask her if she ever got the vaccine. Shingles will follow nerve pathways in the body, which is why people's breakouts are so similar. According to the CDC, the vaccine is still appropriate for those who have already had shingles, and can not only lessen the chances of a recurrence, but the severity of any recurrences. http://www.cdc.gov/VACCINes/vpd-vac/shingles/default.htm

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2016 02:45PM Blessings2011 wrote:  ShetlandPony – Thank you…. I think that’s what I was aiming for: “neither overly sad nor falsely positive”…  I think that would be the response I would be most comfortable with if the situations were reversed. Thanks, DivineMrsM – I never ask a question unless I truly want to hear the answer. (I am a retired counselor…) My husband jokes that I have a “TALK TO ME” sign tattooed on my forehead. I can get a person’s whole life story in just a few minutes standing in line, or waiting in a crowded room. Every person has a story worth telling. I love your suggestions, as well as the book you mentioned. As for the hugging part, DH was there to get his immune system destroyed (Rituxan) and we both wore surgical masks, so that really wasn’t an option. (And once we got back to the room, everyone got hooked up pretty quickly.) However, on our last day there, I went over to her chair and held her free hand and called her by name (amazing, even with my brain fog – I remembered her name and her daughter’s name!) I told her how lovely it was chatting with her, and that we would keep her in our prayers for continued good outcomes during her scans. (She was wearing a cross, and had discussed her good results in recent scans, or I wouldn’t have brought that up.) Sometimes people just don’t want to discuss personal issues in a public place, but in the Oncology Waiting Room, chances are, people are there for very similar reasons. I once sat next to one woman who was very stoic for the first five minutes, and we kept the topic very light… weather, etc. Slowly she opened up about her Stage IV dx and treatment. All I did was make eye contact, and let her know I heard her every word. Sometimes that’s all you can really do. Thank you, ladies, for reassuring me that I didn’t delve into areas that were none of my business.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 04:46PM Blessings2011 wrote: MishaT - Ditto to everything NatsFan said about taking your husband with you to get your results. Initially, I got my results over the phone. The Radiologist - who I LOVED and who had done seven different biopsies on me - called one afternoon.  She asked how I was doing, and said that she had gotten my results, and that she was so sorry, but it was breast cancer. She gave me a moment to let that sink in, then went on to tell me more information that would help me understand all the GOOD things I had going for me with my particular diagnosis. (She knew me well enough to know that I used to be a medical counselor, and could absorb the more technical information.) She couldn't have been nicer to me, and for that I will always be grateful. I already had a surgeon's appt scheduled, and she said my printed reports would be available then. I thanked her, went into the bedroom, closed the door, and had a good cry. DH came in and asked what was wrong, and I told him. He just held my hand and said "No matter what happens, we're in this together. We're a team, remember that." He went to every appointment with me, and did pretty much what NatsFan described. He was my best caregiver and my biggest advocate. Since he couldn't "fix" my cancer, it helped him tremendously that I trusted him with the role of notetaker and intermediary. As I understand it, you still don't know if it's cancer or not? I love NatsFan's saying about "Don't go there until you get there." Wishing you the best on Wednesday!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 10:52PM Blessings2011 wrote: I am six months out from my BMX with immediate recon/TEs. The one thing I did that made a huge difference for me was to rent a hospital bed, because we have a Tempurpedic mattress that is like swimming in Jello, trying to get out of. (None of our recliners were comfortable enough to sleep in.) With the fully-electric bed, I could raise up the back so I wasn't sleeping flat, and raise up the mattress under the knees to make it easy on my back. When I wanted to get out of bed, I just raised the back all the way up and it was easy to stand up without using my arms. As for bathroom issues - no problem at all! Keep in mind you're reaching DOWN for that stuff....not up. I didn't shower for two weeks (as long as my drains were in) but I did use bathing wipes that made me feel fresh, and also took "birdie baths" as my MIL calls them.  DH tried to help me wash my hair in the kitchen sink, but I almost drowned, so the next time I did it myself. Some ladies go to the salon just for a wash and blow dry. The hardest part for me was pulling open the freezer drawer in the bottom of the refrigerator so I could get some ice. We finally used an ice bucket on the kitchen counter. I did have pain from the TEs, but I also tried to go it alone without pain meds. BIG mistake. When I started taking them as prescribed, the pain soon went away. I felt really crappy with no energy, and that was partly from getting the anesthesia out of my system, but mostly it was because I was eating about 25 grams of protein a day, when I really needed 100 grams. When I upped my protein intake, I felt better. I really did have a textbook recovery...no problems... and when the fills started, I had NO problems at all. My DH was amazed that I recovered, and became so independent, as fast as I did! He was prepared to be my nurse, my valet, my hairdresser, my driver, my pack mule, and my personal assistant for WAY longer than he actually was. Trust me: the anticipation is WAY worse than the reality!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2016 01:04AM Blessings2011 wrote: I had excruciating pain every day for a month after my BMX. I came home from the hospital, wanting to be like those women who had a mastectomy, took a Tylenol, then ran a marathon the next day. (Or so it seemed from their posts.) I didn't realize how unlikely that was, as my pain was never under control in the hospital... I refused to use the Morphine PCA at my bedside. Then I paid attention to all the wise women here who told me that I had been given pain meds for a reason, and to TAKE THEM in order to stay ahead of the pain. Once you have it, it's hard to catch up. I had a combination of Norco and Valium, which worked well. I took them exactly according to directions, around the clock. That broke the pain cycle, and I was able to wean off them. It just took me longer. If it were me, I'd get back on a regular schedule with the meds, then rather than skipping them entirely, just cut back on the dosage gradually until you don't need them any more. You might surprise yourself. Yes, PMPS is a definite possibility, but being only two weeks post-BMX with immediate implants, I would give yourself more time to heal. Be sure to tell your PS you are having pain. A good motto for post-surgery activities: Just because you CAN, doesn't mean you SHOULD.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2012 06:10PM - edited Jan 27, 2012 06:10PM by Blessings2011 I've been healing nicely and fills are going well....hard to believe, since I was such a big baby here when I first got home from the BMX! I just never thought the day would come when I didn't feel like I was dying from the TE pain. Now, it's - to use that awful word - DOABLE. I'm happy that I have good range of motion, but I still have quite a bit of underarm pain where they took three "sentinel nodes"...(not just one)...I didn't need axillary dissection, though. But this morning, stretching in bed, I felt something like a skinny rope deep inside my armpit. Yikes! Pleased as I am with healing, though, I was really ticked off that never in this journey did a medical professional stress to me the possibilities of LE. Oh, it was mentioned in the tons of literature I was given, but no one really talked about it. I even went to a "Post Mastectomy Physical Therapy and Lymphedema" workshop a few weeks ago. Huuuuuge waste of time! More blah blah blah about other stuff, and a two-page handout on where lymph nodes are located in the body. I think there were some minimal suggestions for massage. And there were only two of us MX patients there...it could have been SO much more personalized! So yesterday I got a referral to the LE "Specialist" at the hospital. I'll see her on Monday. Dang, sometimes ya just gotta keep hammering away to get what ya need!!! Big hugs to all my December sisters....and special prayers for all those facing challenges right now.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 02:51PM Blessings2011 wrote: Well, after 30+ years of battling my weight, I am ready to take a serious step. Kaiser has a Weight Management program that lasts for 82 weeks. (gasp!) The first 16 weeks consist of medically-supervised meal replacement products, including shakes, soups, and bars. The next phase deals with building back in healthy home cooked meals. There are weekly meetings, lab tests, physician supervision, psychological supervision, and groups. Interestingly, a cancer diagnosis is NOT one of the medical conditions that preclude you from this program, unless you are actively receiving chemo or rads. I had signed up for an orientation session over a year ago, then cancelled, thinking "Who am I kidding?" But one of the ladies in my quilting class recently completed the program and has lost 70 pounds, and is off all of her diabetes, cholesterol, and blood pressure medication. I'll be attending the next orientation session in a few weeks. It's not cheap, but at this point, my health is worth it. Several things changed my mind: the fact that my cancer is estrogen-driven, and despite the fact that I've been post-menopausal for 14 years, estrogen is still made in the brain, and - in BELLY FAT! The other thing is that I have SO many other health problems, including severe fibromyalgia, that restricts my ability to get good daily exercise, even walking sometimes. My cholesterol is high, my blood sugar is high, and I have degenerative disk disease and spinal stenosis. Weighing in at 185 pounds on my 5.5" frame has taken its toll. I am really afraid of taking the Arimidex - not because I "could" get the side effects, but rather because I already have so many of them. What if they get worse? I am too young to feel this old. I will be meeting with my MO again to discuss Plan A, Plan B, and so on, should I be totally unable to take the AIs. But I am hoping that dropping an excess of, say, 50 pounds, will make a big difference in my ability to even get moving daily, to strengthen my muscles to avoid falling, and to get my diet back to ground zero so that I may begin a whole new way of eating for the rest of my life. Will keep you all posted!

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 03:30AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hello, December Sisters! We've just now gotten back from a week in Laguna Beach (we have a timeshare there.) GORGEOUS weather.....and for the first time since my BMX in December, I felt NORMAL!!! After three weeks of pure H#LL after my BMX with TEs, the annoying discomfort has disappeared....of course, they still feel like boulders under my skin, but I had one of those cami's with a built-in shelf bra, and wore it under my shirt as we sat in our lawn chairs down at the surf. DH was running the video camera of the waves, so we can have a relaxing DVD to play on our flat screen TV. While he was doing that, I took my shirt off, just had my cami on (and jeans), and went around taking pictures of shells and driftwood. (Couldn't take any with me, it was a protected tidepool.) Standing in the surf, taking pictures, enjoying the beautiful surroundings, I felt NORMAL! I did not feel like a breast cancer patient. I even had him take pics of me in all my pasty-white, pre-weight-loss glory. Of course, my stamina sucks something awful, but I have to say, I was NOT thinking about the TEs that whole time! Will catch up with individual posts later when I've unpacked....or maybe when I've had a nice long hot shower....or maybe tomorrow!!! Nighty-night!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 01:39PM Blessings2011 wrote: Cookie - hope today is a good sign that the itchies are going away! Keep us posted! ~~~~~~~~~~~ Optifast is going well.....last night was class, and I lost 4.8 pounds last week. The only glitch - my ALT (liver function) numbers have tripled. Somewhat worrisome....I had HepB in 1982 (almost died) and am very protective of my liver. Doc says he is more interested in symptoms than numbers (I have none) but is sending me for an US on liver and gallbladder tonight at the hospital. It was so weird - I mentioned it to a my friend in class who is a 3 year ovarian cancer survivor, and she asked "Are you worried about liver mets?" I just stared at her. Never crossed my mind. But there is a higher incidence of liver cancer in post HepB patients, so better safe than sorry, and run the tests now. I'll also have additional bloodwork. Come to find out, several members of the class showed elevated ALT numbers in the beginning, which came down on their own. This is what I am hoping for.....that it's diet-related. There is some research showing that Optifast actually reduces the size of the liver, and causes it to release fats into the bloodstream. Hoping to get to the bottom of this mystery, and that I can stay in the program because it really does work! I love the products, it's easy to stick to, and I'm never hungry. If I have to take a break I will, which just means the TEs will be in longer than I'd hoped. Got them in December, was hoping for exchange in September. The only issue I'm having now is that the smaller I get, the bigger (and harder) my 620cc TEs feel - especially at night - it's like rolling over onto a boulder! Other than that, life is good. Sending out hugs to all my December sisters!!!!

Clerk: "Well, sometimes we don't get the correct information." Me: "Obviously. But in the meantime, if you do find a third party liable for my condition, could you please let me know? It sure would feel good to sue someone for this." Clerk: (Speaking very quickly now)........"Uh, again, I didn't mean to upset you, Mrs. X. Have a nice day!" CLICK. Argggggghhhh......

Fitzdc - YAY on the good outcome of your revision!!! And new nips? WooHOO! I'm still thinking of finding a way to go see Vinnie for 3D tatts. Hope your neck issues resolve soon! ~~~~~~~~~~~~  After my BMX w/TEs in December, I got filled to 620 ccs in only five visits. At that time I asked my PS what would happen if he put in implants the size of my Amazon-sized TEs, and I later lost weight. He said the implants wouldn't change at all. "So I'd have stripper boobs?" I asked. He kind of laughed and nodded. "I'll get back to you." I told him. I could have had my exchange already, but I decided to postpone it to lose weight. After my surgery, my risk of recurrence was 1% to 2%. My MO wanted me on Anastrozole (generic Arimidex) right away. I said I didn't need it. I was post-menopausal (14 years) and had already had a hysterectomy. She kindly pointed out that estrogen was manufactured in - among other things- BODY FAT!!! So in March, I joined the Optifast weight loss program at Kaiser. So far, I've lost almost 50 pounds, and am aiming for another 10 - 15 pounds. I wanted to go a little lower, since I heard that Anastrozole tends to put weight on you. But the docs will tell me when I've lost enough. (And the MO let me postpone the AI until the Fall...) For the first time in years, I'm working out. I do water aerobics, go to the gym, walk, and ride my bike. My fibromyalgia pain (usually a "15") is now a 1 -2 on a scale of 10. Not because of the weight loss so much, but because I've gotten off all the white sugar, white flour, and gluten. Now we're slowly adding back in real food, and in another two weeks I'll be cleared to go into surgery again. As I lose more weight (and padding) the TEs seem bigger and harder. Sleeping at night is very difficult and painful. It's time for them to go. I see the PS on Thursday, and will ask for the next available date for exchange surgery. Thanks again to Kam for checking in with us again!!!! Later, Sisters....gotta go swim.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2012 04:50AM Blessings2011 wrote: Kam - gentle hugs to you. Flutelike? I thought perhaps it was a new music therapy for neuropathy. Ginger -  I've had fibromyalgia since 2000, have gone through a ten-week Pain Management program for chronic pain, and have a standing order for Vicodin when the pain keeps me from sleeping several nights in a row. However,  one of the unexpected side effect of my four months on Optifast was a huge reduction in my fibromyalgia pain. I'd say on a pain scale of 1 - 10, it's been like a 1 or a 2 instead of the constant 7,8,9. What was different? Optifast is gluten-free. I'd always wanted to go on an elimination diet, but it was just too darn much trouble. But four months on the liquid fast, and my symptoms diminished so quickly I know it wasn't from just the weight loss and exercise. I've also been reading on the AI threads about how women with joint pain SEs have benefitted from eliminating gluten from their diets. Faith - That whole Brava thing is SO out there! I mean, who woulda thought of that? Creating the framework to inject your own cells to recreate a breast....amazing!!!! Do you think maybe a warm washcloth in the morning could help break the seal and make it easier to peel the sticky sides off so it doesn't hurt you? ~~~~~~~~~~ I see the PS tomorrow!!! I have my 10,000 questions all neatly typed up, along with my Allergan catalog circled and marked, and am hoping that we can set a date for exchange.....SOON!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 07:21PM Blessings2011 wrote: Had a GREAT meeting with the PS yesterday....he was so impressed with my weight loss, and even remarked "Wow, I can't believe how big these expanders look now that you've gotten so much smaller!" I was basking in the glow of that and other positive comments all evening.... Here is what I know: he will be using Allergan Natrelle High Profile Smooth Saline implants, in either 650, or 700 ccs. Each of these can be overfilled by 40-50ccs. (thank you, Whippetmom!!!) Currently, my 700cc TEs are underfilled at 620ccs. The fact that my TEs are wider than the implants won't be a problem - the most would be 2 cm, just one cm on each side. The TEs touch in the middle, and the implants won't. He won't be doing any suturing to make the pockets smaller, as that would cause a longer surgery and recovery time for me, and possible complications down the road. He wants the implants to move, and not be like the TEs. He did say that perhaps they may migrate slightly when I lie on my back, but they definitely won't point east and west, or disappear under my armpits.   Surgery will be outpatient, about two hours. General anesthesia but no intubation, just LMA (laryngeal mask airway). NO DRAINS!!! Two hours in Recovery, and home I go. Will get a big Ace bandage in the OR, a few days later I can switch to a sports bra, and then we'll discuss more supportive, underwire bras I can get. Tentatively, I'm scheduled for August 22nd. (I think he's fitting me in on one of his Clinic days. He knows I'm more than ready to get this done!) SOOOO - almost ready to cross over to the squishie side!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 08:16PM Blessings2011 wrote: Kam170 - Absolutely... the conditions surrounding your retirement can play a big part in how you feel about it. Many people who are forced to take disability retirement do have to go through that grieving process, and often feel cheated out of being able to finish off their careers the way they wanted to. When I retired, I had been married for a year. My DH retired right before our wedding, after 33 years of teaching high school. He was SO ready. But I had a mom in assisted living, and the costs were very high, so back to work I went. When she went into a skilled nursing facility the following year, MediCal picked up the tab and I could afford to retire. I absolutely loved my job, my colleagues, and my students. My identity was wrapped up in being a counselor, and I did wonder who I would be after I was no longer employed. I gave the university six months notice. During that time, I made sure I completed the major projects I had started, so I could leave on a high note. While I knew I would miss my co-workers, several had already left for other jobs or retirement, and I knew we'd find a way to keep in touch. My first weeks at home were a blur. I felt compelled to stay busy; to be productive. I cleaned out closets, I rearranged rooms, I organized the junk in the garage. Then I realized I didn't have to do anything I didn't want to  You're right... you are making a very fast transition. It may take a while to realize the benefits. But I think especially since we've had BC, that makes us think about the way we spend our time, and just how much time working does take up.  I am so fortunate I retired before my dx. I can't imagine trying to make doctors' appointments at only "convenient" times, or begging for extra time off because I just wasn't feeling strong enough to go back to work after surgery. Now that I think about it, I don't know anyone who has regretted the decision to retire! I am happy for you. p.s. Are those your kitties in your avatar? CUTE!

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 09:06PM Blessings2011 wrote: WHOA, NELLIE!!!! First fills today!!! Got 180 ccs in the OR on December 5th. I asked the PS if I were getting 50 ccs today, as that seems to be the standard here on the forum, and he said "Let's just see how it goes. I don't have any preconceived amounts that I use." (And of course, I'm thinking, he'll just keep inflating me until I scream, or they pop.......) Well, he did the left side first. I felt nothing - not even when the needle went in! He filled very slowly, and kept asking me how it felt. Finally I said it feels kind of heavy....and he said that was good. Then he did the other side. THAT one I felt....a little bit of stinging/burning.  He said it was because the needle was going though the muscle to the port, and that next time, it may be completely different, or I may not feel it at all. Again, he filled it slowly, and when I said I was feeling some pressure, he stopped. He filled me with 100ccs in each side today!!!! Yowza!!! Right now, they just feel tight, no real pain except for one area underneath the left IMF. He said that this was where the pocket was beginning to expand. He said I may be sore tonight, but then again, I may not. I was hoping to see this big rise in my foobs as he filled, but remember, I have the Amazon size expanders in, and 100ccs spreads out over a wide, diffuse area. I think the other thing to keep in mind is that pre BMX I had so much loose skin, and such lax pecs, it may be easier for me to accept a larger fill than someone with a smaller chest area and tighter skin. I can now take a shower and let the spray hit my incisions, which are healing well. (I still can't take a bath because the drain incision on the right is still somewhat deep and trying to heal.) I can use soap and water on them, and lotion if I want. Tomorrow I'm going to a Physical Therapy/Lymphedema class at the hospital, and I can take notes, but he said to not do any of the stretching or other exercises until he sees me again. That doesn't bother me, as I don't seem to have much swelling/lymphedema that I can see, and I do have good ROM already. He said I could carry a purse that weighs less than 10 pounds (DH laughed out loud at that one) and that if I felt o.k., I could start driving again. On Friday, the Oncologist had been adamant that I lose weight and get in shape....DH and I belong to the Outpatient facility of a local Rehabilitation hospital, and the PS said it's o.k. to walk on the treadmill, do light lower body exercises, but no arm or upper body work. And - I can't go back to the therapy pool yet....they keep it at 94 degrees, and it's wonderful for my fibromyalgia, but even though they keep it full of chemicals, I can't take the chance on picking up any infections. SO - one more milestone achieved!!! If I keep going at this rate, I'll be done with fills and the waiting period, and can have my exchange surgery much sooner than I had imagined. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ AussieKate - so sorry to hear of your setbacks....prayers and hugs for you as you deal with this new information as well. fitzdc - will be thinking of you as you talk to the oncologist tomorrow. Please post what you find out! chrissilini - I had all sorts of hard places on my chest....around my foobs, underneath/inside my foobs, you name it. But that seemed to change every day. The skin got looser, and I think the TEs got more recognizable to me. I'm slowly learning exactly where they are, and what's happening with them. Of course, with every fill, that will change! I'm just glad you don't have an infection...

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2012 08:47PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, smethot, and welcome to the forum. A little over a year ago, I was in your shoes. I'd gotten the diagnosis of BC, and was waiting for surgery. I knew I had multifocal (in more than one place) DCIS (non-invasive cancer) with multifocal IDC (invasive ductal carcinoma). I'd had seven different diagnostic procedures, and had met with the surgeon. I was offered a lumpectomy with radiation, but since the cancer was in two places, the surgeon recommended a unilateral mastectomy. After much consideration of my history, I chose a bilateral mastectomy. I had my surgery on December 5, 2011. I was very fortunate. The cancer was very small and caught early. All the margins were clear, the Sentinel Node Biopsy (SNB) was clear at the time of surgery. Even better, all the nodes were clear in the final pathology report. What that meant was that I did not need chemo or radiation. I chose to have immediate reconstruction, by having Tissue Expanders placed at the time of my surgery. Last August, I had them swapped out for permanent saline implants.  In the process, I found a way to get healthy - which I hadn't been for years. I lost a lot of weight, started exercising, and today I feel better than I have in 20 years. My BC treatment consists of taking an estrogen-blocker for the next five years. Yes, the fear of BC can be awful. But you seem to have a partial plan in place already, and you will know more once you have met with your surgeon. There are many pieces of the breast cancer puzzle, and the more you know, the more powerful you will feel. But stay away from Dr. Google! He can be a liar and a fearmonger! Wait until you get personalized information from your surgeon. Wishing you and your family a blessed Christmas....
