Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 04:39PM Blessings2011 wrote: When I had my BMX on December 5th, I was prepared for EVERYTHING! My house was organized, I'd purchased all sorts of mastectomy-related items, including the camisoles with drain pouches, the Pink Pockets, and a ton of button-front clothes. My bag for the hospital was chock-full of everything I MIGHT need. Here's the thing - I never even opened that bag once when I was there. My surgery was late in the day, I got to my room about 8 pm, and when I was finally awake at 1 am, I chatted with the nurses, fell asleep, chatted some more, fell asleep, and later on that morning it was time to go home. I was wrapped in a giant, thick Ace bandage that would remain on for a week, so I just used my diaper pins to keep the drains pinned to the bandage. I dressed in what I'd wear to bed when I got home, had a nice fuzzy robe, and a pillow to protect my chest on the short drive home. But the smartest thing I did was rent a hospital bed for my immediate recovery. Our mattress is a Tempurpedic, wonderful to sleep in, but you really need the strength of two arms to get in and out of it. With the hospital bed, I could raise the head up to where it needed to be (they don't want you lying flat for a while) and because you need to sleep on your back (which is painful for me) raising the mattress up under my knees made it very comfy. DH rigged up a remote control for my reading lamp, and I had an over-the-bed table for all my "stuff". I also had a huge brass bell to ring to summons DH if I needed him, but that hospital bed gave me the independence I needed! The other thing I found handy was to wear satin jammies to bed....easy to turn, position, and slide out of bed to get to the bathroom. We had a "drain station" set up, with surgical gloves (DH is a former EMT), alcohol wipes, the measuring cups we got from the hospital, and the daily log. Make sure you empty those drains regularly - before they get full - and log in the amounts each time.  Fold the empty bulb in half, then roll it towards the top to squeeze all the air out.  Be VERY careful about wiping the plugs and the bulb openings with alcohol before sealing up again....this is an open pathway to germs to get into the body. We also kept a clipboard of the drugs I took, so I made sure I didn't take too few or too many. Many hugs and prayers to you, Kouragio!

So I did.   But I also looked at the diet and exercise plan as my breast cancer treatment, since I had not needed chemo or rads. I don't regret it at all, and in fact, I'd never felt as good as I did when the program ended. Thank you for your kind words.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 06:46PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, mom22ja! A lot of your questions about the surgery will be answered by your surgeon on Friday. In the meantime, here's some info from BCO regarding different types of surgeries: http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/surgery/ Are you having a UMX or a BMX? (Unilateral or bilateral mastectomy?) Everyone heals at a different rate and everyone's pain tolerance is different. I wanted to be one of those women who came home from surgery and only took a Tylenol, and ran a marathon a few weeks later. Uh, that wasn't me. For me, I did need to take my pain meds. Prior to surgery, I had a little "nest" set up in the master bedroom where I could recover in peace and quiet. We had a "drain station" set up in the bathroom, where all the supplies we needed, as well as the logs for writing in the information were kept. We also had a clipboard for meds, so DH could log in what I took and when. As far as the tissue expanders go, they are basically like deflated implants, except they have a hard back. (Implants are squishie all over.) The expander has a metal port, which is how fills are done. More about this below. (Note: you cannot have an MRI with these metal ports in place!) During the MX, after all the breast tissue is removed, the plastic surgeon (PS) will separate the pectoral muscles on the chest, and make a pocket for the expanders to go into. He will suture them in place. Once the expanders are in place, most of the time, he will then fill them with a small amount of saline. (You may wake up from surgery with teensy little foobs.) Before you are sutured up, he may insert Jackson Pratt drains, which are long clear tubes that help drain any excess fluid away from your chest. The tubes are about three feet long, and the top 8" is flattened, with holes to draw in the fluid. Then the tubing becomes round and clear, and exits your body through a tiny hole. The tube is stitched in place. At the end of the clear tube is the drain bulb, which collects the draining fluid. It really does sound gorier than it is. There is a whole procedure for emptying the drains and logging in the amounts. The nurse or breast care coordinator should show you how it's done. PM me if you want more info. Once the drains and the tissue expanders are in place, the PS will then suture you up. Don't freak out if this isn't the best sewing job you've ever seen....it's only temporary. You'll wake up in recovery. Be sure to let your anesthesiologist know in Pre-Op if you have any concerns regarding nausea or vomiting after surgery. There are wonderful drugs he can give you while you're out so that you don't experience any of that. Soon you'll be taken to your room. If you have pain, say so. Otherwise, you may have a PCA (Patient Controlled Anesthesia) machine by your bed. Use it if you need it. I read so many posts on what to take to the hospital - I came prepared for anything, and never opened my bag once. After my surgery, I was all set to go with a mastectomy cami, but when I woke up, I was wearing a huge Ace bandage...so I just pinned my drains to the bottom of that with cute diaper pins. Bring a pillow for the ride home. Not to snooze on, but to put between your chest and the seatbelt. Have a comfy place to sleep - you'll need to be raised up, and on your back. Lots of ladies use recliners, I rented a hospital bed. Be sure to stay hydrated, and TAKE THE STOOL SOFTENERS even if you think you don't need them. Like I said, pain tolerance varies so much......but if you are in pain, let your doctor know. You should be sent home with good meds to keep you comfortable. Watch out for foods that people bring over. I never had so much greasy, fatty, rich casseroles in my whole life! Set things down where you can reach them in the kitchen. Don't lift anything over what your doctor tells you to. Get up and move every day, but don't overdo it. Some docs let you shower with drains in, others don't. Be really careful emptying the drains....that's a direct path for bacteria to enter the body. After all the bandages came off, nothing touched my skin that wasn't freshly laundered. When your incisions have mostly healed, then your fills will start. You go to your PS's office, and lie on a table. Remember the metal ports? Since the TEs are located UNDER the pectoral muscles, he will use a small tool like a studfinder to locate the port. Then he will use a small needle and syringe and go through the skin and muscle, into the TE and being filling it with sterile saline. Don't be nervous. Most of the time you will have no feeling at all when the needle goes in, thanks to the nerves being cut during the MX. Sometimes, though, the TEs can shift a bit under the skin, and you may feel the briefest of little stings if the port happens to end up under an area with partial feeling. But usually it doesn't. The PS will have his own method for fills. Mine said he went by how the breast mounds looked and felt, and by what the patient told him. I just remember saying "they feel kind of full" and then finding out he had filled me to 120ccs. This was after getting 180ccs in the OR! If you've had radiation, or have any skin or healing issues at all, the best policy is "Low and Slow." That means not too many ccs at once, and not too close together. They can also remove saline after they put it in, if you feel it too much. Later on in the day, some ladies feel muscle spasms in the back or shoulders. I never did, but then again, I was overweight, and had lots of extra skin and very loose muscles. At that point, muscle relaxers, Valium, and warm showers help. When the TEs are filled to the size agreed upon by you and your PS, then you wait to make sure everything is healed. Mine makes you wait 3 months. Your next surgery will be your exchange surgery, where your TEs are removed, and your permanent implants put in. Sorry this is so long..hope it helps!

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 03:58AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Shachar - I had numerous tests and biopsies, and I've had two Ultrasound-Assisted Core Needle Biopsies. Here is my experience. Mine were done in the ultrasound room. My breast was exposed, and the tech put the gel on it so the radiologist could use the wand to see the tumor/suspicious area. Once the tumor was located, then the Radiologist gave me a numbing shot in the breast, which sounds way worse than it is. The shot stings for a very brief moment, then the tissue goes numb. When she was sure that I couldn't feel anything, she had the tech isolate the exact area of the tumor, and she inserted the instrument that has the core-needle on it. She put the tip of the needle into the mass, and counted to three. She explained that I would hear a snapping sound as the instrument took a tiny bit of tissue, but should feel nothing. She was right. She did this several times to get several samples, and even though I could feel pressure as she moved the instrument around, I didn't feel any pain at all. I could have looked at the ultrasound screen if I wanted to, or watched the needle go into my breast, but I chose not to. I figured if I couldn't see it, it wouldn't hurt. I was right. In fact, we were talking the whole time, and I remember laughing at quite a few things that were said. I was very comfortable. Afterwards, I got a bandaid, and an ice pack to stuff inside my bra for the ride home. I kept icing the area for the rest of the night, and except for a bit of bruising, had no after effects. If you ask for some anti-anxiety meds beforehand, you might get them, but you in that case you may want a ride home. Seriously, if you don't want to watch, just close your eyes and do some deep breathing. It will be over before you know it! Wishing you the best....

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 07:06PM Blessings2011 wrote: In defense of getting results over the phone, I do need to stress that I had spent hours and hours developing a relationship with my wonderful Radiologist. She was kind, nurturing, caring, informative, and only wanted the best for me. She was obsessed with getting me the absolute maximum amount of information about what was going on in my breast, so I could have the best tools to make a decision, should that time come. This woman not only took the time to call me at home (where and when I requested) with the results, her manner over the phone could not have been any more nurturing than if we were sitting face to face. It was more like a telephone counseling session, where she was concerned not only about getting me the facts, but also the good news, the decisions that would have to be made, the next steps in the process, the professionals I would be seeing and their roles in my treatment, and every few minutes she would just stop and ask me how I was doing. At the end, she gave me her pager number and told me to call her any time I had questions, or just needed to talk. She also came into the hospital on her vacation to reassess my films and diagnostic results to see if there might have been anything she missed - especially on the right breast which had shown up negative in the mammogram. She consulted with a colleague, and decided that should I want a lumpectomy on the left, she really wanted me to go in and have additional tests on the right, including an MRI. She called me at home to tell me this. By that time, I had decided on a BMX. She took a deep breath, and told me that in her opinion, I had made a very wise choice. I will always remember the way she made me feel - important, cared for, supported, and encouraged. A friend of mine who is a five year BC survivor, told me I would meet many wonderful angels (helpers) along the way. I think my Radiologist was the first one, and she definitely set the tone for what I would experience the during the rest of my BC journey. BTW, this was at Kaiser, where all my procedures and treatments are under one roof, and all the different professionals speak very highly of each other.

I'd had a core-needle biopsy, and all I could imagine was the needle puncturing the cancer, and having it spread all over my body like a balloon with a hole in it. I also said that maybe it wasn't in the nodes now, but in three months I was sure it would be. She talked me down from the ledge, saying that breast cancer didn't act like that. She calmed my fears, and my surgery turned out fine.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2012 05:05AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Jubby, and welcome to the forum! I was a total space cadet the first two months after my BMX, I think...mostly because I had pain issues with my TEs, and was still on the pain meds. There are two things you can do to help the healing process along: 1) Drink plenty of water! The anesthesia and other assorted drugs do stay in your system for a while, and staying hydrated helps flush them out, as well as helping eliminate constipation and other pesky side effects of surgery. 2) Make sure you are eating enough protein. It has been suggested that after surgery, we need at least 100 grams of protein a day to heal. I wasn't getting enough, and when I upped my protein intake, I felt so much better! At 11 days out, you are still recovering, and will be for a while. Now is the time to be good to yourself... rest, relax, and nap when you need to. And when you start to feel better, don't fall into the trap that many of us do, and try to do too much at once. We still need to follow our doctors' restrictions, no matter how good we feel. Wishing you the best in your recovery!

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2014 07:19PM Blessings2011 wrote: sbrownrigg - Congratulations on crossing over to the Squishy Side!  After my BMX, I practically hid behind my husband whenever we walked through crowds... I didn't want anyone bumping into me.  After Exchange, I was protective of my chest until I knew I was healed inside and out. But I did worry about the implants themselves... it will be two years in August that I got my permanent saline implants. Recently, I had an acupuncture treatment that required me to lie on my stomach. Flat. Yep - like lying on two small beach balls. I was sure I'd hear a big bang, and they would deflate.  I was very hesitant, but turns out, those suckers are STRONG.  As you heal from your surgery, and your swelling goes down, and your pain recedes, and your restrictions are over, you will find out what you can and can't do with regard to your muscles. That part is a whole new world. I never knew I could hurt myself opening up a window. But I was standing wrong when I did it, and pulled a muscle. You'll learn safer ways to do things with your arm and chest muscles, but as for the implants, they really don't need much protection! Wishing you great healing....

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 12:55AM Blessings2011 wrote: Kristin - that must be so painful for you! Soooo sorry to hear that!!!!!  My MIL was recently refused surgery, as they discovered a bedsore she had developed in the nursing home. The surgeon said that bedsores can go from Stage I (just beginning) to Stage IV (to the bone) in a very short amount of time. If you haven't already done so, you need to contact your doctor ASAP! That way you will know that you are treating it correctly, and not just guessing. It needs to be seen to determine the best treatment. Memory foam conforms to the body, keeping air out. The better choice would be an egg-crate foam pad, allowing more air to circulate. Hope it goes away soon, and that you find relief!

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 02:14PM Blessings2011 wrote: Anesthesia and major surgery really do a number on you. It takes a while to recover. Are you taking your blood pressure? If it's low, that can cause dizziness. Are you drinking enough fluids? Again, that can cause dizziness. How about protein? When I came home from the hospital, I felt so weak and unsteady, I could barely stand. That seemed to be lasting an awful long time, then I realized I was eating the same foods as my DH. Well, he has kidney disease and is on a very low-protein diet. I read here that we need as much as 100g of protein a day to heal. I was getting less than 25g. So I got some protein drinks, and some organic turkey jerky to snack on, and that made me feel much better. Also, any pain meds you are on can cause dizziness. Just be careful. Walking is great, but you may want to limit it to walking near your house for short periods of time. Just getting in the car and driving to the store can be very tiring. Give it time, and just to be on the safe side, let your doc know what's going on. Hoping you feel better soon!

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2014 12:49PM - edited Nov 4, 2014 12:54PM by Blessings2011 Less than 1% risk of reduction here. Multifocal DCIS and multifocal IDC, but IDC tumors were 1.5mm and 0.5mm, AND although they showed up in numerous biopsies, were missing in final path report after BMX. So, tiny tumors, no node involvement, clean margins, no Oncotype test = no chemo, no rads, and 5 years prescribed AI. First, I lost a lot of weight. That reduced my risk by 33%, bringing it to under 1%, then I went on Arimidex, then Femara, which further reduced my risk by 50%, bringing it to the 0.33% range.  "BUT" - my MO said - "it's not zero. (Not possible.) As long as there is a risk I want you on AIs." I gave it my best shot for two years but dangerous SEs convinced the MO to take me off completely. Risk is still extremely low - less than 1% - but it's still there.  And - I may be wrong -  I don't believe the type of surgery you have defines risk percentage.... in other words, BMX is really no better than lumpectomy with rads... it just happened to be the right choice for me. So I'll remain vigilant, but not obsessed with recurrence. It's a crap shoot.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 12:43PM Blessings2011 wrote: Initially I could have had a lumpectomy with rads, but I did a ton of research to discover what each of my options were, and why. I had mostly multifocal DCIS, with a microinvasion of IDC in the left breast. My radiologist felt sure there was something in the right breast, but was having difficulty seeing anything through the dense, heavy tissue. I had lots of risk factors, my mom had breast cancer (but I was never given the BRCA test), and "the girls" were 38DD/38DDD before my dx. Everything considered, I went with a BMX with immediate reconstruction in December,  and I've never regretted it.The final path report showed no cancer on the right, so it turned out to be a prophy mastectomy after all. I don't care. I'm still glad I did it. I am finished with fills, and - after a stringent weight loss program - will have my exchange surgery in late summer or early fall. I can still get breast cancer again, either a local or a distance recurrence, but my risk is very, very small. Just because I had both breasts removed does not mean it can't come back. However, I did not need chemo or rads, just five years of Arimidex. In the meantime, I'll be vigilant, but not obsessed.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 07:43PM Blessings2011 wrote: laniek - I'm not sure that your BS/PS will give you much of a preference. My drains were more under my arms, and I think this is mostly because of how the drain tubes are constructed. The clear tubes that lead to the plastic bulbs can be up to 36" long. But the part that is under your skin is flat, with perforations, like a soaker hose. That part is about 8" long. I don't think I know of anyone who had drain tubes exiting near the breastbone. That may make it easier to sleep on your sides, though, if you don't have TEs that cause pain.
Posts.Title: drains laniek GmaFoley

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2014 03:23AM Blessings2011 wrote: Twolumps - They may not release you from the hospital unless you have someone to spend the first night with you. As for being incapacitated, the mastectomy itself is fairly straightforward. Breast tissue is primarily fat and glandular tissue being removed. It's the reconstruction process that adds time in the OR, and pain afterwards. Hard-backed tissue expanders are inserted underneath pectoral muscles and nerves that have been cut and sutured. I was suprised at how little hand grip I had when it came to things like opening jars. And the suggestion about moving needed items to counter-level was right on. As for taking care of personal needs on the toilet, no worries there. You can do whatever you need to do by yourself. I did a ton of laundry ahead of time so that I could go for a week without wearing the same pjs twice. I also had a week's worth of camisoles, but I didn't buy all the expensive mastectomy camisoles. I just pinned my drains to my camis with diaper pins. AND - once I could take a shower, I never used the same towel twice. Again, I was just thinking of germs. Oh - the best jammies I got were brushed satin. Nice and warm, and the satin made it easier to move around in bed. A note about stripping drains: it's RARELY needed. In the beginning you'll see a lot of dark fluid coming down the tubes into the bulbs. Make sure you empty out the bulbs and log in the amounts before they get half full. This keeps the good suction going. In fact, you can wash your hands well or use gloves, sit on the side of the tub or on a stool, remove the cap, empty the bulb into the measuring cup, and log in the amount. Toss the fluid in the toilet and flush it down. Then, before you put the cap back on, take an alcohol wipe and clean all around the cap and the bulb opening. With the cap still off, flatten the bulb, start rolling it up from the bottom so all the air is squeezed out of it, THEN put the cap back on. This is how the nurse in the hospital taught me to do it. As you start to heal, what you see in the clear tubes will change from a dark fluid to a more pinkish straw colored fluid. You will also probably see lots of strands of gunk in the tubes. While it's not pretty, it does NOT mean that the tube has to be stripped. If your bulb is still filling up, the fluid is being drawn out of your body into the drain. You can try to strip your drains by pinching the tube at the top where it exits your body. Don't worry - it's stitched in there. Hold it tight against your body, and use a wet alcohol wipe to pull hard and "milk" the tube down towards the bulb. What you will probably find is that nothing really moves. I tried the tube stripping thing once or twice, then called the PS who told me to forget it as long as I was getting drainage into the bulbs. DH told me he was very surprised that I became as independent as I did so quickly.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 04:08PM Blessings2011 wrote: hawaiik!!!!! So good to see you posting here.... Sounds like us December gals had lots of different procedures and challenges. I can't believe that in four days it will be five months since my BMX! I just remember all the anxiety leading up to surgery day... Post BMX was o.k., except for the TEs which were trying to kill me. The pain was unbearable. Then I finally took the advice of the ladies on the forum, who said TAKE THE PAIN MEDS! I did, around the clock, and finally turned the corner on pain. A month later, I started fills, and because I was so overweight and flabby, I was filled to 620ccs in only 5 visits. Now I am on Optifast (liquid meal replacement) through Kaiser, and postponing my exchange surgery until I lose another 40 pounds. (I'm already down 31 pounds....wooHOO!) So maybe exchange in September? I was fortunate. Did not need chemo or rads. So this four month liquid diet is nothing. I just consider it part of my BC treatment. (My MO is thrilled.) I'll start the Arimidex in the fall, too. Sending out big hugs and positive thoughts to all our December sistahs!!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 01:39PM Blessings2011 wrote: Welcome to the forum, kpannabecker! I think we've all been where you are....in the Waiting Room .... just...WAITING. With your history, it's normal to be anxious, but the truth is, right now all you have is news. You don't have BAD news. My original girls were 38DDD. They were dense, heavy, painful, and fibrocystic. They felt like socks filled with rocks. There was no way I could do a self exam - there were lumps everywhere! But for the past 20 years, I've gotten clear mammograms. In September 2011, though, I had some bleeding from my nipple, and by the time I could have surgery for it, it was December 2011. I was totally freaked out at the time lapse, but my medical team was awesome and really helped calm me down. According to Dr. Susan Love, by the time most cancers are large enough to be seen, they have been in the body for 8 - 10 years. There was no rush. AND - the truth is that most breast lumps turn out to be benign. May this be so for you!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2013 07:06AM Blessings2011 wrote: My mom is my hero. In 1983, when she was 60 years old, she was dx'd with BC. Of course in those days there wasn't much testing, and not much in the way of treatment. She was lucky - it hadn't spread to her lymph nodes, her liver, or her bones (funny the things you remember) so all she had was a radical mastectomy. It was pretty brutal. Her scar was huge and scary. But I loved looking at it because it meant that I still had my mom with me. She never lost her dignity or her sense of humor. She'd go in for a mammogram on the remaining breast and tell the tech "Now remember - you're only going to charge me half price!" She passed in 2009 from Parkinson's, at the age of 88, with no recurrence of cancer. Two years later, I would be dx'd with BC at the same age Mom was. My first impulse was to call my mom. I needed to hear her voice telling me everything would be o.k. Sadly, I couldn't do this, but all along my path I have heard her voice, calming me and guiding me. Whatta woman!!!! Miss her every day.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2012 10:28PM Blessings2011 wrote: gabe2011 - Yes, it's normal to have pain four days later. I was in severe pain, both in the hospital (because I wouldn't use the morphine PCA) and later at home because I was trying to stay off the narcotics. At my one-week post-op appt, my BS was horrified that I was still taking the max amount of Norco! Half an hour later, though, the PS said that was crazy, and that of course I was still having pain from all that I had been through just the week before. Narcotics and pain meds have their place. There is no medication that will completely eliminate all pain all the time, but taken correctly, pain meds will take the edge off so that we can function during the day, and sleep well at night. A body that is in constant pain is stressed, and a body that is stressed cannot heal properly. I felt guilty that I was experiencing "pain" when so many others were just reporting they had "discomfort". Here I am, 25 days out from my BMX/TEs, and I can tell you that yes, it will get better. if you aren't sure, please do contact your doc. They're used to these questions.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 09:48PM Blessings2011 wrote: I do have to say that we have three recliners here at home, and for me, it would be impossible to sleep all night in any one of them. What did help - a lot! - was renting a fully electric hospital bed for $200 a month. I also rented an over-the-bed table to hold all my junk. I put a Tempurpedic topper over the hospital mattress, and an electric blanket on the bed. I have small pillows that I bunch up and put under my arms. At night, when I'm ready to sleep, I raise up the bed under my knees, and recline my head back to get comfy. The support is incredible, even with my bad back. I barely move all night. But if I do need to get up during the night, I have a remote control button attached to the hospital bed controls, that turns my reading lamp on. I can also lower the bed, and raise the head, meaning I don't have to call on DH for help.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2014 03:13PM Blessings2011 wrote: Dear FeDragonfly - you feel like you are in a whirlwind because that's EXACTLY where you are. News like this just pulls the rug out from under us and sends us spinning. However, there are a few things I do want you to remember: 1. The MAJORITY of breast issues are benign - NOT cancer. 2. Many of the ladies sitting on the bench in the Mammo waiting room will be called back in for additional imaging, and many will be referred for ultrasound. Thank goodness our medical professionals are so diligent at doing their jobs. What they are trying to do is RULE OUT any possible abnormalities, not diagnose you with something serious. 3. The lady in scrubs sitting next to you sounded comforting, but a bit premature in suggesting that you will have a needle biopsy. She has no idea what your mammogram results showed. You may need something as simple as an MRI, or the doctor may just want to do some simple explanation to you in person. 4. Right now, you don't have bad news. You just have news. PLEASE take a deep breath, and find something you love to do, and do it. Stay busy. Keep your mind occupied, or else it will take you to dark places. (And stay off Dr. Google!!!! He can be a liar and a fearmonger!) 5. If you spend all your time worrying about the future before you ever meet the Breast Specialist, and your results turn out to be benign, then you will have thrown away valuable time in your life worrying about nothing. 6. I'm really sorry your Mom is in ill health. I know how stressful that can be. Not to minimize your situation in any way, I would be grateful that my mom had a 2 - 7 year life expectancy rather than a 2 - 7 week, or 2 - 7 month life expectancy, which many ladies here are dealing with. Sad as it is, you have the time to make the most of your relationship with her. 7. Congratulations on the birth of your newest grandchild - what a blessing! 8. Make sure you have someone with you when you go see the Breast Specialist. Have them take notes for you if you are too distracted. We can't always process ALL the information right away. Understand that if you miss something you can always call back. 9. Like I said in the beginning, the majority of breast issues are benign. However, if it turns out that there is more going on in your case, you have come to the VERY best place for information, encouragement, and support!  10. Please do come back here and post after you have seen the doctor. Let us know how you are doing! Wishing you the best......

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2012 01:14PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, nibbana - so sorry to hear about your diagnosis, but very glad you found this forum. So much goes into whether or not there is a recurrence of cancer in the other breast! You need to know all the details of the results of your biopsy reports, your exact type of cancer (aggressive? slow-growing?), the IHC (Immunohistochemistry) details, BRCA status, etc.....these things are usually explained at the time you meet with your breast surgeon to discuss the types of treatment available to you. You may feel "green" now, but trust me, you will become an expert. Are you scheduled to see a breast surgeon? Is there a Nurse Navigator or Breast Care Coordinator at your doctor's office? Perhaps you could call and get more information before you see the surgeon. Personally, my IDC was a microinvasion from DCIS (non-invasive cancer) found in the left breast. Because of my history and risk factors, I decided on a bilateral mastectomy (BMX) with immediate reconstruction. I could have had a lumpectomy with radiation, but chose a different way to go. There are so many wise women here to share their experiences...I'm sure they will be along soon. Wishing you the best....

I said fine. I hadn't been that size since 6th grade :-O I did a LOT of searching the Internet for pics! Just keep in mind that yes, there will be some scary ones, but all in all, I'm glad I did. I got a good look at what the mastectomy scar itself will look like (much smaller that the one my mom had in her day) as well as what a reconstructed breast looks like using the various options. The other thing I wanted to say is that you are guaranteed by law to have matching boobs (as best as the surgeon can do.) Seriously. If you want to go smaller on the left, you can have a reduction and a lift to match the new right side. Hope you stay free of the germ bombs in your classroom and are well and healthy before your surgery!

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2012 12:52PM Blessings2011 wrote: Wow, meny - interesting study. Looking at the actual details, I see that it was conducted on women who were undergoing only biopsies or lumpectomies. And, according to the study, there was NO DIFFERENCE in the amount of pain medication used after surgery, only in the amount of propofol and lidocaine during the procedures. It's just that the women who had been hypnotized REPORTED less pain after the procedures. Looks like they still took the meds. I agree with the concept of hypnosis before surgery to calm anxieties, and to "set up" our minds to believe that our pain and nausea levels will be minimal. (Believe it, but can't say for sure, since I've never been hypnotized.) I'm wondering about the overall cost of surgery being "significantly less", though....certainly, you wouldn't be charged for as many drugs.....but unless the billing clerk was hypnotized to ignore some of the costs, I can't imagine the pricing would be all THAT different! (The study reported that on average, the hypnotized women took ten and an half minutes less in the OR, resulting in a $700 savings.) "Overall, our results support the present hypnosis intervention as a brief, clinically effective means for controlling patients' pain, nausea, fatigue, discomfort, and emotional upset following breast cancer surgery beyond traditional pharmacotherapeutic approaches," stated the authors. This is very interesting to me because I participated in a ten-week Chronic Pain Management Program at my local hospital several years ago, and I am still practicing what I learned.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 12:51AM Blessings2011 wrote: mesha_38 - I'm so sorry you are going through this. It's hard enough to have suspicions, and then to not have anyone really listen to you makes you think the absolute worst. You definitely need a second opinion, and it sounds like someone (radiologist? GP?) is also recommending an MRI. If a doctor is recommending this, then you need to find someone who can provide you with the services you need. I, too, had very dense breasts, and nothing ever showed up on a mammogram. When I started having problems, it took an ultrasound to find it. When I was 18 I had a benign fibroadenoma removed that was the size of a walnut. That one didn't hurt a bit. But eventually, my breasts got very dense, heavy, and fibrocystic, to the point where self exams were impossible. They hurt all the time, and this was waaaay before I was diagnosed with BC. I did have to watch out for caffeine, because it seemed to make the pain worse. In your case, though, it sounds like you just need a different breast surgeon, or someone who can arrange for you to get the tests you need. Even if it's benign (hoping so!), you still need answers. Wishing you the best....

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 02:16PM Blessings2011 wrote: MsMay - I can't comment on the implant question, as I'm not a "small woman", but I do have a few comments on drains. My PS removed the drains once they reached a certain level per day (I forget how much) OR at the two-week mark. He felt that the possibility of infection outweighed the need for drains at that point. Mine came out at two weeks. What some women find is that the more they move their arms, the more drainage there is.  We have a saying around here - "Just because you CAN, doesn't mean you SHOULD!" What that means is that you need to stay active... walk, gentle stretches, etc, plus whatever the PS has cleared you for.  But if you are doing a lot of lifting and reaching and carrying and other exertions involving your arms, it could be increasing your fluid output. Try laying low for a day or so and see if that changes the amount of drainage. And remember: the drains are temporary! As crappy as it may feel to have to deal with them, it is MUCH better to have all that excess fluid drain out of you rather than build up inside, after the drains are removed.

The "discomfort" I can take - those random pulling/aching/stabbing pains that are intermittent. But the constant burning/aching/throbbing pain that seems to be centered on my chest wall does keep me from sleeping and resting, so doc says TAKE THE DRUGS! However, I do feel like I should soon be turning the corner on pain. Every day I feel  bit more range of motion, even though I'm not supposed to be doing anything with my arms.  Drains are slowing down, gone from red to pink to pinkish-yellow. Thank goodness I'd read so many posts here about what to expect in the bulbs. Pre-op instructions said to empty them twice a day, morning and night. But when the PS saw me the morning he discharged me, the drains were full, and he said I needed to empty them WAY before that - at least by the half-full mark, or else there wouldn't be enough suction. In the hospital, the nurse folded the empty bulb in half, then rolled it up toward the cap, THEN put the cap back on. We adjusted the charts at home so we could write in drain emptying four times a day. I have a disposable pad I put over my lap and under the drains as DH unplugs and empties them. (The nurse said they could squirt across the room if you're not careful!) Having "stations" set up before I came home was a good idea. I took plastic trays - one for meds (pain, nausea, antibiotic, etc.) along with charts on clipboards to note what I took, how much, and when. DH is the keeper of the charts. I am capable of taking my own meds, but it helps to have one person in charge. I have another tray for drain care - it has the surgical gloves, the alcohol wipes, and the log for measurements. My cousin who is a nurse said to be especially careful with the drains - they are a doorway for bacteria to enter the surgical wounds. Sorry - I may be repeating myself here! Glad to see more sisters coming home from surgeries - sending hugs and healing wishes to you!

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 07:52PM Blessings2011 wrote: Regarding meds: I've never had Percocet - I got good ol' morphine in my in-patient PCA, then I got went home with Norco for pain - same as Vicodin (hydrocodone)  but with less Tylenol in it. I tolerated it very well. Just remember that there are lots of pain meds they can prescribe in case one does not work well for you. I'm allergic to almost every antibiotic, including Keflex, and horrifically allergic to Clindamycin! I was afraid to take the Cipro they gave me IV in the hospital, and for ten days at home, but I did, and except for taking some Benadryl along with it in the beginning to prevent itching, I  never had any side effects! Good to know in case I ever get Anthrax! (Cipro is the drug they use for Anthrax...) Zofran has been around a long time. It was originally developed to prevent nausea and vomiting in chemo patients. Many years ago, I started to request it during surgery, and I no longer experience post-op nausea or vomiting. For at home use, however, I was given Phenergan. I've had experience with Phenergan suppositories, which are wonderful for uncontrollable vomiting, but for me, the pills had the annoying side effect of muscle twitching/spasming. Fortunately my cousin, an ER nurse, had warned me about this. The first one I took was also the last one I took. I started taking the Colace the day of surgery. Some ladies start earlier. I thought for sure I wouldn't need them, since my diet is fairly good, and I take a good probiotic. WRONG! Even though I was eating prunes and drinking prune juice in addition to the Colace, I still needed a day or two of the Milk of Magnesia. I might try the Valium for muscle spasms. I start my fills on January 3rd. I also asked my PS about Robaxin - a muscle relaxer I was prescribed for back muscle pain. He said it wouldn't hurt to try it if I felt I needed it.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 12:23AM Blessings2011 wrote: Let's see...I met with the PT/LE Specialist at the hospital yesterday and liked her a LOT! I did share with her how disappointed I was in how little emphasis was placed on LE, not only before/after my surgery ( I "only" had an SNB), but also at the workshop I went to where I got some ridiculous information. She started out by explaining LE in easy, understandable terms, and gave me more explicit info on how to avoid it, especially in my left arm. Just because I had only three nodes removed, and have no signs of LE now, I could get it anytime in the future, and it pays to be safe. She said one of her BC patients had no LE at all for ten years, then one day her garage door got stuck open, and she yanked really hard, repeatedly, to get it shut. Then the LE hit. She said that if I were to go back to the gym, the free weights were better than the machines....but either way, my maximum limit should be 5 pounds. (I think they had me at 40 pounds before surgery!) I asked about cording. She checked my upper arm and didn't feel anything, so I told her to check harder inside my armpit. She agree that I might have some minor cording (Axillary Web Syndrome) and that in the majority of cases, this was self-limiting - it would go away on its own. But if I wanted to, she showed me how to do some massage, with my thumb moving one way and my fingers the other way, to stretch it out. (It really hurt when she did it - but only because my skin is so sensitive, and she didn't use lotion. "Oh my!" she said when she saw the red marks on my skin. "You need to be more gentle than I was, and use lotion!" ....."or do it in the shower..."). I could still feel the area yesterday morning, but it felt like a wire instead of a rope, so I think it's getting smaller. She said that cording is an irritation of the lymph duct, and is not lymphedema. In my case, it was very small and would probably go away soon. But in the meantime, she encouraged me to keep taking the LE precautions. The seroma, which felt like the size of a golf ball after surgery, is now just barely perceptible. She said it as o.k. to massage that as well, to help it reabsorb into my body. I came home with a bunch of new exercises, and a whole lot better understanding of LE and cording.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 06:41PM Blessings2011 wrote: Bogie - Since surgery, I've always had blood draws and BPs done on my right side, where no nodes were removed. No one yet has said that this would be a problem....they said just avoid it on my left (SNB) side. Kam170 -  The LONG version of my story is on page 36 of this thread, somewhere in the middle. The SHORT version is that I need to lose at least 40 pounds, and Kaiser is offering an 82 week Weight Management Program. The first 16 weeks involve meal-replacements in the form of shakes, soups, and bars. I need to get this fat off for two reasons: 1) My cancer is estrogen-positive, and even though I'm post-menopausal, my big honkin' belly fat is still producing estrogen. 2) I want my PS to have the best material to work with at the time of my exchange. If he puts in 700cc or 800cc high profile implants just so I can have some projection over my big gut, and I lose weight later, I will end up looking like Dolly Parton. NOT for me!!! I already know he will be doing extra work cleaning up some of my side boobage, and armpit fat/spillover, and it would be better to have lost the weight prior to going into the Exchange Surgery. I was worried that my exchange might come sooner than I'd expected, because he was filling me so fast. But this morning I got only 80ccs on the left, and 60ccs on the right. I didn't tell him to stop; he just felt the TEs and said that was all for today. So actually, if we slow down, my wait until exchange (final TE fills + 3 months waiting period) may take me closer to my original date. The meal replacement plan is faster than WW. I love WW, but I only lose a pound a week and often hit plateaus. I am very limited in how much I can exercise, and my doctors seem to think this program is a good jump-start to getting down to a normal weight. I can count on losing up to 40 pounds in four months. Then we start easing back into home cooked meals. Sorry....guess my SHORT answer wasn't so short after all!

They delivered the hospital bed yesterday, and I put it the sitting area of our master bedroom. I've made it up to be soothing and cozy. The reason for the hospital bed is that we have a Tempurpedic mattress on our bed, and while it's fabulous for sleeping with a bad back, it is sort of like swimming in jello when you try to get out of it without using your arms. This way, I can raise the head of the bed, have something under my knees to take the pressure off my back, and can raise and lower it to get out of bed by myself. We have recliners, but 1) they aren't comfortable to sleep in, and 2) I wouldn't be able to reach the handles to sit up again! I've cut back on my food intake - no meat since last week - and am keeping well hydrated. I've found that this works well for me before any kind of surgery. I'm getting my protein from other sources. Got some meals frozen, got my button-front clothes ready to go, got my bag packed for the hospital. While my pretty satin jammies might feel good, I think I'll use their hospital gowns while I'm there. I'm concerned about is picking up/bringing home germs from the hospital. Sad, huh? DH and I decorated the house (inside and out) with a FEW of the Christmas decorations we usually put up. Whatever WE put up, HE has to take down! Thanks again to those of you who posted that the anticipation was much worse than the reality of surgery! As long as I keep the focus off myself, and on Him, I'm o.k. Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 04:33AM Blessings2011 wrote: Ladies - here are some notes I took from my meeting with the Oncologist on Friday. I hope this post isn't too long. I thought about creating a new thread, but I'd promised to post here. If you think I should put it in a separate thread, I will. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Recap:  Heavy, dense breast tissue, normal mammograms every year for the past 20+ years. Bleeding from left nipple in September: two diagnostic mammograms, two ultrasounds, one galactogram, and two core-needle biopsies. Dx: Multi-focal cancer, mostly DCIS (one area of DCIS AND IDC, a second area of just DCIS). ER/PR+; Her/2/Neu -.BMX/TEs on December 5, 2011. SNB clear, final path report clear. No evidence of any IDC in either breast. So this is the information the Oncologist had when we met on Friday. 1)  First, she told me that she was very pleased with all the results of my testing. The cancer was small and caught early. (She, too, agreed with the idea that the core needle biopsy had removed all the invasive cancer so none was detectable on final pathology.) 2) She said that in cases like mine, chemotherapy and radiation would not be needed, but that she would offer me medication to prevent recurrence. (Later, it didn't sound like an offer at all, but rather a mandate.) 3)  Even though the areas of IDC were small - .5 mm ( grain of salt) and 1.5 mm (half a grain of rice) this now puts me at future risk for either a local or a distant recurrence. 4)  A local recurrence would mean that more invasive breast cancer cells could be found in the breast tissue. There is no way every single cell of tissue can be removed at the time of mastectomy,  and it could be possible that a microscopic invasive cancer cell could still be lurking there. We don't believe there is any, and the reports would back this up. 5)  A distant recurrence would mean that invasive breast cancer cells have spread (metastasized) to other body parts such as the lungs, liver, or spine. This would be very serious, and treatment options at that point would be very limited. She used the word "incurable", as treatment would focus on quality of life and minimizing the spread of the disease. We don't believe this has happened, or is likely to happen, as there was no lymph node involvement, nor any vascular involvement. 6) My particular type of invasive cancer is considered a microinvasion because it was so tiny. It is considered Stage 1A. And the IHC tissue analysis indicated that it was a very slow-growing (non-aggressive) type of cancer. So the odds of it spreading anywhere else in the body are very low at this point. The actual risk of recurrence is between 1% and 2%. 7)  The tumors were estrogen and progesterone positive. Even though I'm post-menopausal, the adrenal cortex still produces estradiol, as does cholesterol, and belly fat. Since I am not having chemo or rads, the next best treatment to prevent recurrence is to take either a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) like Tamoxifen or Evista, OR an Aromatase Inhibitor (AI) such as Arimidex or Femara. 8)  She is recommending Arimidex pending the results of the labwork she ordered. In particular she will be looking at bone density, liver function, Vitamin D level. Most likely I will need to take Fosamax as well. 9)  The most common side effect of Arimidex is body aches...because I have fibromyalgia, this may be a problem. I can try the others (Femara, Aromasin) but if I can't tolerate those, the only alternative would be Tamoxifen. 10) The purpose of this drug is not to prolong my life. The purpose would be to prevent a local or distant recurrence of breast cancer. 11)  I do not need the Oncotype test - the IDC was too small (< 1 cm) 12)  I do not need the BRCA test - there is no family history to indicate this. (Mom was post-menopausal when she was dxd.) 13)  I can still take Premarin vaginal cream for vaginal dryness - a tiny amount, several times a week and tapering off when no longer needed. She did say that this is a case of "use it or lose it" and that chronic vaginal dryness can be helped by intercourse, or other stretching of the vaginal tissues. 14) I don't have to eliminate every source of soy from my diet, I just need to not use soy milk as my regular source of milk. I'm switching to Lactose-free milk. Example - my fish oil capsules contain soy. I can still take them. 15) I can take vitamins, but I should NOT take any anti-oxidants. Recent studies have shown that they help ALL cells grow, including cancer cells. 16) For AI side effects such as hot flashes, Effexor is o.k., as is black cohosh, but no other herbal supplements can be used. I've said the visit was "sobering" because I was under the impression that my surgery was sort of the maximum treatment for the minimal diagnosis. I was really hoping that I could say "thanks, but no thanks" to a drug that would have no bearing on my future quality of life. Now I have a lot to think about. I've heard so many comments from people saying "Oh, now you are cancer-free and never have to worry about breast cancer again!" ....and unfortunately, this isn't really the case. Right now, there is no evidence of disease. I am praying that there will be no evidence of disease in me until the day God calls me home for whatever reason. There are no guarantees in this world. Stuff happens. Accidents happen. I could get run over by a truck tomorrow as I walk to my mailbox. Statistically, this isn't likely, nor is the chance that I will experience a recurrence of this breast cancer. So it's up to me to stay vigilant but not obsessed, and live the rest of my life committing to be the healthiest and happiest I can be. Not a bad goal for anyone, actually. Oh - almost forgot - the Oncologist asked if I did much reading on the Internet. She warned me about there being so much bad information out there, and if I WERE going online, to be sure to go to BreastCancer.Org - that they had the best, most accurate info of any of the online sites.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 04:19AM Blessings2011 wrote: I posted here a while back about having my doubts about taking the Arimidex, and when I emailed my MO my concerns, she told me to come back in and we'd talk. So I saw her yesterday, and oh, what a good meeting! I told her that at our first meeting, I felt like all she had done was throw statistics at me, and that my questions weren't answered. I  then went on to say that I understood that stats were what she did - that her goal was to reduce the risk of any recurrence in her cancer patients. I also said I hadn't asked the right questions so she could give me the right answers. I told her that it wasn't that I was afraid of GETTING side effects from the Arimidex; it was that I already HAVE many of the side effects...and what would adding this drug do to my QOL? She was very patient and listened well. Bottom line - I told her I would try the Arimidex and we would discuss side effects. Based on how bad they were, I could try another drug, or she would just tell me that the risk was not worth the benefit, and to stop taking the drug. I think that's what worried me the most.....that to her, QOL would not factor into the big picture, when it really does. She said that taking the Arimidex would lower my current 1% - 2% risk of recurrence another 20% - 40%, as close to zero as possible. I'm so glad we understand each other.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 10:27PM Blessings2011 wrote: Kam - I had that discussion with the MO when I was trying to use the CancerMath site to convince her that I didn't want to take the Arimidex. My sole focus was quality of life. Her sole focus was preventing recurrence. If I understood her correctly, then yes, CancerMath does predict only mortality and survival rates, not possibility of recurrence. This appears to be verified by their website information. I think that all we can do is listen to our docs, make our decisions based on what we believe is best for our bodies, and let go and have peace of mind that we've made the right decisions for ourselves. Maya Angelou says "We do the best we can with what we know. And when we know better, we do better." "Mets" was never in my vocabulary before my dx. It is now, but it is not what I focus on. "Mortality" was also something I never paid much attention to. I still don't. We just don't know what's around the next corner, and if I spend all my energy worrying about tomorrow's problems (that may never happen), it will just rob me of all today's joy. I just can't live like that. Part of it is my strong faith. I believe in hope. What I DON'T believe in is numbers on a screen. CancerMath has no useful purpose for me anymore. It is not a crystal ball, and it can't predict my future.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2012 07:46PM Blessings2011 wrote: I was dx'd with multifocal cancer in my left breast - DCIS (non-invasive) and IDC (invasive) in two different areas - in September 2011. After spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple (never found a lump), I had seven different diagnostic procedures: screening mammogram, diagnostic mammogram, ultrasound, ductogram, and two ultrasound-guided core needle biopsies. The last procedure I had was a diagnostic mammogram on the right. Within days after the first US-guided core needle biopsy, I had my IHC results: ER/PR+, and Her/2/Neu -. The Radiologist was always suspicious that I had something going on in the right breast. She wanted me to have a breast MRI to rule anything else out. The breast surgeon offered me a lumpectomy with radiation, but said that due to the cancer being in two different places, she would have to take a large wedge of tissue, and I would probably be better off with a unilateral mastectomy. After carefully researching my options, and thinking about my history, I chose to have a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction using Tissue Expanders. With that decision, I no longer needed to have the breast MRI. Had I chosen the lumpectomy with radiation, I would have needed the MRI just to rule out anything else going on in both breasts.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2012 07:15AM Blessings2011 wrote: Sassie73 - what toomuch said is definitely true. The waiting is really the hardest part...there are so many unknowns, and for some reason, our minds just seem to go down the darkest path!!! But she is also right when she says the majority of breast lumps are benign. If you spend all your time worrying about the "what if's" of this breast lump, and it does turn out to be benign, then you will have worried for nothing. You will have robbed yourself, your husband, and your child of any of the joys of this Thanksgiving week. Instead, please take a deep breath, find something you love to do, and do it. Keep busy. The 26th is just around the corner....not so far away. Wishing you the best...please come back and update us after your appointment. And try to have a wonderful Thanksgiving!!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 11:53AM Blessings2011 wrote: Nurseash85 - So sorry you are going through this. Last September I had a small amount of spontaneous bleeding from my left nipple. The next day I saw my PCP, and two days later I saw the Breast Surgeon. She assured me that it was probably a papilloma, but referred me for further testing to rule out anything more serious. She told me that papillomas were very, very common in women, but must be surgically removed, as they almost always eventually cause bleeding. I had two diagnostic mammograms, two ultrasounds, a ductogram (which failed, as the duct was almost completely blocked), and two Ultrasound-guided core-needle biopsies. It was only the last two procedures that found not only DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ, or non-invasive cancer) plus a small microinvasion of IDC (invasive cancer). Even then, the Radiologist was still concerned about the right breast. Both screening and diagnostic mammograms were unclear enough that she wanted me to have an MRI. But by that time, I had already made my decision. Because of my history and my risk factors, I decided to have a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. I was 60 years old at the time, and it was the right decision for me. You are very young. You deserve the best, most agressive, determined specialist you can find - a breast surgeon, not a general surgeon. Hopefully, you will find that the causes of your bleeding and abnormalities are all benign, and that a simple procedure can alleviate your fears. But get yourself to a Breast Surgeon!
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon and so Confused-Please Help Nurseash85 Blessings2011

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2012 11:24AM Blessings2011 wrote: Nurseash85 - now that you mention it, nothing was ever tested on my discharge. It was dark reddish brown, and watery. If the breast surgeon took a smear, I sure don't remember it, and I certainly never got any results back. But I understand that other women with bloody nipple discharge do get it tested. No,  I didn't have a lump, per se. My Original Girls were very large (38DDD) - heavy, droopy, fibrocystic, and painful. They felt like bags of rocks, and self-exams were impossible. But I passed every yearly mammogram I'd had for the past 20 years. Every year, I asked my PCP for additional testing, like an ultrasound. He always refused, saying that an US is not a screening tool. But when I showed up in his office with a bleeding nipple, THAT got his attention! Make sure you resist the temptation to see if the nipple is still bleeding by squeezing it. That could make it more difficult for the specialist to see it. I had a hard time with my ductogram, because we couldn't make the bleeding start. We had to have the mammo tech assist by "milking" the breast itself, not just the nipple. (We actually had a good laugh over that. When the Radiologist asked for her help, her reply was "Oh sure, ask The Milker..." a reference to her growing up on a small local dairy.... ) With a history of breast cancer in your family, you have a right to be concerned. However, try to remember that more than 80% of breast lumps are benign, and that your shoulder pain could be something as simple as the strain of being a nurse and lifting heavy things (like patients). Keep plugging away until you find a specialist you are comfortable with. Wishing you the best....

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 04:40AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Becky2405, and welcome to the forum! Sorry you had reason to find us, but this is the best place to be in terms of information and support. Spiculated lesion just means that it is a lump of tissue with spikes or points on the surface. It's important to keep in mind that both benign and cancerous lesions can be spiculated. Right now, you don't have BAD news, you just have news. You will find out more at your diagnostic mammos and ultrasound. Your surgeon may even want to get a biopsy, but even that is no reason to panic. This is really the hardest part - the waiting and the uncertainty. Our minds take us down scary roads when we don't have enough information. I would caution you to stay away from Dr. Google - he can be a liar and a fearmonger. Stay busy and distracted. Find something you love and go do it. You'll have results soon enough. If there is, in fact, something to worry about, you will take it one day at a time, step by step. And there are a gazillion women here to help you! Hoping for benign results on your upcoming tests.... (p.s. Glad the power did not go out and strand you in the mammo machine!)

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2014 02:04PM Blessings2011 wrote: At 12 years old, they are certainly more knowledgeable than we were at that age!  Our 13 y/o grandson also has Asperger's, and he deals best with simple, straightforward, concrete answers. If I had to tell him I was going to have surgery, I would say that I am going to have a lump removed. It's very common for women to have these lumps, and that the only way to study them is to take it out and look at it. It's a very routine procedure for women, and there is no need to worry. (Because right now, right this minute, there isn't. You don't have BAD news, you just have news.) If anything changes in the future, you can make more decisions then. Just remember that the majority of breast issues are benign... NOT cancer! Wishing you the best.....

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2014 03:54AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, 2014 Sistahs! I had my BMX in December 2011... so it's been a while. A few suggestions: If you usually decorate your house, and you still want to do it this year, do it early. DH was a trooper dragging stuff down from the attic after Thanksgiving, so we could make the house festive. I didn't have a comfy recliner to sleep in, and our bed is a massive Tempurpedic memory foam mattress which is like swimming in Jello, so I rented a fully electric, fully adjustable hospital bed for a month. I covered the mattress with a twin sized Tempurpedic topper and it was incredibly comfortable for my back. (I am not a back sleeper, but that's the only position you'll be in for a while.) We were lucky - it fit in the sitting area in our master bedroom. DH hooked up my reading lamp to a remote control and pinned it to my mattress, so I could turn out the light when I was tired. We got an over-the-bed hospital table, and toddler sized sippy cups and little snacks I couldn't spill. If you have any pain at all - take your pain medication around the clock! You can't catch up to pain, and the fight isn't worth it. Of course, you may be one of those ladies who goes home and takes nothing stronger than a Tylenol. But if you do take the pain meds, TAKE THE STOOL SOFTENERS!!!! Seriously. Just do it. I set up a Pain Station and a Drain Station in the bathroom. DH kept track of every pill I took, and at what time. The Drain Station contained all my alcohol wipes, surgical gloves, the measuring cup, and the log of bulb measurements. I actually had no problem emptying my drains myself, but it gave DH (a retired EMT) something to do to feel useful. We were very cautious about letting me have visitors. Our family is notorious about being deathly ill, then denying they are contagious. So we just told everyone I was in Quarantine. Which brings me to another important point: now is the WORST time for germs out in public places. My BMX was scheduled originally in October, but cancelled by the hospital for scheduling reasons. Then I was scheduled for November 8th, but as I was out and about trying to do my Christmas shopping early, I caught the WORST upper respiratory infection that lasted for three weeks. They barely let me have my surgery in December. So we armed ourselves with surgical masks, giant sized hand sanitizers, large cans of Lysol spray at each door, where we would spray the soles of our shoes after coming in from the outside, Clorox wipes in case anyone came in the house - we'd wipe down surfaces afterwards, and - every time we went to the hospital or the doctor's office, we always wore surgical masks (on the advice of our doctors.) I know, sounds like we were crazy people, but we didn't get sick, and I didn't have some horrible infection while trying to recuperate from a BMX. So I wish you all the best - quick, successful procedures, no complications, and complete healing. And remember.... the worst parts of recuperation are JUST TEMPORARY. This too, shall pass.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 06:57PM Blessings2011 wrote: chrissilini - I wasn't quite to the point of meltdown after I saw the Oncologist, but I sure had to take some time to revisit my direction in this journey. Part of the problem for me was my crowd of supporters (family and friends)...most of whom had no idea what having breast cancer means. I can't blame them at all - I had no idea, either! I do feel somewhat of a need to be positive in their presence, yet at the same time, a need to educate them on what it means to have a breast cancer diagnosis. (The pink ribbons in October don't really do much of that....) Now it's time for me to see the glass as half full! After all, the oncologist was PLEASED with my diagnosis. She was HAPPY that my risk of recurrence was so small. But what did I hear? Just the worst parts.....and my imagination took off. If there were 100 of us Stage 1A sisters in a room, 99 of us would probably have no recurrence at all for the rest of our lives. Why do we automatically assume we'll be the 1% that does? Sheesh. It's like if I'm driving around close to my neighborhood, and see smoke in the distance, I always think - oh, that could be my house on fire! Now that the new year is here, I want to change my focus from being sick, to living well. I know there are no guarantees that a certain lifestyle will prevent cancer, but if I lose weight, get stronger, lower my blood sugar and blood pressure, and improve my immune system, well, I think that will go a long way toward my feeling like a strong, healthy woman. And just maybe I can kick those AI hot flashes to the curb in the process! Prayers for you on Friday. Keep an open mind, listen to all the details, and focus on the positive ones. Hugs to you!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 08:15PM Blessings2011 wrote: Gosh, I was a big baby after I got home from my BMX on December 5th. I never, ever got my pain under control in the hospital (refused to push the PCA containing morphine) and I hated to think I needed to take the narcotics around the clock, but I did. Many ladies here - AND my awesome PS - told me that. So it was two Norco every six hours, around the clock. DH got up at 4 a.m. just to make sure I got my meds. Some days all I did was lay in bed and cry. I was so happy for all the sisters who had come home from surgery and took just a Tylenol, but I felt like a failure because I wasn't one of them. I could only sleep for maybe an hour or two at night, so of course, I had zero energy during the day. I did try to get up and at least walk around the house, or in the back yard, so I wouldn't get blood clots. Everyone was saying "Give it time!" and I was thinking "I already have!" I just hadn't given it enough time. Last week, almost a month after surgery, I had my first set of fills (which is amazing in itself, as my TEs had felt like they were on fire inside my chest from the get-go) - and - incredibly - my first day without pain! DH and I try to walk around the block, but I still shuffle and lose my balance. It's exhausting. We're up to two times around, though, and we plan to keep increasing it. Going back to work isn't an issue for me; I'm retired. But I know I would never have the energy to go back now, and maybe not even in another month. I think doctors tend to underestimate the time it takes to recover; it's usually the nurses that set you straight.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 12:53AM Blessings2011 wrote: Ginger - if you get that feeling again (something lodged in your esophagus) please contact your doc ASAP. I get pills stuck in the back of my throat all the time because I am so lazy I take them all at once. The little tiny Elavil pills burn like the dickens before I cough them out! Then I have to go out and eat a piece of bread (o.k., a Hawaiian roll) to make sure nothing else is stuck. But I do remember that tightness in my throat many years ago, and for me, it was a symptom of a hiatal hernia. For my niece, it's a narrowing of the esophagus that requires stretching on occasion. And not to sound alarmist or anything, but remember, as women, our heart attack symptoms are different than mens, and can present as indigestion or nausea. A nurse once told me that the biggest symptom of heart attack in women is denial. Just take good care of yourself!!!! And hoping you feel better every day.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 04:33AM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, yeah - here's the other part of the story.... I think I posted here about signing up for the Kaiser Weight Management Program in order to lose 40 pounds by June...well, after I announced to the entire world that I was going to do this, the doubts crept in. People started telling me how harsh that would be on my body, especially after major surgery. I started to doubt my ability to stay on the program for the entire four months of meal replacements. I decided to pray really hard, and to get out of God's way. I knew He had a plan for me, but I sure was trying to control everything by doing research, listing pros and cons, and having a gazillion appointments with other medical professionals at Kaiser. So I just asked for a sign...something that I could take for certain that I was on the right path. I asked my PS if I were healthy enough to go on a 960 calorie diet. He said yes. I had all my labwork done and it was all normal. I spoke to a Health Educator who told me that exercise was 60% of the program, and that I could do it myself if I followed a 1200 calorie-a-day plan in conjunction with one of the Registered Dieticians. She said all I needed to do was get an hour of aerobic activity per day. (Yeah, right, with all my other medical issues...) I had an EKG done that showed PROBABLE LEFT AORTIC ABNORMALITY. Turns out the EKG tech knew nothing about TEs, and that they would cause an abnormal EKG reading. (Learned that after-the-fact from my PS) I saw the Weight Management doctor who was pleased I wanted to join the program, but was very worried that the very low calorie diet would affect my healing, especially since I was looking at a June exchange date. She referred me to the MO for approval. Amazingly, the MO was THRILLED that I was going to go through the program. She said that no, I could not have any surgery during the meal replacement phase, but during transition, where food was reintroduced, I would be fine at about three weeks in. In her opinion, losing 40-50 pounds right now would be the absolute best thing I could do for my overall health (cholesterol, blood sugar, blood pressure, excess body fat) AND the best thing I could do for my breast cancer. In fact, she wants me to delay taking the Arimidex until AFTER the four-month meal replacement phase, so that whatever side effects I might get from the diet would not be confused with the side effects from the AI. SO - I took that as my sign. The next "cohort: doesn't start til March 15th, so I will sort of be in training to lower my food intake and up my water intake in the meantime. And finally, I realize that it's not a race to get my exchange. I would dearly love to have my squishies before summer, but the original date would have been in August anyway, had I not gotten some unexpected fills. So I will bide my time, follow the directions, and let the docs tell me when I'm healthy enough for my exchange. So thanks to all of you who have been telling me the same thing here!!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 10:38PM Blessings2011 wrote: Thanks, chrissilini - and congratulations to YOU! Slow and steady IS the way to go, and you're doing it the right way. Hi, Kam -  I made the decision to do Optifast on my own, because I asked my plastic surgeon what would happen if he put in permanent saline implants that matched the size of my TEs before I lost weight, and he said "The implants would look bigger afterwards." Well, I have in AMAZON sized expanders, and if he did match up the saline implants to the TEs I now have, and I did lose the weight later on, I would have stripper boobs. NOT what I want! I have about 40 more pounds to lose. My goal is 135 or 140. The other reason is one I hadn't thought of. I had to get my MOs approval before being accepted into this program, and when she saw I had applied to it, she was THRILLED!!! She said that if I hadn't done it myself, she would have referred me. She told me "The very best thing you can do for your overall health - AND your ER+ breast cancer - is to drop this weight, now!!!" Estrogen is produced in body fat, of which I have plenty. After I get off Optifast, I'll be taking the Estrogen-sucking drug Arimidex for five years. Someone just reminded me that this drug alone can add the pounds. So I'll be on the liquid diet for three more months, then slowly transition back to food. Most people on the plan continue to lose weight as they add regular meals to their days. Once I have been off the fast for three weeks, I can have surgery again, but I want to make sure I'm strong nutritionally, as well as physically, so I'm back at the gym. I'm expecting to have my exchange surgery in September.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 11:18PM Blessings2011 wrote: Rose - when I ended my 25 year university career in 2006, I always said that the very best part of it was when I was a Reentry Counselor. Meeting with adults who either abandoned their dreams for a degree because of Life, or just postponed them due to other circumstances, I was blessed every day with the most incredible people with the most amazing amount of determination and gratitude that something they once had thought was impossible, was actually happening. I had many students with major illnesses and disabilities along the way. Most  major institutions are prepared to accommodate students in any way they can. Sometimes it's really not about the degree at all - it's about being in a learning environment,  being motivated and encouraged and excited that you are finding out that you are still the same SMART person you thought you were when you were ten or fifteen or twenty, before you became a wife, a mom, a career woman, an unemployed person, an person with an illness, a person with bills, a mortgage, kids needing braces, a person faced with incredible debt after owing just a 20% deductible on medical charges.... Education can be expensive. Financial aid in the way of scholarships, grants, and loans is available. Community Colleges have wonderful classes for not very much money. Online courses are offered for those who can be disciplined enough to do the work without sitting in class, but enjoy the freedom of taking a course sitting at the computer in their jammies with a cup of tea, at 1 a.m. Me, I always loved the give-and-take of the  in-person classroom. But these days, many profs offer a scheduled time for students to chat, as well as online-chat in lieu of office hours. Love of learning is a lifelong affliction, by the way. It is highly addictive. After my Bachelors degree, I knew I wanted my Masters because I wasn't done learning. It was just that simple. I would being by identifying the area you wish to study, find out what institutions offer that program, look up their catalog online, and see if taking the entire list of required courses is something you want, or if you would rather pick and choose what you study. The Major Advisor for that program usually has the authority to waive and make substitutions for degree requirements. And many institutions offer the opportunity to create a Special Major. Please feel free to PM me if you have any questions.  I am always a cheerleader for education. p.s. I was also the Director of the 60+ Program. You had to be 60 to enter, all fees and tuition were waived, and you had to be following a degree program. My oldest student was 93. It's never too late.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 12:57PM Blessings2011 wrote: Welcome home, AussieKate! So glad you've had such a rapid improvement! ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Brilliant thoughts yesterday: 1. Just because I am home from BC surgery, that doesn't mean I can skip my regular meds while taking the pain pills and antibiotics! Duh. 2.  Just because someone brings a meal to my home doesn't mean I have to eat it! Duh. I found myself doubling up on the Norco I brought home from the hospital. I had a lot of break-through pain, so I thought taking the maximum amount would be a good thing. Not necessarily so! I had the dreaded narcotic constipation and by Friday, took my first Milk of Magnesia. Yesterday I took another one. Last night I was feeling really nauseated, and took a Phenergan. Today, let's just say that constipation is no longer a problem. Before I had my BMX/recon, I'd made a list of the foods I wanted to have handy. Small, snacky things, like little containers of fruit cocktail, jello, tapioca, yogurt, crackers, etc. That was before I realized what a huge church family we have, and that we would be inundated with tons of food - and not neccessarily healthy stuff. A lot of it has been rich, fatty, and not what we usually eat around here. Instead of my little healthy stuff, I've eaten whatever friends have delivered. Yesterday, we got all the leftovers from a Christmas party I couldn't attend! It was a sweet thought, but.....ugh. So back to basics - get back on the probiotics I usually take every day, and the fewer additional prescriptions the better.....(still have 5 days to go on the antibiotics) AND - more healthy eating. Fresh fruits and veggies, and sincere thanks to all who bring food. Rather than dictate to them what to bring, we just freeze it in smaller amounts to eat later, and send the rest over to my 90 year old father in law, who adores it.
