Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2011 11:37PM Blessings2011 wrote: chrissilini - after what I went through (big honkin' flu that derailed my November surgery) I am probably the most paranoid person when it comes to germs. This time of year is terrible for colds, flu, and other illnesses. I stayed home for a month before my BMX just so I wouldn't pick up anything else. After I got home, we told our family and friends that I was in quarantine for a few weeks just so they wouldn't come over and share their germs with me. (We seem to be surrounded by people who hack and cough and wheeze in your face, while proclaiming "Oh, I'm not contagious!" ) If you'd really miss seeing your Dad at Christmas, have him come by all means. But that means either he wears a mask, or you do. And he washes his hands, uses hand sanitizer, and someone follows him around the house wiping down everything he has touched: cabinet knobs, refrigerator doors, sink handles, light switches, etc. Now is NOT the time for you to try to recover from viruses.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 08:25PM - edited Sep 17, 2013 08:27PM by Blessings2011 Hi, SamanthaD - when I was 18, I had a benign fibroadenoma removed from my right breast. I'd had it ever since I had boobs, and just figured that if it were serious, it would have caused me more problems than it did. (Ah, the wisdom of teenagers.... ) When they finally removed it, it was the size of a ping-pong ball...but the shape of my breast was not distorted at all afterwards. My mom had BC, and as I got older, I knew I was at risk. Had I found any more fibroadenomas, I probably would have had them removed, as I would have been paranoid that they were hiding areas of cancer somehow.  But I never got any more, and it was 42 years later I was dx'd with BC in my left breast, totally unrelated to my fibroadenoma. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2012 01:50AM Blessings2011 wrote: Totally. One thing you will find here on BCO - we are all very different...especially in the way we heal. Some women can have a BMX w/TEs, come home, take a Tylenol, then run a marathon the next day. Then there's the rest of us. It takes TIME to recover from surgery, and for some, it takes longer than for others. Two months after my surgery, I was still weak as a kitten with no energy and a penchant for naps - frequent naps. That made me more depressed than anything. A few things that helped: Taking my pain meds regularly, and around the clock until I was certain I didn't need them any more. You can't "catch up" to pain, so take the meds. Move. You don't have to run a marathon, but start small and work your way up. My first exercise was limping down to the mailbox, clinging to the arm of my DH. Not tooo much longer than that, I was power walking. Make sure you are getting enough protein - "they" say we need at least 100 grams a day in order to heal. As soon as I bumped up my protein in the form of whey protein shakes and organic turkey jerky, my strength started to return. Stay hydrated. This was always a problem for me. I found that I could drink more diluted iced herbal tea than plain water. Get a good night's sleep. HAH! Easy to say, right? But if you are not getting enough sleep at night, you'll feel awful and wrung out the next day. Always check with your doctor if you feel something is not right. Ask if there is anything he can do to help you - especially in the area of pain or sleep meds. And many women find great relief from going to a physical therapist. Make an appointment and see if there are things that you can do to feel better. Wishing you the best....

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 07:57AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hart - when I was 18, I had a fibroadoma the size of a walnut - a BIG walnut - removed. I'd had it forever, but when I got to college, the doctor at the university said it had to come out. It was benign, and totally unrelated to the breast cancer I would be diagnosed with 42 years later. Here's the good news: the majority of all breast lumps, issues, and problems are benign....NOT breast cancer! But you are doing the right thing - letting a specialist check you out further to 1) get a baseline on what's going on in there, and 2) hopefully give you peace of mind that this is nothing to worry about. The mammogram should be brief, but don't freak out if you sit there in your gown afterwards while a radiologist looks at your films. They could call you back in for better views and clearer pictures. That happens a lot. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 08:50PM Blessings2011 wrote: After four mammograms, two ultrasounds, a ductogram, and two core-needle biopsies, I had a great relationship with my Radiologist. She said she would call me no matter what the results were. I gave her my best time frame and best phone number. When she did call, she was awesome. Wanted to know how I was doing from the biopsies, then said, I'm so sorry. It's cancer. Then proceeded to give me the good information (tiny, slow-growing, caught early), and stopped every few minutes to ask how I was doing, how I was processing this information, and if I needed her to repeat anything. We really did have a wonderful conversation, much more than just my dx. When I hung up the phone, I was shocked, I cried, but I was glad this doc was the one to tell me.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 08:45PM Blessings2011 wrote: Surgical masks!!! Hand sanitizer! Clorox wipes! This might sound excessive, BUT...... DH was diagnosed with kidney disease last year and put on massive doses of steroids. Because his immune system was pretty much destroyed, he wore a disposable surgical mask EVERY time he went out in public, and everytime he saw the rugrats (grandkids). He also put hand sanitizer in a little belt loop holder and used it religiously. He went off the steroids in December, and his immune system should be getting back to normal soon, so he's trying to go more places without the mask. I got sick a month before my BMX last November, so was in bed for a whole month before my surgery....I had been faithful about washing hands and using hand sanitizer, but the day I went to the Apple store for my iPad, the clerk was sniffling and coughing in my face. BAM. Down I went. My PCP reminded me that many germs are airborne, and to wear a mask especially to doctors' and hospital visits.  When I got home from surgery, I adopted the surgical-mask-in-public habit, too. Plus I use hospital-grade hand sanitizing foam in a little can from CVS. We also use Clorox wipes on surfaces that are touched, and whenever we go to the hospital for appointments, or the nursing home to see family, we spray Lysol on the soles of our shoes before we enter the house. We'll let up eventually, but in our case, a simple cold would have meant a very serious illness.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 01:01AM Blessings2011 wrote: When I was dx'd, I asked my DH how he felt about my boobs. He said "I like them, but I LOVE you, and I'd rather have you healthy." He went on to say that no matter what happened, we'd do it together, because we are a team. While I was still in the decision-making process, I made him go online with me and look at pics of women who'd had reconstruction, and those who had not. He was fully prepared by the time we met with the plastic surgeon. My mom had BC when she was my age. She had a radical mastectomy with no treatment, and no recon. I was as used to her huge scar as I was the curve of her smile. In my heart, I knew I wanted to give recon (implants) a try, but if that failed, I would have them removed and go flat immediately. DH understood and agreed, and the hardest thing for him was my coming home from the hospital in horrible pain - not from the BMX, but from the expanders. We both questioned the wisdom of having them put in. He was my Pain Man (gave me all my meds) and my Drain Man (took charge of emptying and measuring all the drains.) He was right - we were a team. I'm fully filled now (620ccs) and they feel like boulders. DH seems happy with them (he always was a rockhound) and I have no shame at all walking around topless - something I never did when I was a 38DD/DDD.  He knows the reality of a breast cancer diagnosis. Things can change in a heartbeat. But right now, I think the sexiest thing for him is the idea that I have a new reason to take good care of my body. I think this whole experience has strengthened our marriage.

Until you've been there yourself it's difficult to know how to respond.) I will continue to post Facebook messages throughout the month of October I hope they will be sort and to the point,so as not to lose the reader's interest. I will make posts on MBC separate because they are so important for others to understand. As for Pinkwashing, I've been posting about that for years - after one well-meaning friend, upon hearing I had BC, actually mailed me some cocktail napkins with pink high heels and pink ribbons. SERIOUSLY? That's how she showed her compassion? ARGHHH - I knew I had my work cut out for me. The reference to Pinkwashing in this year's FB post was a reminder from last year's which was longer. Ladies - with one in eight of us being dx'd with BC, we have a LOT of consumer power. There are a lot of ways we can protest - with our mouths, our letters and our wallets. I always take the time to complain to the managers of stores with huge pinkwashed displays. I let them know that I and my friends with BC will not shop there unless the display is tasteful and productive. I want to know where the money goes, and who profits by it. I let manufacturers know that I will no longer purchase their products as long as they are pinkwashed and do not reveal where the money goes. And I let them know there are a gazillion other women like me who will be boycotting their products until they gain some perspective and sensitivity towards breast cancer patients. O.K. Off my soapbox!!!! Hope everyone is having a great day, and enjoying these last few days of September! P.S. Never be afraid to speak up!

NOT GOOD! This is a very serious issue. 2.  Does the activity SEXUALIZE breast cancer? NOT GOOD! There is nothing sexy about breast cancer. 3.  Does the activity generate income to be donated to a reputable organization that provides direct services to women in need? GREAT! Posts.Content: May 26, 2014 03:28PM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, JoPete! If your eventual decision is mastectomy plus immediate reconstruction in the way of implants, then yes - you need two surgeons. The Breast Surgeon (BS) does the Sentinel Node Biopsy or Axillary Node Removal if necessary, and has not been done previously. Then he or she removes all the breast tissue to make sure there is nothing left behind (except for possible nipple/areola sparing MX.) They then send all the removed tissue off to the Pathologist for the final pathology report. Then the Plastic Surgeon steps in and takes over. He or she creates the pockets where the eventual implants will go, and inserts temporary Tissue Expanders, to stretch and create room for the expansion process, and whatever else their preference is, like Alloderm, or other materials used in the recon process. They insert drain tubes. They then close the incision and apply the bandages. (Every surgery is different; this is just a general description of common "immediate" recon surgery.) So - the BS opens, and the PS closes. My medical team called it "tag team surgery"... While you are waiting, you may want to go back to the home page of BCO. They have wonderful sections that are chock full of information that explains the different kinds of breast cancer, surgeries, treatment options, etc. There is a lot of knowledge on this site. Wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: Do I need two surgeons? JoPete Moderators

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2016 12:24AM Blessings2011 wrote: Blueorange - Let's see.... back in 2011 August 30th - bleeding from left nipple August 31st - saw Primary Care doc September 2 - Met with Breast Surgeon for consult September 8th - diagnostic mammogram, ultrasound, and ductogram September 12th - ultrasound-assisted core needle biopsy September 15th - Radiologist called with diagnosis of breast cancer SO - in 3 weeks I'd seen two docs, had four tests, and gotten a diagnosis. In the next two weeks, I had three more diagnostic tests. October 4 - Met with Breast Surgeon and Nurse Navigator to discuss options. Chose Bilateral Mastectomy with Reconstruction. October 10 - Met with Plastic Surgeon to discuss Reconstruction October 20 - Had Pre-Op for October 31st surgery, which, thankfully, was cancelled. Didn't want staff in Halloween costumes. November 8 - Surgery rescheduled, had to cancel - I had the flu. December 5 - FINALLY got my BMX and recon. December 30 - First meeting with Oncologist. She wanted to make sure she had the Final Pathology report first. So you can see that in the beginning, things moved quickly. (Thanks, Kaiser.) But once I had to miss my first two surgery dates, I could swear I could feel the cancer just growing inside me like a balloon blowing up. (The nurse explained that it wasnt.) I had my surgery three months after diagnosis. Saw my Oncologist nearly four months after diagnosis. Started my treatment (Aromatase Inhibitors) almost a year after diagnosis. You can see how different we all are. Some of that has to do with access to health care, but lots of it has to do with the type and size of your tumor(s). Mine were early and small, and waiting - according to the surgeon - was no big deal. Well, at least for HER. But it is not uncommon. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2016 12:38AM Blessings2011 wrote: rosierosie - All my docs just shook their heads and smiled when they walked into the exam room... there I was with my three pages of questions I had written down before every appointment. And I wouldn't let them leave before those questions were answered. That's why I suggested asking the doc about a Nurse Navigator. If the doctor isn't able to answer all your questions due to time limits, the Nurse Navigator is there for just that reason... to make complicated medical things understandable, and to make sure you feel like you are being heard. Oh - also, my mom was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 60 - same age I was. In those days there were no fancy tests, no reconstruction, or a variety of options, so she had a single mastectomy, and no other treatment. Every year she would go in for a mammogram on her remaining breast and tell the nurse "Now remember, you're only going to charge me half price for this!" She passed away, 28 years later, at the age of 88 from other health issues. She was still cancer-free at that point.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 04:08PM Blessings2011 wrote: Yeah! What everyone else said! Had bleeding from left nipple, saw PCP, he got me in to see the BS a day later, she explained all the possibilities, and referred me for the first of what was to be seven diagnostic procedures. During the first procedure, I got to know the Radiologist really well, and from then on, she was the one to keep scheduling all my biopsy stuff according to what each of the previous procedures had revealed. When she felt she was all done, and had aggressively searched for any and all cancers in my breasts, then the reports were sent back to the BS and the discussions about which surgery to have began.
Posts.Title: Confused about my upcoming BS appointment pp729 Sommer43

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2012 01:29AM Blessings2011 wrote: I was a 38DDD before surgery and had always wanted a reduction. Before my bilateral mastectomy (BMX) and immediate reconstruction, I told my plastic surgeon that I wanted to be smaller. I guess he didn't hear that very often... My mastectomy went very well, I got tissue expanders (TEs) inserted in the OR at the time of surgery. They were filled to 180 ccs so I actually had teensy foobs when I woke up. I am 7 weeks post-op and have had two fills so far. My chest is small, like that of a slender woman. (I'm not!) But I right now I'm at 400 ccs, and we are aiming for 700. What my PS has told me is that based on my size, he doesn't want to give me anything smaller than what equates to a C cup. I have a wide chest. What I have found here oh this forum is that we come in all different sizes and shapes. We've had all sorts of procedures, and each person is totally different. You'd be amazed at the great outcomes some of these women have. I'm so sorry you have to be here, but very glad you found this place. I went into my surgery and my reconstruction so much more confident because of the answers I found here. Welcome, Honeypotpie, and best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2011 02:07PM Blessings2011 wrote: Aw, DM13 - it's just normal to grieve for once was, especially when we're in pain and feeling vulnerable. But like others have said, this is a new beginning for you! Do you think your bad decision was having the surgery? Or letting your 14 year old daughter help you in the shower? My mom had a radical mastectomy with no reconstruction 25 years ago. Believe me, THOSE scars were horrific. But you know what? It helped me see my mom as a whole person. The scars were just her badge of courage that she had fought - and won - against breast cancer. That gave me great hope when I had my own BMX two weeks ago. I see my scars as my badge of courage, and the tissue expanders are just the symbols of hope that the shape of my body will return to a new normal down the road. Big hugs to you!!!! May you heal more every day!!!

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 11:43AM Blessings2011 wrote: Hi, Rose_NJ - so sorry about the big delay in your biopsy....I know how frustrating it is. In fact, my surgery was rescheduled twice - I was dx'd in September and didn't have my surgery til December. Oh, the images that went through my brain in the waiting period!!! Please try to take a deep breath and relax a bit. Nothing will change between now and the biopsy, and the best thing you can do for yourself is find something you love to do and stay busy doing it. Worrying about what may or may not be tomorrow's problems will only rob you of today's joys. Oh, and stay away from Dr. Google. Sometimes he's a big fat liar. This site - BCO - is the only "approved" site my oncologist will let me visit!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2016 07:13PM Blessings2011 wrote: rosierosie - so sorry you are joining this club that no one wants to join, but trust me - there are AMAZING women here who have been in your shoes. Everyone is here to help you, and this site is actually the only one my Oncologist said I could visit, as they had the most recent, valuable information. The hardest part, aside from waiting for biopsy results to come back, is to deal with all the anxiety and fear our minds produce when we have just a "little" information. Once you have met with your doc, hear more details, and learn more about your options, you will start to feel more in control over what's going on. Having a treatment plan makes it possible to take things one day at a time, one step at a time. Take another set of ears with you - that's always a good idea. I had a spiral notebook where I wrote everything down. Ask your doc if they have a Nurse Navigator to help you. They are wonderful. This year will be my five year anniversary. I was diagnosed in September 2011, and had my surgery in December 2011. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2016 09:48PM Blessings2011 wrote: Had BMX in the afternoon, stayed overnight. PS came by the next morning and asked if I were ready to go home. Since I never got my pain under control, I said no. He said fine, and OK'd another night. Two minutes later the Charge Nurse came storming into my room and said "What's this I hear about you not going home this morning? You need to LEAVE. This hospital is NOT the place for you to recover. You need to be home, in your own bed. Whatever you need, we'll make sure you get it before you go, but you have to leave. I don't want you to risk getting any infections." Sheesh! I told her to go ahead and contact the doc and have him give me my D/C papers. But aside from her scary bedside manner, she was absolutely right. My pain was not under control because I never used the morphine PCA. (I got a boatload of drugs for at home.) I was given all the info I needed on what symptoms to watch out for. I did feel better being in my own bed, but concerned that DH had to be my nurse. (He didn't mind.) I think the overnight stay was important for observation after a major surgery, but after that... I sure didn't want to pick up any hospital-acquired germs.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2012 01:16AM Blessings2011 wrote: I've had yearly mammos for the past 20 years. (Mom had BC.) I told THEM I had dense breasts. Dense, heavy, fibrocystic breasts. Ten years ago (around age 50) I started asking for ultrasounds as well as mammos. PCP always refused, saying that ultrasounds "were not screening tools." Every year I got a chipper postcard after each mammo - "Congratulations! No cancer detected!" Then ten months after my last one, I had bleeding from my left nipple. NO palpable lumps, no pain, no other symptoms. Turns out it was DCIS and IDC. Turns out it had been there a while.  Turns out you could have seen it on ultrasound. (Never got BIRADS.) THEN - I got seven different diagnostic tests. THEN - everyone listened to me. In all fairness, my Radiologist, who I love, told me what an inexact science mammos are. She said that she could see the beginning of the DCIS as far back as 2009 and 2010 in my screening mammos, only because she knew what to look for. She said if you put my mammos up on a screen in a room full of the best radiologists in the country, probably most of them would not notice such a small discrepancy. My invasive cancer was multifocal - one tumor was 1.5 mm (half a grain of rice) and the other was half a mm - a grain of salt. Actually, I think it's amazing that it was detected at all, but it was hiding in some larger areas of DCIS. They called it Stage 1A. Had BMX, no chemo, no rads.
Posts.Title: False-Negative Mammogram & Ultrasound Questions RobinJoy RobinJoy

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 10:36PM Blessings2011 wrote: cats134 - I read the title of your post, and it took a few minutes to realize "Hey, that would be ME!" I had my BMX w/TEs on December 5th, so on April 5th, that was four months for me. I was fortunate that I only had a SNB on one side - three nodes and none were involved. You had quite a few nodes taken, and from both sides....no wonder you are having more symptoms! I'm still numb in parts of my left armpit and the back of my left arm, and did experience a bit of cording and a seroma in the left pit, that both went away on their own. No lymphedema. When I got home from the hospital, I was totally obsessed with germs. I never touched any of my incisions, only dried off with fresh towels, and only wore freshly-laundered sports bras and nightgowns. Even though I did not need chemo or rads, I knew that having TEs left me open to all sorts of new kinds of infection. But the foob gods were gracious, and my incisions closed well. The stitching isn't great, and I told my PS that my quilting teacher would probably not give him an "A" grade, but it's temporary until my exchange. I was also lucky with fills. I am overweight and out of shape. This is the one time in my life where it paid off. I had lots of skin to work with and my muscles (pecs) were very lax, so I had no pain during fills. I now have 620 ccs of saline in each side, and they are like boulders inserted into my chest. Tough to sleep at night.... It's funny you should mention the tight bra feeling. So many nights (pre-BMX)  I'd sit there watching TV after wearing a tight bra all day (I was a 38DD/38DDD) and I'd reach back and unhook that bra and go "AHHHHHHHH"..... well, with TEs - and, apparently even without recon, there is no "AHHHHH" feeling. They do say that after exchange it gets better, though.... I DID have a rotator cuff tear...on both sides, actually, and I know that pain very well. Ten years ago I had a shoulder reconstruction done arthroscopically on the left side, and we left the right side, which wasn't as bad, to heal on its own. After my BMX, I was really afraid to move, but being the independent sort I am, I wanted to do everything myself. So even though I never went to PT, I have full range of motion in both arms. My stamina still kind of sucks. Some days I have energy; others, not so much. For the past two days DH and I have been digging up the garden and planting perennials. Just thinking about that reminds me of how far I've come! Normally, I would be having my exchange surgery in June, but I made a decision to take some drastic steps. Right now, if the PS puts in the permanent implants that match the size of my TEs, and I decide to lose weight later, I'll have stripper boobs. SO not cool.  So I made the decision to start an Optifast program at Kaiser, with meal replacements for four months. My goal is to lose 40 - 50 pounds. I can't have surgery until I'm out of the fasting phase and back into eating regular food. I really don't care how long it takes, but I'm thinking August or September. My MO was thrilled when she heard I was in the program. She told me that the very best thing I could do for my overall health - AND my ER+ breast cancer - was to drop this weight - NOW! So that's my plan. The truth is, breast cancer was always in the back of my mind. My mom had a radical mastectomy at the age of 67. It wasn't pretty, but her huge scar always made me think of her as a warrior. She had no recon and no treatment, and kept her sense of humor through it all. She died 20 years later, in 2009, still NED. When I made the decision to have the TEs, I had no problem with getting them removed if there were any issues, and just going natural. After all, that was my mom's normal. Cats134 - the only thing I would caution you about is comparing yourself to any other woman on this forum!!! I was so frustrated that after surgery, my pain continued for so long when others said all they took was a Tylenol for a day or two. But then there were the ladies who went through Hell with infection after infection, and my incisions healed up quickly with no issues. We are all SO different here! But I do understand....sometimes it's good to be alerted to possible complications, and it's REALLY good to read success stories! I have absolutely no regrets over my decision to have the BMX. No cancer was found in the right breast, but in my mind it was just a matter of time. I'd always wanted a breast lift, but never dreamed I'd get it this way! I'm in the process of getting healthier every single day, which wouldn't be happening if I hadn't gotten my BC diagnosis. And finally, I never would have met all the wonderful ladies here!!! Wishing you continued good healing...... (Just wondering....is your avatar one of your furbabies?)
Posts.Title: Four Months after a BMX, How's everyone doing? Cats134 Ddeal14

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2011 06:11PM Blessings2011 wrote: Jenjen - I have two tumors in my left breast: one is 9mm, and the other is 6mm. I had ultrasound-guided core needle biopsies on both of them. Most of what I have is DCIS - ductal carcinoma in situ - which is non-invasive cancer completely contained within the duct. On the larger tumor, I have two areas that are invasive cancer: one is 1.5 mm, and the other is .5mm (half a mm). Keep in mind that a millimeter is about the size of a mustard seed. So you can see that they can detect VERY small areas of cancer.  Now, having said that -  in the grand scheme of things, your suspicious area may be considered small, but there are so many other factors in determining what kind of tumor it is. There is more than just size to consider, and the fact remains that this may very well be benign!  You don't have bad news yet, you just have news. Wishing you well.....

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 07:31PM Blessings2011 wrote: Forgot to ask what surgery you had....I had a BMX with TEs on December 5th. Because my TEs were so excruciatingly painful, I was on Norco and Valium around the clock for three weeks. Seriously. DH even woke me up at 4 a.m. for my Norco dose. It was the only way I could stay ahead of the pain. I was moving around the house, walking in the yard, maybe around the block with DH, but driving was out of the question for me until about a month after surgery. I even packed a soft little pillow between me and the seat belt, and turned the steering wheel with my elbows at my sides. (I never ventured very far...) I also remember LOTS of naps! We'd be talking in the living room, and the next thing DH would do was look up and I'd be gone...back in the bedroom, out like a light, snoring away. Wishing you pain relief, and a quick recovery period!!!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 12:11PM Blessings2011 wrote: Oh, icefishinglady - I am FOUR MONTHS OUT and I STILL have no stamina!!! Part of it is all I went through before my surgery (very sick, BMX postponed) and then the stupid TE pain after surgery, and now I'm on Optifast, so they warn us not to work out too much. O.K.!!!! Fine by me!!!!  Nooooooo problem!!!!! It's weird....some days are great....last weekend we drove up to the mountains, had a picnic, shopped in a little town, drove some more to meet up with our kids and grandkids, and spent the rest of the day and evening with them. We got back home around 10 p.m. I had energy galore!!!! Well, then the next day I slept til noon, and stayed in my jammies all day! One question: are you eating enough protein? My DH has kidney disease, and is limited to 25-50 grams a day. I was eating the same thing he was. Then I read here that in order to heal well from surgery, we need at least 100 grams of protein a day!!! So I got some protein drinks from Trader Joe's, along with some organic turkey jerky, and upped my protein intake to around 100 grams. It sure helped me feel better! You may want to check with your doc on that... You are doing SO great for just having had your surgery!!!! PATIENCE, my friend....HAVE PATIENCE!!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 03:00PM Blessings2011 wrote: Syra101q - You asked "What are the chances I have cancer?" The chances are very, very, very, VERY small. In fact, the majority of all breast lumps, problems, issues, etc., turn out to be benign...NOT cancer!!! I'm so sorry to hear of your mum's passing, but please believe me, it will worry your dad MORE if you have something that needs looking at, and you don't tell him. I lived with my dad when I was 16, and sometimes it was hard to approach him with personal stuff. But a parent's job is to take care of their kids, not the other way around. Talk to your dad, make an appointment to see the doctor, if only to get peace of mind that your lump is nothing to worry about. Then please come back and let us know how you are doing!!! Hugs!!!
